events.text_segment: They could not, however, reach the great city the first day; so when night came on, they went into a wood to sleep. The ass and the dog laid themselves down under a great tree, and the cat climbed up into the branches; while the cock, thinking that the higher he sat the safer he should be, flew up to the very top of the tree, and then, according to his custom, before he went to sleep, looked out on all sides of him to see that everything was well. In doing this, he saw afar off something bright and shining and calling to his companions said, ‘There must be a house no great way off, for I see a light.’ ‘If that be the case,’ said the ass, ‘we had better change our quarters, for our lodging is not the best in the world!’ ‘Besides,’ added the dog, ‘I should not be the worse for a bone or two, or a bit of meat.’ So they walked off together towards the spot where Chanticleer had seen the light, and as they drew near it became larger and brighter, till they at last came close to a house in which a gang of robbers lived.

events.title: A Cacophonous Concert Drives Out Thieves
detailed_summary: The ass, being the tallest, approached the window and peered inside the house.
Chanticleer, the cock, asked what the ass could see.
The ass described a table laden with abundant food and drink, surrounded by robbers enjoying themselves.
The cock remarked that it would be an ideal lodging for them.
The ass agreed, if only they could gain entry. They then collaborated on a plan to expel the robbers.

Their strategy involved the ass standing on his hind legs with his forefeet against the window, the dog climbing onto the ass's back, the cat scrambling onto the dog's shoulders, and finally, the cock flying to perch on the cat's head.
Once assembled, at a given signal, they all began their 'music' simultaneously: the ass brayed, the dog barked, the cat meowed, and the cock crowed.
They then burst through the window into the room, creating a tremendous clatter among the shattered glass.
The robbers, already alarmed by the strange concert, were utterly terrified, believing a frightful goblin had invaded, and fled as quickly as they could.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The ass, being the tallest of the company, marched up to the window and peeped in.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The robbers, who had been not a little frightened by the opening concert, had now no doubt that some frightful hobgoblin had broken in upon them, and scampered away as fast as they could.

events.text_segment: The ass, being the tallest of the company, marched up to the window and peeped in. ‘Well, Donkey,’ said Chanticleer, ‘what do you see?’ ‘What do I see?’ replied the ass. ‘Why, I see a table spread with all kinds of good things, and robbers sitting round it making merry.’ ‘That would be a noble lodging for us,’ said the cock. ‘Yes,’ said the ass, ‘if we could only get in’; so they consulted together how they should contrive to get the robbers out; and at last they hit upon a plan. The ass placed himself upright on his hind legs, with his forefeet resting against the window; the dog got upon his back; the cat scrambled up to the dog’s shoulders, and the cock flew up and sat upon the cat’s head. When all was ready a signal was given, and they began their music. The ass brayed, the dog barked, the cat mewed, and the cock screamed; and then they all broke through the window at once, and came tumbling into the room, amongst the broken glass, with a most hideous clatter! The robbers, who had been not a little frightened by the opening concert, had now no doubt that some frightful hobgoblin had broken in upon them, and scampered away as fast as they could.

```plaintext
The ass, being the tallest of the company, marched up to the window and peeped in. Chanticleer, the cock, asked what the ass could see. The ass described a table laden with bread, cheese, and wine, and a group of robbers sitting around, eating and drinking. The cock said that it would be a fine place to stay if they could get in. The ass agreed, saying they should try to drive the robbers out. They then devised a plan: the ass would stand on his hind legs with his forefeet against the window, the dog would climb onto the ass's back, the cat would scramble onto the dog's shoulders, and the cock would fly up to perch on the cat's head. Once in position, at a signal, they all began their 'music'— the ass brayed, the dog barked, the cat meowed, and the cock crowed loudly. The noise was so great that they burst through the window, smashing the glass and creating a terrible racket. The robbers, frightened by the strange concert and believing a goblin had entered, were terrified and fled as fast as they could.
```

events.title: The Musicians Feast and Find Rest
detailed_summary: With the robbers gone and the house clear, the four animal travelers settled in.
They eagerly consumed the food and drink the robbers had left behind, eating with great gusto as if they hadn't eaten in a long time.
After they had their fill, they extinguished the lights.
Each animal then found a comfortable resting place according to its preference.
The donkey lay down on a pile of straw in the yard.
The dog stretched out on a mat behind the door.
The cat curled up on the hearth near the warm ashes.
The cock perched on a beam on the roof of the house.
Exhausted from their journey, they all fell asleep quickly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The coast once clear, our travellers soon sat down and dispatched what the robbers had left, with as much eagerness as if they had not expected to eat again for a month.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and, as they were all rather tired with their journey, they soon fell asleep.

events.text_segment: The coast once clear, our travellers soon sat down and dispatched what the robbers had left, with as much eagerness as if they had not expected to eat again for a month. As soon as they had satisfied themselves, they put out the lights, and each once more sought out a resting-place to his own liking. The donkey laid himself down upon a heap of straw in the yard, the dog stretched himself upon a mat behind the door, the cat rolled herself up on the hearth before the warm ashes, and the cock perched upon a beam on the top of the house; and, as they were all rather tired with their journey, they soon fell asleep.

events.title: The Robber's Terrifying Return and the Animals' Final Victory
detailed_summary: Around midnight, the robbers, observing from afar that the house was dark and quiet, began to suspect they had fled too hastily.
One of them, more courageous than the others, volunteered to return and investigate.
Finding everything still, the robber entered the kitchen and fumbled for a match to light a candle.
He spotted the cat's gleaming eyes, mistook them for live coals, and attempted to light his match from them.
The cat, not appreciating the gesture, lunged at his face, spitting and scratching him.
This terrified the robber, who then ran towards the back door.
As he reached the door, the dog jumped up and bit him on the leg.
While crossing the yard, the ass delivered a kick to him.
The cock, awakened by the commotion, crowed loudly from its perch.
The robber fled back to his comrades as fast as he could.

He recounted a horrifying tale to the captain: a dreadful witch had attacked him, scratching his face with her long, bony fingers; a man with a knife hidden behind the door had stabbed him in the leg; a black monster in the yard had struck him with a club; and the devil on the rooftop had shouted to 'Throw the rascal up here!'
Following this terrifying report, the robbers never dared to approach the house again.
The animal musicians, however, were so pleased with their new home that they decided to live there permanently, and the narrator presumes they might still be there.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But about midnight, when the robbers saw from afar that the lights were out and that all seemed quiet, they began to think that they had been in too great a hurry to run away; and one of them, who was bolder than the rest, went to see what was going on.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: After this the robbers never dared to go back to the house; but the musicians were so pleased with their quarters that they took up their abode there; and there they are, I dare say, at this very day.

events.text_segment: But about midnight, when the robbers saw from afar that the lights were out and that all seemed quiet, they began to think that they had been in too great a hurry to run away; and one of them, who was bolder than the rest, went to see what was going on. Finding everything still, he marched into the kitchen, and groped about till he found a match in order to light a candle; and then, espying the glittering fiery eyes of the cat, he mistook them for live coals, and held the match to them to light it. But the cat, not understanding this joke, sprang at his face, and spat, and scratched at him. This frightened him dreadfully, and away he ran to the back door; but there the dog jumped up and bit him in the leg; and as he was crossing over the yard the ass kicked him; and the cock, who had been awakened by the noise, crowed with all his might. At this the robber ran back as fast as he could to his comrades, and told the captain how a horrid witch had got into the house, and had spat at him and scratched his face with her long bony fingers; how a man with a knife in his hand had hidden himself behind the door, and stabbed him in the leg; how a black monster stood in the yard and struck him with a club, and how the devil had sat upon the top of the house and cried out, ‘Throw the rascal up here!’ After this the robbers never dared to go back to the house; but the musicians were so pleased with their quarters that they took up their abode there; and there they are, I dare say, at this very day.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: He crept softly through the shadows, his heart pounding with a mixture of fear and curiosity. As he approached the house, he noticed that the door was slightly ajar, and a faint light flickered inside. Steeling himself, he pushed the door open and stepped inside, only to find the room empty, save for a small, shining chest in the corner. The robbers had heard of a treasure hidden within, and now, in the dead of night, they hoped to claim it for themselves. But as he reached out to open the chest, a sudden voice echoed through the room, startling him so much that he nearly fell backward. It was the voice of an old woman, who appeared from the shadows, her eyes twinkling with mischief. "You have come for the treasure, but beware," she warned, "for it is guarded by a spell that only the pure of heart can break." The robber, trembling, listened as she told him of a test he must pass to prove his worth. He was to leave behind his greed and selfishness, and show kindness and courage instead. Moved by her words, he promised to change his ways. The old woman smiled and, with a wave of her hand, the spell was lifted. The treasure was revealed to be not gold or jewels, but the virtue of goodness itself. The robber left the house that night a changed man, vowing to live honestly and kindly from then on.

events.title: Sultan Overhears His Death Sentence and Seeks the Wolf's Aid
detailed_summary: The shepherd announced his plan to shoot their old dog, Sultan, the next day, considering him useless due to his age and lack of teeth.
The shepherd's wife implored him to spare Sultan, highlighting the dog's many years of loyal service and arguing he deserved to live out his days comfortably.
The shepherd dismissed his wife's plea, stating Sultan could no longer deter thieves and his past service was merely to earn his keep, confirming the decision to end Sultan's life.
Sultan, who was nearby, overheard this conversation and was terrified at the thought that the next day would be his last.
That evening, filled with sorrow and fear, Sultan went to his friend, the wolf, in the forest and explained his master's intention to kill him.

events.text_segment:
A shepherd had a faithful dog, called Sultan, who was grown very old, and had lost all his teeth. And one day when the shepherd and his wife were standing together before the house the shepherd said, ‘I will shoot old Sultan tomorrow morning, for he is of no use now.’ But his wife said, ‘Pray let the poor faithful creature live; he has served us well a great many years, and we ought to give him a livelihood for the rest of his days.’ ‘But what can we do with him?’ said the shepherd, ‘he has not a tooth in his head, and the thieves don’t care for him at all; to be sure he has served us, but then he did it to earn his livelihood; tomorrow shall be his last day, depend upon it.’
Poor Sultan, who was lying close by them, heard all that the shepherd and his wife said to one another, and was very much frightened to think tomorrow would be his last day; so in the evening he went to his good friend the wolf, who lived in the wood, and told him all his sorrows, and how his master meant to kill him in the morning.

events.title: The Wolf's Deceptive Rescue Plan and Its Successful Execution
detailed_summary: The wolf comforted Sultan and outlined a clever strategy to save him.
According to the plan, when the shepherd and his wife were in the field with their child, the wolf would emerge from the woods and pretend to abduct the child.
Sultan was instructed to lie near the child as if guarding it, then vigorously chase the wolf, who would then drop the child.
Sultan would then retrieve the child, appearing as its savior to his master and mistress.
The plan was executed perfectly; the wolf ran off with the child, the parents screamed, Sultan pursued and brought the child back.
Overjoyed and grateful, the shepherd declared that Sultan had saved their child and would be cared for, well-fed, and even given the shepherd's old cushion to sleep on for the rest of his life.
From that point on, Sultan enjoyed a life of comfort and abundance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ‘Make yourself easy,’ said the wolf, ‘I will give you some good advice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So from this time forward Sultan had all that he could wish for.

events.text_segment: ‘Make yourself easy,’ said the wolf, ‘I will give you some good advice. Your master, you know, goes out every morning very early with his wife into the field; and they take their little child with them, and lay it down behind the hedge in the shade while they are at work. Now do you lie down close by the child, and pretend to be watching it, and I will come out of the wood and run away with it; you must run after me as fast as you can, and I will let it drop; then you may carry it back, and they will think you have saved their child, and will be so thankful to you that they will take care of you as long as you live.’ The dog liked this plan very well; and accordingly so it was managed. The wolf ran with the child a little way; the shepherd and his wife screamed out; but Sultan soon overtook him, and carried the poor little thing back to his master and mistress. Then the shepherd patted him on the head, and said, ‘Old Sultan has saved our child from the wolf, and therefore he shall live and be well taken care of, and have plenty to eat. Wife, go home, and give him a good dinner, and let him have my old cushion to sleep on as long as he lives.’ So from this time forward Sultan had all that he could wish for.

Never trust a stranger, no matter how kind they seem, for they may have wicked plans. Always carry a little bread and a flask of water, so you can sustain yourself if you get lost. Remember, patience and caution are your best friends in times of trouble. If you see a house with a red roof, do not go inside, for it is the home of a wicked witch who loves to trap travelers. Instead, look for a clear stream and follow it downstream; it will lead you to safety. Keep your wits about you and listen to your instincts. If you feel danger nearby, hide quickly and stay silent. Do not be afraid to ask for help from kind-hearted people you meet along the way. And above all, trust in your own courage and goodness, for they will guide you through the darkest woods. With these words, the wolf vanished into the shadows, leaving the girl both frightened and wiser. She took a deep breath, remembered the wolf’s advice, and continued her journey with renewed hope and caution, determined to reach her home safely.

events.title: The Wolf's Demand and Sultan's Unwavering Loyalty
detailed_summary: Shortly after, the wolf visited Sultan to congratulate him on their success.
The wolf then suggested that as a form of repayment, Sultan should look the other way if the wolf decided to take one of the shepherd's sheep.
Sultan firmly refused, asserting his unwavering loyalty to his master.
The wolf, believing Sultan was not serious, later attempted to steal a sheep during the night.
However, Sultan had already warned his master about the wolf's intentions.
The shepherd lay in wait and, as the wolf was selecting a sheep, ambushed him with a heavy cudgel, giving him a severe beating.

But Sultan had told his master what the wolf meant to do; so he laid wait for him behind the barn door, and when the wolf was busy looking out for a good fat sheep, he had a stout cudgel laid about his back, that combed his locks for him finely.

events.title: The Wolf's Challenge and Sultan's Unlikely Ally
detailed_summary: Furious from the beating, the wolf insulted Sultan, calling him an old rogue, and swore he would get his revenge.
The following morning, the wolf dispatched the boar to challenge Sultan to a duel in the woods to settle their dispute.
Sultan, finding no other companion to act as his second in the fight, decided to take the shepherd's old, three-legged cat with him.
The cat, struggling somewhat due to her limp, walked with her tail held stiffly upright in the air.

events.title: Foes Misinterpret Cat's Appearance, Leading to Their Cowardly Retreat
detailed_summary: The wolf and the wild boar were the first to arrive at the agreed-upon location for the duel.
When they saw Sultan and the cat approaching, they misinterpreted the cat's erect tail, believing it to be a sword that Sultan intended to use.
Furthermore, each time the limping cat paused, they thought she was bending down to pick up a stone to hurl at them.
Feeling uneasy about this perceived method of combat, they decided against fighting.
Consequently, the boar concealed himself behind a bush, and the wolf hastily climbed up into a tree.
Sultan and the cat soon arrived at the spot, looking around and wondering why their adversaries were not present.

events.title: Cat Scares Boar, Exposing Wolf and Forcing Reconciliation
detailed_summary: The boar hadn't managed to hide completely, as his ears were visible protruding from the bush.
When the boar twitched one of his ears, the cat, mistaking the movement for that of a mouse, pounced on it, biting and scratching.
Startled and in pain, the boar leaped up, grunted, and fled, shouting out that the one responsible for the trouble was hiding in the tree, thereby revealing the wolf's location.
Sultan and the cat then looked up and saw the wolf perched among the tree branches.
They derided him as a cowardly scoundrel and refused to allow him to come down until he expressed genuine remorse and promised to reconcile and be friends with old Sultan again.

chapters.chapter_title: THE STRAW, THE COAL, AND THE BEAN

events.title: An Unlikely Encounter and Shared Escapes
detailed_summary: An impoverished elderly woman gathered beans for cooking.
She started a fire on her hearth using straw for kindling.
While transferring beans to a pan, one bean fell unnoticed to the ground, landing near a piece of straw.
A burning coal then leaped from the fire, joining the bean and straw.
The straw initiated a conversation, inquiring about the origins of the bean and coal.
The coal recounted its fortunate escape from the fire, which would have otherwise reduced it to ashes.
The bean shared its own narrow escape, explaining that it would have been boiled into broth with its companions if the old woman had put it in the pan.
The straw lamented the fate of its fellow straws, all destroyed by fire and smoke by the old woman, and expressed relief at its own accidental escape.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In a village dwelt a poor old woman, who had gathered together a dish of beans and wanted to cook them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I luckily slipped through her fingers.’

events.text_segment: In a village dwelt a poor old woman, who had gathered together a dish of beans and wanted to cook them. So she made a fire on her hearth, and that it might burn the quicker, she lighted it with a handful of straw. When she was emptying the beans into the pan, one dropped without her observing it, and lay on the ground beside a straw, and soon afterwards a burning coal from the fire leapt down to the two. Then the straw began and said: ‘Dear friends, from whence do you come here?’ The coal replied: ‘I fortunately sprang out of the fire, and if I had not escaped by sheer force, my death would have been certain,—I should have been burnt to ashes.’ The bean said: ‘I too have escaped with a whole skin, but if the old woman had got me into the pan, I should have been made into broth without any mercy, like my comrades.’ ‘And would a better fate have fallen to my lot?’ said the straw. ‘The old woman has destroyed all my brethren in fire and smoke; she seized sixty of them at once, and took their lives. I luckily slipped through her fingers.’

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: In a village dwelt a poor old woman, who had gathered together a dish of beans and wanted to cook them. She started a fire on her hearth using straw for kindling. As she transferred the beans into a pan, one bean fell unnoticed to the ground, landing near a piece of straw. Suddenly, a burning coal leaped from the fire, joining the bean and the straw. The straw, feeling curious, began to speak, asking the coal and the bean about their origins. The coal recounted how it had escaped the fire, which would have reduced it to ashes, and the bean explained that it had narrowly escaped being boiled into broth with its companions if the old woman had put it in the pan. The straw lamented the fate of its fellow straws, all destroyed by fire and smoke, and expressed relief at its own accidental escape.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: As she was about to put the beans into the pot, she suddenly remembered that she had no salt to season them. She looked around her humble cottage, but could not find any salt. Just then, a kind fairy appeared before her, noticing her plight. The fairy said, 'Do not worry, dear woman, for I will help you.' She waved her wand, and a small jar of salt appeared on the table. The old woman was overjoyed and thanked the fairy profusely. She added the salt to her beans and cooked them with great care. When she tasted the beans, they were delicious beyond her expectations. The fairy, pleased to see her happiness, told her that kindness and gratitude always bring blessings. From that day on, the old woman was never poor, for she shared her beans and her good fortune with her neighbors. And so, the village learned that a kind heart and a grateful spirit can turn even humble beginnings into happiness and prosperity.

events.title: A Pact for a Shared Journey
detailed_summary: The coal posed the question of their next course of action.
The bean proposed that, having all narrowly avoided death, they should remain together as companions.
Furthermore, the bean suggested they depart their current location to seek refuge in a foreign land, thereby avoiding potential new dangers.
This plan was met with approval from both the straw and the coal.
The three companions then embarked on their journey together.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ‘But what are we to do now?’ said the coal.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The proposition pleased the two others, and they set out on their way together.

events.text_segment:
‘But what are we to do now?’ said the coal.
‘I think,’ answered the bean, ‘that as we have so fortunately escaped death, we should keep together like good companions, and lest a new mischance should overtake us here, we should go away together, and repair to a foreign country.’
The proposition pleased the two others, and they set out on their way together.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: ‘But what are we to do now?’ said the coal. The straw looked worried, and the bean thought for a moment. Then the bean said, ‘Since we have all narrowly escaped death, perhaps it is best for us to stay together as friends.’ The coal nodded in agreement, and the straw added, ‘And maybe we should leave this place and seek safety in a distant land, where dangers are fewer.’ The three companions decided to follow this plan, and so they set out on their journey together, determined to find a safer home.

events.title: The Perilous Brook Crossing and Tragic Demise
detailed_summary: The companions soon reached a small brook, but found no bridge or plank to cross it.
They were uncertain about how to proceed.
The straw devised a plan, offering to lay itself across the water to serve as a makeshift bridge.
The straw then stretched itself from one bank of the brook to the other.
The coal, described as having an impetuous nature, boldly stepped onto the straw bridge.
However, upon reaching the middle of the brook and hearing the sound of the water flowing beneath, the coal became frightened and hesitated, unable to move further.
The straw, likely ignited by the coal or strained by its weight, began to burn, broke into two pieces, and fell into the stream.
The coal followed, slipping into the water, where it sizzled and was extinguished.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Soon, however, they came to a little brook, and as there was no bridge or foot-plank, they did not know how they were to get over it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The coal slipped after her, hissed when she got into the water, and breathed her last.

events.text_segment: Soon, however, they came to a little brook, and as there was no bridge or foot-plank, they did not know how they were to get over it. The straw hit on a good idea, and said: ‘I will lay myself straight across, and then you can walk over on me as on a bridge.’ The straw therefore stretched itself from one bank to the other, and the coal, who was of an impetuous disposition, tripped quite boldly on to the newly-built bridge. But when she had reached the middle, and heard the water rushing beneath her, she was after all, afraid, and stood still, and ventured no farther. The straw, however, began to burn, broke in two pieces, and fell into the stream. The coal slipped after her, hissed when she got into the water, and breathed her last.

But as he reached the middle of the brook and heard the water flowing beneath, he became frightened and hesitated, unable to go further. The straw, perhaps ignited by the coal or strained by its weight, suddenly caught fire, broke into two pieces, and fell into the stream. The coal, startled, slipped into the water, sizzled, and was quickly extinguished.

events.title: The Bean's Explosive Laughter and Fortuitous Mending
detailed_summary: The bean, having cautiously remained on the shore, witnessed the unfortunate end of its companions.
The bean found the incident overwhelmingly funny and began to laugh uncontrollably.
Its laughter was so intense and hearty that the bean eventually burst open.
The bean's fate would have been sealed then, had it not been for the timely arrival of a tailor, who was journeying in search of employment and had stopped to rest by the brook.
Possessing a kind heart, the tailor took out his needle and thread and sewed the burst bean back together.
The bean expressed its sincere gratitude to the tailor for his help.
The narrative concludes by explaining that because the tailor used black thread for the repair, all beans since that time have a characteristic black seam.

events.title: The Barren Royal Couple and the Fish's Prophecy of a Daughter
detailed_summary: A royal couple, despite their riches, were deeply saddened by their inability to conceive a child after many years of marriage.
One day, the queen, while near a river in her garden, showed compassion to a small fish that had beached itself and was close to dying by returning it to the water.

Before departing, the rescued fish informed the queen that it was aware of her desire for a child and, as a token of gratitude for her kindness, prophesied that she would soon give birth to a daughter.
This prophecy was fulfilled when the queen bore an exceptionally beautiful baby girl.
The king was filled with immense joy at the sight of his daughter and announced his intention to host a magnificent feast to introduce the princess to the entire realm.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What the little fish had foretold soon came to pass; and the queen had a little girl, so very beautiful that the king could not cease looking on it for joy, and said he would hold a great feast and make merry, and show the child to all the land.

events.text_segment: A king and queen once upon a time reigned in a country a great way off, where there were in those days fairies. Now this king and queen had plenty of money, and plenty of fine clothes to wear, and plenty of good things to eat and drink, and a coach to ride out in every day: but though they had been married many years they had no children, and this grieved them very much indeed. But one day as the queen was walking by the side of the river, at the bottom of the garden, she saw a poor little fish, that had thrown itself out of the water, and lay gasping and nearly dead on the bank. Then the queen took pity on the little fish, and threw it back again into the river; and before it swam away it lifted its head out of the water and said, ‘I know what your wish is, and it shall be fulfilled, in return for your kindness to me—you will soon have a daughter.’ What the little fish had foretold soon came to pass; and the queen had a little girl, so very beautiful that the king could not cease looking on it for joy, and said he would hold a great feast and make merry, and show the child to all the land.

The prophecy was fulfilled, and the queen soon bore a beautiful girl. The king was overjoyed and decided to hold a grand feast to celebrate the birth of his daughter and to introduce her to all his subjects.

events.title: The Christening Feast and the Fairies' Gifts
detailed_summary: The king extended invitations for the celebratory feast to his relatives, aristocracy, companions, and local inhabitants.
The queen particularly insisted on inviting the fairies, hoping they would bestow their blessings and goodwill upon their newborn daughter.
Although there were thirteen fairies residing in the kingdom, the king and queen possessed only twelve golden plates suitable for serving such esteemed guests.
As a result, one of the fairies was consequently omitted from the guest list and did not receive an invitation.
Twelve fairies attended the event, each distinguished by a tall red hat, red high-heeled footwear, and a long white magical staff.
Following the conclusion of the banquet, these fairies convened in a circle around the infant princess to grant her their most precious gifts.
These endowments included qualities like virtue, attractiveness, and wealth, collectively ensuring the princess would possess all desirable attributes in the world.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So he asked his kinsmen, and nobles, and friends, and neighbours.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: One gave her goodness, another beauty, another riches, and so on till she had all that was good in the world.

events.text_segment: So he asked his kinsmen, and nobles, and friends, and neighbours. But the queen said, ‘I will have the fairies also, that they might be kind and good to our little daughter.’ Now there were thirteen fairies in the kingdom; but as the king and queen had only twelve golden dishes for them to eat out of, they were forced to leave one of the fairies without asking her. So twelve fairies came, each with a high red cap on her head, and red shoes with high heels on her feet, and a long white wand in her hand: and after the feast was over they gathered round in a ring and gave all their best gifts to the little princess. One gave her goodness, another beauty, another riches, and so on till she had all that was good in the world.

events.title: The Thirteenth Fairy's Curse and the Twelfth Fairy's Intervention
detailed_summary: Just as the eleventh fairy concluded her blessing, a significant disturbance was reported from the courtyard, signaling the arrival of the thirteenth fairy, who had not been invited.
This fairy made her entrance into the dining hall, characterized by a black cap, black footwear, and carrying a broomstick.
Incensed by her exclusion from the feast, she severely reprimanded the king and queen and immediately plotted her retribution.
She then proclaimed a curse: the king's daughter, upon reaching her fifteenth year, would suffer an injury from a spindle and consequently die.
At this point, the twelfth of the benevolent fairies, who had yet to bestow her gift, came forward.
She explained that while the malevolent curse was destined to be fulfilled, she possessed the ability to mitigate its harshness.
Her gift, therefore, was to alter the curse so that when the princess was wounded by the spindle, she would not truly perish but instead fall into a profound slumber lasting one hundred years.

events.title: The King's Precaution and the Inevitable Fulfillment of Prophecy
detailed_summary: The king, in a desperate attempt to completely shield his beloved daughter from the prophesied misfortune, issued a decree that all spindles within the kingdom were to be acquired and subsequently destroyed by fire.

Meanwhile, the positive attributes gifted by the initial eleven fairies fully manifested in the princess; she developed into a person of such beauty, grace, goodness, and wisdom that she was adored by everyone acquainted with her.
On the very day she attained the age of fifteen, her parents, the king and queen, were absent from the palace, leaving her by herself.
The princess took the opportunity to wander through the palace, exploring its many rooms and chambers.
Her exploration led her eventually to an ancient tower, accessed by a constricted staircase that terminated at a small door.
A golden key was present in this door; upon turning it, the door swung open, revealing an elderly woman inside, diligently occupied with spinning.
The princess, addressing the woman politely, inquired about her activity, to which the old lady replied she was spinning, nodding and humming as her wheel spun.
Captivated by the motion of the spinning apparatus, the princess expressed her admiration and took the spindle, intending to try spinning herself.
However, almost immediately upon her touching it, the fairy's curse came to pass; the spindle pricked her, and she collapsed to the ground, appearing lifeless.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: However, the king hoped still to save his dear child altogether from the threatened evil; so he ordered that all the spindles in the kingdom should be bought up and burnt.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But scarcely had she touched it, before the fairy’s prophecy was fulfilled; the spindle wounded her, and she fell down lifeless on the ground.

events.text_segment:
However, the king hoped still to save his dear child altogether from the threatened evil; so he ordered that all the spindles in the kingdom should be bought up and burnt. But all the gifts of the first eleven fairies were in the meantime fulfilled; for the princess was so beautiful, and well behaved, and good, and wise, that everyone who knew her loved her.
It happened that, on the very day she was fifteen years old, the king and queen were not at home, and she was left alone in the palace. So she roved about by herself, and looked at all the rooms and chambers, till at last she came to an old tower, to which there was a narrow staircase ending with a little door. In the door there was a golden key, and when she turned it the door sprang open, and there sat an old lady spinning away very busily. ‘Why, how now, good mother,’ said the princess; ‘what are you doing there?’ ‘Spinning,’ said the old lady, and nodded her head, humming a tune, while buzz! went the wheel. ‘How prettily that little thing turns round!’ said the princess, and took the spindle and began to try and spin. But scarcely had she touched it, before the fairy’s prophecy was fulfilled; the spindle wounded her, and she fell down lifeless on the ground.

She wandered through the rooms and chambers, exploring everything, until she came to an old tower, which was reached by a narrow staircase ending in a tiny door.

On the door was a golden key, which the princess turned, and the door opened, revealing an old woman spinning at her wheel.

The princess asked her what she was doing, and the old lady replied she was spinning.

She watched the wheel go round and round, and was so taken with the motion that she took the spindle and tried to spin herself.

No sooner did she touch it than she pricked her finger, and fell down as if she were dead.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But despite the king's efforts, the curse was not so easily broken. The princess, in her curiosity, wandered into a hidden chamber where an old woman was spinning with a spindle. As soon as she touched the spindle, she pricked her finger and fell into a deep sleep, just as the curse had foretold. The king and queen, heartbroken, placed her in a beautiful chamber within the castle, where she slept for many years. The entire castle was then surrounded by a thick, enchanted forest, making it impossible for anyone to reach her. Many brave princes tried to break the spell, but none succeeded. One day, a young prince heard of the sleeping princess and, moved by her beauty and innocence, ventured into the forest. With great courage, he fought through the thorns and brambles, and finally reached the princess. As he gently kissed her, the curse was lifted, and she awoke. The castle and the forest transformed back to their former glory, and the prince and princess were married, living happily ever after, their love breaking the spell that had kept her asleep for so many years.

events.title: The Enchanted Slumber Descends Upon the Palace
detailed_summary: The princess had not died, but rather had succumbed to a very deep sleep.
The king and queen, who had just arrived back at the palace, along with their entire retinue, also fell into a slumber.
This magical sleep permeated the entire palace grounds: horses dozed in their stalls, dogs slept in the courtyard, pigeons rested on the rooftop, and even flies remained motionless on the walls.

The enchantment extended to inanimate objects as well: the fire in the hearth ceased its burning and appeared to sleep; the mechanism turning the roasting spit stopped, and the spit itself, holding a goose for the king's meal, became still.
The cook, in the midst of pulling a kitchen-boy's hair to reprimand him, was frozen in the act, and both she and the boy fell asleep.
The butler, who was surreptitiously tasting the ale, also fell asleep with the drinking vessel poised at his lips.
In this manner, every person and object within the palace came to a halt and entered a state of profound sleep.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and thus everything stood still, and slept soundly.

Even the fire on the hearth left off blazing, and went to sleep; the jack stopped, and the spit that was turning about with a goose upon it for the king’s dinner stood still; and the cook, who was at that moment pulling the kitchen-boy by the hair to give him a box on the ear for something he had done amiss, let him go, and both fell asleep; the butler, who was slyly tasting the ale, fell asleep with the jug at his lips: and thus everything stood still, and slept soundly.

events.title: The Thorn Hedge Encircles the Sleeping Palace
detailed_summary: A substantial barrier of thorns quickly materialized around the palace, growing taller and denser with each passing year.
Ultimately, the historic palace became entirely enveloped and obscured by this thorny growth, so much so that even its roof and chimneys were no longer visible.
Nevertheless, tales of the exquisitely beautiful sleeping princess, who came to be known as Briar Rose, circulated throughout the surrounding lands.
Consequently, over a period of time, several sons of kings were drawn by these accounts and made attempts to force their way through the dense thicket to reach the enchanted palace.
None of these aspirants, however, were ever successful in their endeavors; the thorns and bushes seemed to actively seize them, as if with hands.
These unfortunate princes found themselves trapped fast within the thorny barrier and ultimately met with a miserable demise.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A large hedge of thorns soon grew round the palace, and every year it became higher and thicker; till at last the old palace was surrounded and hidden, so that not even the roof or the chimneys could be seen.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This, however, none of them could ever do; for the thorns and bushes laid hold of them, as it were with hands; and there they stuck fast, and died wretchedly.

events.text_segment: A large hedge of thorns soon grew round the palace, and every year it became higher and thicker; till at last the old palace was surrounded and hidden, so that not even the roof or the chimneys could be seen. But there went a report through all the land of the beautiful sleeping Briar Rose (for so the king’s daughter was called): so that, from time to time, several kings’ sons came, and tried to break through the thicket into the palace. This, however, none of them could ever do; for the thorns and bushes laid hold of them, as it were with hands; and there they stuck fast, and died wretchedly.

events.title: A Prince Hears the Legend of Briar Rose and Resolves to Find Her
detailed_summary: After a great many years had passed, a king's son journeyed into that particular region.

An elderly man there recounted to him the legend of the impenetrable thorn thicket, detailing how a magnificent palace lay concealed behind it, and within, a marvelous princess named Briar Rose remained in an enchanted sleep along with her entire court.

The old man further conveyed that he had learned from his own grandfather about numerous princes who had previously come and attempted to breach the thicket, but all had become ensnared and perished in their efforts.
Despite these grim accounts, the young prince declared that such stories would not deter him; he was resolved to proceed and see the famed Briar Rose for himself.
The old man made efforts to dissuade the prince from his perilous undertaking, but the prince's determination to go was unshakeable.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The old man tried to hinder him, but he was bent upon going.

He told, too, how he had heard from his grandfather that many, many princes had come, and had tried to break through the thicket, but that they had all stuck fast in it, and died. Then the young prince said, ‘All this shall not frighten me; I will go and see this Briar Rose.’ The old man tried to hinder him, but he was bent upon going.

events.title: The Prince Arrives as the Century Ends and Enters the Sleeping Palace
detailed_summary: On the very day the prince arrived at the thorny barrier, the century-long enchantment was fated to end.
As he approached, he found not a forbidding wall of thorns but rather an array of beautiful, blooming shrubs, through which he passed without difficulty.
Once he was through, these shrubs closed up behind him, becoming as dense as they had ever been.

He finally arrived at the palace, where he observed the sleeping inhabitants: dogs were asleep in the courtyard, horses stood dormant in the stables, and pigeons rested on the roof, their heads tucked beneath their wings in slumber.
Upon entering the palace itself, he noted flies asleep on the walls.

The roasting spit was motionless; the butler remained frozen with a jug of ale at his lips, about to drink; a maid sat with a chicken in her lap, poised to pluck it; and the cook in the kitchen was still captured with her hand raised, as though she were about to discipline the boy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now that very day the hundred years were ended; and as the prince came to the thicket he saw nothing but beautiful flowering shrubs, through which he went with ease, and they shut in after him as thick as ever.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and the cook in the kitchen was still holding up her hand, as if she was going to beat the boy.

events.text_segment: Now that very day the hundred years were ended; and as the prince came to the thicket he saw nothing but beautiful flowering shrubs, through which he went with ease, and they shut in after him as thick as ever. Then he came at last to the palace, and there in the court lay the dogs asleep; and the horses were standing in the stables; and on the roof sat the pigeons fast asleep, with their heads under their wings. And when he came into the palace, the flies were sleeping on the walls; the spit was standing still; the butler had the jug of ale at his lips, going to drink a draught; the maid sat with a fowl in her lap ready to be plucked; and the cook in the kitchen was still holding up her hand, as if she was going to beat the boy.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Suddenly, he found himself in a splendid garden, filled with the most wonderful flowers and singing birds. In the midst of the garden stood a magnificent castle, shining like gold in the sunlight. events.title: The Awakening Kiss and the Revival of the Palace
detailed_summary: The prince ventured further into the palace, where the silence was so profound he could hear his own respirations.
At last, he reached the old tower and unlatched the door of the small chamber where Briar Rose was located.
There she lay, deeply asleep on a couch near the window, her beauty so captivating he could not avert his gaze.
Overcome by her appearance, he bent down and bestowed a kiss upon her.
The very moment his lips touched hers, Briar Rose's eyes fluttered open, she awoke, and offered him a smile.
Together, they exited the room.
Concurrently, the king and queen also awoke, as did the entire court, all of them looking at one another with immense surprise.
The horses began to move and shake their bodies, the dogs leaped up and barked, and the pigeons lifted their heads from under their wings, surveyed their surroundings, and flew out into the fields.
The flies on the walls resumed their buzzing.
The kitchen fire flared back to life; the roasting jack and the spit began to turn once more, the goose for the king's dinner rotating upon it.
The butler completed his interrupted draught of ale, the maid recommenced plucking the fowl, and the cook finally administered the intended disciplinary rap on the ear to the kitchen boy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then he went on still farther, and all was so still that he could hear every breath he drew; till at last he came to the old tower, and opened the door of the little room in which Briar Rose was; and there she lay, fast asleep on a couch by the window.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: and the cook gave the boy the box on his ear.

events.text_segment: Then he went on still farther, and all was so still that he could hear every breath he drew; till at last he came to the old tower, and opened the door of the little room in which Briar Rose was; and there she lay, fast asleep on a couch by the window. She looked so beautiful that he could not take his eyes off her, so he stooped down and gave her a kiss. But the moment he kissed her she opened her eyes and awoke, and smiled upon him; and they went out together; and soon the king and queen also awoke, and all the court, and gazed on each other with great wonder. And the horses shook themselves, and the dogs jumped up and barked; the pigeons took their heads from under their wings, and looked about and flew into the fields; the flies on the walls buzzed again; the fire in the kitchen blazed up; round went the jack, and round went the spit, with the goose for the king’s dinner upon it; the butler finished his draught of ale; the maid went on plucking the fowl; and the cook gave the boy the box on his ear.

events.title: The Hungry Dog's Plight and the Sparrow's Compassionate Offer
detailed_summary: A dog was neglected by his master and suffered from extreme hunger.
Unable to endure his suffering any longer, the dog fled, feeling deeply sad and sorrowful.
On his journey, he encountered a sparrow who inquired about the cause of his distress.
The dog explained that he was incredibly hungry and had no food.
The sparrow, unconcerned by the scale of the problem, invited the dog to accompany it to a nearby town, promising to secure him ample food.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A shepherd’s dog had a master who took no care of him, but often let him suffer the greatest hunger.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘If that be all,’ answered the sparrow, ‘come with me into the next town, and I will soon find you plenty of food.’

events.text_segment: A shepherd’s dog had a master who took no care of him, but often let him suffer the greatest hunger. At last he could bear it no longer; so he took to his heels, and off he ran in a very sad and sorrowful mood. On the road he met a sparrow that said to him, ‘Why are you so sad, my friend?’ ‘Because,’ said the dog, ‘I am very very hungry, and have nothing to eat.’ ‘If that be all,’ answered the sparrow, ‘come with me into the next town, and I will soon find you plenty of food.’

events.title: A Feast for the Famished: Sparrow's Ingenuity at the Butcher's and Baker's
detailed_summary: The dog and sparrow journeyed together into the town, and upon passing a butcher's shop, the sparrow advised the dog to wait while it procured some meat.
The sparrow landed on the butcher's shelf and, after carefully checking for observers, dislodged a steak by pecking and scratching at it until it fell.
The dog seized the fallen steak, retreated to a corner, and consumed it entirely.
The sparrow offered to get more, led the dog to another shop, and similarly obtained a second steak for him.
After the dog finished the second piece of meat, the sparrow asked if he had eaten enough.
The dog confirmed he had plenty of meat but now desired some bread.
The sparrow agreed and guided him to a baker’s establishment.
There, the sparrow skillfully pecked at two rolls in the window until they dropped down for the dog.
As the dog still wished for more, the sparrow took him to another bakery and obtained more bread in the same manner.
Once the dog had eaten this additional bread, the sparrow inquired if his hunger was now satisfied.
The dog affirmed that it was and proposed they take a short walk outside the town.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So on they went together into the town: and as they passed by a butcher’s shop, the sparrow said to the dog, ‘Stand there a little while till I peck you down a piece of meat.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Yes,’ said he; ‘and now let us take a walk a little way out of the town.’

events.text_segment: So on they went together into the town: and as they passed by a butcher’s shop, the sparrow said to the dog, ‘Stand there a little while till I peck you down a piece of meat.’ So the sparrow perched upon the shelf: and having first looked carefully about her to see if anyone was watching her, she pecked and scratched at a steak that lay upon the edge of the shelf, till at last down it fell. Then the dog snapped it up, and scrambled away with it into a corner, where he soon ate it all up. ‘Well,’ said the sparrow, ‘you shall have some more if you will; so come with me to the next shop, and I will peck you down another steak.’ When the dog had eaten this too, the sparrow said to him, ‘Well, my good friend, have you had enough now?’ ‘I have had plenty of meat,’ answered he, ‘but I should like to have a piece of bread to eat after it.’ ‘Come with me then,’ said the sparrow, ‘and you shall soon have that too.’ So she took him to a baker’s shop, and pecked at two rolls that lay in the window, till they fell down: and as the dog still wished for more, she took him to another shop and pecked down some more for him. When that was eaten, the sparrow asked him whether he had had enough now. ‘Yes,’ said he; ‘and now let us take a walk a little way out of the town.’

events.title: Tragedy on the High Road: The Dog's Death and the Sparrow's Vow
detailed_summary: The two companions set off along the main road, but the warm weather soon made the dog weary, and he expressed a wish to nap.
The sparrow consented, stating it would rest on a nearby bush while the dog slept.
The dog then stretched out on the road and quickly fell into a deep sleep.
While the dog slept, a carter approached with a cart pulled by three horses and carrying two wine casks.
The sparrow observed that the carter was not altering his course and was on a direct path to drive over the sleeping dog.
The sparrow called out, warning the carter to halt or face severe repercussions.
The carter, muttering dismissively about the sparrow's perceived inability to harm him, cracked his whip and proceeded.
He drove his cart directly over the poor dog, the wheels crushing the animal to death.
The sparrow then cried out, accusing the carter, whom it called a cruel villain, of killing its friend.
The sparrow declared that this act of cruelty would cost the carter all his possessions.
The carter, defiant, challenged the sparrow to inflict its worst and continued on his journey.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So they both went out upon the high road; but as the weather was warm, they had not gone far before the dog said, ‘I am very much tired—I should like to take a nap.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Do your worst, and welcome,’ said the brute, ‘what harm can you do me?’ and passed on.

events.text_segment: So they both went out upon the high road; but as the weather was warm, they had not gone far before the dog said, ‘I am very much tired—I should like to take a nap.’ ‘Very well,’ answered the sparrow, ‘do so, and in the meantime I will perch upon that bush.’ So the dog stretched himself out on the road, and fell fast asleep. Whilst he slept, there came by a carter with a cart drawn by three horses, and loaded with two casks of wine. The sparrow, seeing that the carter did not turn out of the way, but would go on in the track in which the dog lay, so as to drive over him, called out, ‘Stop! stop! Mr Carter, or it shall be the worse for you.’ But the carter, grumbling to himself, ‘You make it the worse for me, indeed! what can you do?’ cracked his whip, and drove his cart over the poor dog, so that the wheels crushed him to death. ‘There,’ cried the sparrow, ‘thou cruel villain, thou hast killed my friend the dog. Now mind what I say. This deed of thine shall cost thee all thou art worth.’ ‘Do your worst, and welcome,’ said the brute, ‘what harm can you do me?’ and passed on.

events.title: Retribution Begins: The Sparrow Dismantles the Carter's Cart and Horses
detailed_summary: The sparrow concealed itself beneath the cart's covering and pecked at the bung of one of the wine casks until it became loose.
Consequently, all the wine drained out from the cask without the carter immediately noticing.
Eventually, the carter looked back and saw his cart dripping and one cask entirely empty, leading him to exclaim his misfortune.
The sparrow then appeared, alighting on one of the horse's heads, and retorted that the carter was not yet wretched enough, proceeding to peck the horse until it reared and kicked.
Witnessing this, the carter retrieved his hatchet and aimed a blow at the sparrow, intending to kill it.
The sparrow, however, flew away, and the carter's strike fatally hit the horse on its head.
The carter lamented his ill luck once more, to which the sparrow responded that he was still not sufficiently wretched.
As the carter moved on with his remaining two horses, the sparrow again slipped under the cart's canvas.
It pecked out the bung of the second wine cask, causing all its contents to spill out.
When the carter discovered this new loss, he again cried out about his miserable state.
The sparrow countered that he was not wretched enough yet, then landed on the second horse's head and started pecking it.
The carter ran towards the sparrow and swung his hatchet again; the bird dodged, and the blow fell upon the second horse, killing it instantly.
The carter bemoaned his unlucky fate, and the sparrow repeated its taunting refrain.
The sparrow then perched upon the third horse and commenced pecking it as well.
The carter, now mad with fury and acting recklessly, struck at the sparrow again but ended up killing his third horse, just as he had the other two.
The carter cried out in his misery, and the sparrow, flying off, declared that he was not yet wretched enough and that it would now bring plague and punishment to his own house.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But the sparrow crept under the tilt of the cart, and pecked at the bung of one of the casks till she loosened it; and then all the wine ran out, without the carter seeing it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘now will I plague and punish thee at thy own house.’

events.text_segment: But the sparrow crept under the tilt of the cart, and pecked at the bung of one of the casks till she loosened it; and then all the wine ran out, without the carter seeing it. At last he looked round, and saw that the cart was dripping, and the cask quite empty. ‘What an unlucky wretch I am!’ cried he. ‘Not wretch enough yet!’ said the sparrow, as she alighted upon the head of one of the horses, and pecked at him till he reared up and kicked. When the carter saw this, he drew out his hatchet and aimed a blow at the sparrow, meaning to kill her; but she flew away, and the blow fell upon the poor horse’s head with such force, that he fell down dead. ‘Unlucky wretch that I am!’ cried he. ‘Not wretch enough yet!’ said the sparrow. And as the carter went on with the other two horses, she again crept under the tilt of the cart, and pecked out the bung of the second cask, so that all the wine ran out. When the carter saw this, he again cried out, ‘Miserable wretch that I am!’ But the sparrow answered, ‘Not wretch enough yet!’ and perched on the head of the second horse, and pecked at him too. The carter ran up and struck at her again with his hatchet; but away she flew, and the blow fell upon the second horse and killed him on the spot. ‘Unlucky wretch that I am!’ said he. ‘Not wretch enough yet!’ said the sparrow; and perching upon the third horse, she began to peck him too. The carter was mad with fury; and without looking about him, or caring what he was about, struck again at the sparrow; but killed his third horse as he done the other two. ‘Alas! miserable wretch that I am!’ cried he. ‘Not wretch enough yet!’ answered the sparrow as she flew away; ‘now will I plague and punish thee at thy own house.’

events.title: Retribution at Home: The Sparrow and a Swarm Devour the Carter's Corn
detailed_summary: Compelled to abandon his cart, the carter returned home, overwhelmed with rage and vexation.
He recounted his misfortunes to his wife, detailing the spilled wine and the death of all three horses.
His wife, in turn, informed him that a malevolent bird had entered their house, bringing with it what seemed like every bird in existence.
She reported that this avian horde was in their loft, rapidly devouring their stored corn.
The husband rushed upstairs and witnessed thousands of birds on the floor consuming his grain, with the familiar sparrow in their midst.
Seeing that almost all his corn was gone, the carter cried out in despair about his wretched state.
The sparrow retorted that he was still not wretched enough and forewarned that his cruelty would ultimately cost him his life, before flying away.

events.title: The Sparrow's Final Taunt and the Carter's Fatal Rage
detailed_summary: The carter, having witnessed the loss of all his possessions, descended to his kitchen, still showing no remorse for his actions, and sat angrily in the chimney corner.
The sparrow positioned itself outside the window and cried out that the carter's cruelty would cost him his life.
In a fit of rage, the carter sprang up, seized his hatchet, and hurled it at the sparrow.
The hatchet missed the bird but shattered the windowpane.
The sparrow then hopped inside, perched upon the window-seat, and repeated its dire warning about the cost of the carter's life.
Driven mad and blind with fury, the carter struck the window-seat with such force that he split it in two.

As the sparrow darted from place to place within the room, the carter and his wife, in their furious attempts to strike it, ended up breaking all their furniture, glassware, and even damaging the walls, without managing to touch the bird.
Ultimately, however, they succeeded in capturing the sparrow.
The wife inquired if she should kill it immediately.
The carter, desiring a more agonizing end for the bird, declared that merely killing it was too lenient and that he would eat it instead.
The sparrow began to flutter and stretch its neck, crying out one final time that the carter's cruelty would yet cost him his life.
Unable to delay any longer, the carter handed his wife the hatchet and commanded her to strike the bird and kill it while he held it in his hand.
The wife swung the hatchet, but her aim was errant; she missed the sparrow and instead struck her husband on the head.
The carter fell down dead, and the sparrow flew serenely back to its nest.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And the wife struck; but she missed her aim, and hit her husband on the head so that he fell down dead, and the sparrow flew quietly home to her nest.

events.text_segment: The carter seeing that he had thus lost all that he had, went down into his kitchen; and was still not sorry for what he had done, but sat himself angrily and sulkily in the chimney corner. But the sparrow sat on the outside of the window, and cried ‘Carter! thy cruelty shall cost thee thy life!’ With that he jumped up in a rage, seized his hatchet, and threw it at the sparrow; but it missed her, and only broke the window. The sparrow now hopped in, perched upon the window-seat, and cried, ‘Carter! it shall cost thee thy life!’ Then he became mad and blind with rage, and struck the window-seat with such force that he cleft it in two: and as the sparrow flew from place to place, the carter and his wife were so furious, that they broke all their furniture, glasses, chairs, benches, the table, and at last the walls, without touching the bird at all. In the end, however, they caught her: and the wife said, ‘Shall I kill her at once?’ ‘No,’ cried he, ‘that is letting her off too easily: she shall die a much more cruel death; I will eat her.’ But the sparrow began to flutter about, and stretch out her neck and cried, ‘Carter! it shall cost thee thy life yet!’ With that he could wait no longer: so he gave his wife the hatchet, and cried, ‘Wife, strike at the bird and kill her in my hand.’ And the wife struck; but she missed her aim, and hit her husband on the head so that he fell down dead, and the sparrow flew quietly home to her nest.

events.title: The King's Perplexing Problem and a Deadly Challenge
detailed_summary: A king was troubled because his twelve daughters, despite being locked in their room each night, awoke every morning with their shoes completely worn out, as if they had danced extensively.
The origin of their nightly excursions and the cause of the worn shoes remained an unsolved puzzle.
To uncover this secret, the king issued a proclamation across his realm.
He promised that any man who could reveal where the princesses danced would win the hand of his chosen daughter in marriage and be designated as the successor to the throne.
However, the proclamation carried a dire warning: any contender who failed to solve the mystery within three days and nights would face execution.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: but whoever tried and did not succeed, after three days and nights, should be put to death.

events.text_segment:
There was a king who had twelve beautiful daughters. They slept in twelve beds all in one room; and when they went to bed, the doors were shut and locked up; but every morning their shoes were found to be quite worn through as if they had been danced in all night; and yet nobody could find out how it happened, or where they had been.
Then the king made it known to all the land, that if any person could discover the secret, and find out where it was that the princesses danced in the night, he should have the one he liked best for his wife, and should be king after his death; but whoever tried and did not succeed, after three days and nights, should be put to death.

events.title: Failed Suitors and a Soldier's Chance Encounter with Magical Aid
detailed_summary: A prince was the first to accept the king's challenge, receiving good hospitality and being placed in a room adjacent to the princesses' chamber to observe them, with his door left open.
Despite these arrangements, the prince succumbed to sleep and, upon waking, found the princesses' shoes worn out, indicating they had danced.
This pattern repeated for two more nights, leading to the prince's execution by the king's order.
Several other hopefuls followed, but all met the same unfortunate end, losing their lives after failing to uncover the secret.
Subsequently, an old soldier, unable to fight due to battle wounds, journeyed through the king's land.
While traveling in a forest, he met an elderly woman who inquired about his destination.
The soldier confessed his uncertainty but expressed an interest in discovering the princesses' dancing secret, hoping it might lead him to become king.
The old woman assured him the task was not overly difficult, offering crucial advice: he must avoid drinking any wine offered by a princess in the evening and then feign deep sleep.
She also provided him with a special cloak, explaining that wearing it would render him invisible, allowing him to follow the princesses undetected.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A king’s son soon came.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then she gave him a cloak, and said, ‘As soon as you put that on you will become invisible, and you will then be able to follow the princesses wherever they go.’

events.text_segment:
A king’s son soon came. He was well entertained, and in the evening was taken to the chamber next to the one where the princesses lay in their twelve beds. There he was to sit and watch where they went to dance; and, in order that nothing might pass without his hearing it, the door of his chamber was left open. But the king’s son soon fell asleep; and when he awoke in the morning he found that the princesses had all been dancing, for the soles of their shoes were full of holes. The same thing happened the second and third night: so the king ordered his head to be cut off. After him came several others; but they had all the same luck, and all lost their lives in the same manner.
Now it chanced that an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer, passed through the country where this king reigned: and as he was travelling through a wood, he met an old woman, who asked him where he was going. ‘I hardly know where I am going, or what I had better do,’ said the soldier; ‘but I think I should like very well to find out where it is that the princesses dance, and then in time I might be a king.’ ‘Well,’ said the old dame, ‘that is no very hard task: only take care not to drink any of the wine which one of the princesses will bring to you in the evening; and as soon as she leaves you pretend to be fast asleep.’
Then she gave him a cloak, and said, ‘As soon as you put that on you will become invisible, and you will then be able to follow the princesses wherever they go.’

events.title: The Soldier's Strategic Deception and the Princesses' Preparations
detailed_summary: Upon hearing the old woman's counsel, the soldier resolved to test his fortune and presented himself to the king, declaring his readiness to undertake the challenge.
He received the same courteous treatment as previous suitors, and the king provided him with fine royal attire.
As evening arrived, he was escorted to the antechamber.
Just before he intended to lie down, the eldest princess approached him with a cup of wine.
The soldier, remembering the old woman's warning, discreetly disposed of the wine without consuming any.
He then settled on his bed and soon began to snore loudly, convincingly simulating deep sleep.
The twelve princesses, hearing his snores, were amused, and the eldest remarked that he, like others before him, could have chosen a wiser path than risking his life.
They then got up, opened their storage, retrieved their elegant clothing, adorned themselves before mirrors, and moved about excitedly, eager for their nightly activity.
However, the youngest princess voiced a sense of unease amidst her sisters' happiness, fearing some misfortune.

The eldest dismissed her concerns, calling her a simpleton and reminding her of the many princes who had failed to discover their secret, adding that the soldier would have slept soundly even without the drugged wine she presumed he drank.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the soldier heard all this good counsel, he determined to try his luck: so he went to the king, and said he was willing to undertake the task.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And as for this soldier, even if I had not given him his sleeping draught, he would have slept soundly enough.’

events.text_segment:
When the soldier heard all this good counsel, he determined to try his luck: so he went to the king, and said he was willing to undertake the task.
He was as well received as the others had been, and the king ordered fine royal robes to be given him; and when the evening came he was led to the outer chamber. Just as he was going to lie down, the eldest of the princesses brought him a cup of wine; but the soldier threw it all away secretly, taking care not to drink a drop. Then he laid himself down on his bed, and in a little while began to snore very loud as if he was fast asleep. When the twelve princesses heard this they laughed heartily; and the eldest said, ‘This fellow too might have done a wiser thing than lose his life in this way!’ Then they rose up and opened their drawers and boxes, and took out all their fine clothes, and dressed themselves at the glass, and skipped about as if they were eager to begin dancing. But the youngest said, ‘I don’t know how it is, while you are so happy I feel very uneasy; I am sure some mischance will befall us.’ ‘You simpleton,’ said the eldest, ‘you are always afraid; have you forgotten how many kings’ sons have already watched in vain? And as for this soldier, even if I had not given him his sleeping draught, he would have slept soundly enough.’

events.title: Unveiling the Hidden Passage and the Silver Grove
detailed_summary: Once fully prepared, the princesses observed the soldier, who continued to snore without moving, convincing them of their safety.
The eldest princess then went to her bed, clapped her hands, causing the bed to lower into the floor and reveal a trapdoor.
The soldier witnessed them descend through the opening one by one, with the eldest leading.
Realizing he needed to act quickly, he got up, donned the invisibility cloak given by the old woman, and followed.
While on the stairs, he inadvertently stepped on the gown of the youngest princess.
She exclaimed to her sisters that something was amiss, feeling someone tug her gown.
The eldest princess dismissed her alarm, casually suggesting it was merely a nail in the wall.
They all continued downwards and emerged at the bottom into a beautiful grove where all the tree leaves were made of silver, shimmering splendidly.
The soldier, wanting a memento, broke off a small silver branch, which caused a loud sound to emanate from the tree.
The youngest princess again expressed her conviction that something was wrong, questioning if her sisters heard the noise, which she noted had never occurred before.
The eldest, however, reassured them by claiming it was only their awaiting princes shouting in joyful anticipation of their arrival.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But the eldest said, ‘It is only our princes, who are shouting for joy at our approach.’

The soldier saw them going down through the trap-door one after another, the eldest leading the way; and thinking he had no time to lose, he jumped up, put on the cloak which the old woman had given him, and followed them; but in the middle of the stairs he trod on the gown of the youngest princess, and she cried out to her sisters, ‘All is not right; someone took hold of my gown.’ ‘You silly creature!’ said the eldest, ‘it is nothing but a nail in the wall.’ Then down they all went, and at the bottom they found themselves in a most delightful grove of trees; and the leaves were all of silver, and glittered and sparkled beautifully. The soldier wished to take away some token of the place; so he broke off a little branch, and there came a loud noise from the tree. Then the youngest daughter said again, ‘I am sure all is not right—did not you hear that noise? That never happened before.’ But the eldest said, ‘It is only our princes, who are shouting for joy at our approach.’

The children and the soldier returned home, safe and sound, and they never forgot the brave soldier who had saved them from the witch’s evil clutches.

events.title: Traversing More Magical Groves and Reaching the Lakeside Rendezvous
detailed_summary: The group proceeded to a second grove where the leaves were entirely of gold.
Following that, they entered a third grove, its leaves made of sparkling diamonds.
From each of these groves, the soldier broke off a branch as a token.
Each time he did so, a loud noise occurred, causing the youngest sister to tremble with fear.
The eldest sister consistently attributed these sounds to the princes exclaiming with joy.
Their journey continued until they arrived at a large lake.
By the lake's edge, twelve small boats were waiting, each occupied by a handsome prince, apparently expecting the princesses.
One princess boarded each boat, and the invisible soldier chose to enter the boat carrying the youngest princess.
While they were being rowed across the lake, the prince in the boat with the youngest princess and the soldier commented on the unusual difficulty in rowing.
He noted that despite his efforts, their progress was slower than normal and he felt quite tired, remarking that the boat seemed exceptionally heavy that day.
The youngest princess attributed his struggle to the warmth of the weather, saying she also felt very warm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then they came to another grove of trees, where all the leaves were of gold; and afterwards to a third, where the leaves were all glittering diamonds.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘It is only the heat of the weather,’ said the princess: ‘I feel it very warm too.’

events.text_segment:
Then they came to another grove of trees, where all the leaves were of gold; and afterwards to a third, where the leaves were all glittering diamonds. And the soldier broke a branch from each; and every time there was a loud noise, which made the youngest sister tremble with fear; but the eldest still said, it was only the princes, who were crying for joy. So they went on till they came to a great lake; and at the side of the lake there lay twelve little boats with twelve handsome princes in them, who seemed to be waiting there for the princesses.
One of the princesses went into each boat, and the soldier stepped into the same boat with the youngest. As they were rowing over the lake, the prince who was in the boat with the youngest princess and the soldier said, ‘I do not know why it is, but though I am rowing with all my might we do not get on so fast as usual, and I am quite tired: the boat seems very heavy today.’ ‘It is only the heat of the weather,’ said the princess: ‘I feel it very warm too.’

events.title: The Secret Ball, Unexplained Incidents, and the Journey Back
detailed_summary: Across the lake, they saw a splendid, brightly lit castle from which joyous music of horns and trumpets emanated.
Everyone disembarked and entered the castle, where each prince began dancing with his designated princess.
The soldier, still invisible, joined in the dancing as well.
Whenever a princess had a cup of wine placed beside her, the soldier would drink it entirely, so that the cup was empty when she lifted it to her lips.
This phenomenon particularly terrified the youngest sister, but the eldest continually quieted her.
The dancing continued until three o'clock in the morning, by which time all their shoes were completely worn through, forcing them to stop.
The princes then rowed them back across the lake; for this return trip, the soldier positioned himself in the boat with the eldest princess.
Upon reaching the opposite shore, the princesses and princes bid each other farewell, with the princesses promising to return for another night of dancing.

events.text_segment: On the other side of the lake stood a fine illuminated castle, from which came the merry music of horns and trumpets. There they all landed, and went into the castle, and each prince danced with his princess; and the soldier, who was all the time invisible, danced with them too; and when any of the princesses had a cup of wine set by her, he drank it all up, so that when she put the cup to her mouth it was empty. At this, too, the youngest sister was terribly frightened, but the eldest always silenced her. They danced on till three o’clock in the morning, and then all their shoes were worn out, so that they were obliged to leave off. The princes rowed them back again over the lake (but this time the soldier placed himself in the boat with the eldest princess); and on the opposite shore they took leave of each other, the princesses promising to come again the next night.
