events.title: Continued Surveillance and Gathering of Proof
detailed_summary: Upon reaching the stairs leading back to their chambers, the soldier quickly moved ahead of the princesses and settled into his bed.
As the twelve weary sisters slowly ascended, they heard him snoring, leading them to believe their secret was still safe.
They then undressed, stored their fine clothes, removed their worn-out shoes, and retired to their beds.
The following morning, the soldier remained silent about his discoveries, having decided to observe more of this peculiar adventure.
He repeated his invisible surveillance on the second and third nights.
Events unfolded in the same manner each night: the princesses danced until their shoes were ruined and then returned home.
Crucially, on the third night, the soldier secured an additional piece of evidence by taking one of the golden cups from the underground castle.

events.title: The Truth Unveiled, the Princesses' Confession, and the Soldier's Reward
detailed_summary: When the appointed time arrived for the soldier to disclose the secret, he was brought before the king, carrying the three branches and the golden cup as proof.
The twelve princesses positioned themselves behind the door to overhear his testimony.
The king formally asked him where his twelve daughters danced each night.
The soldier revealed that they danced with twelve princes in a castle located underground.
He then provided a full account of what he had witnessed and presented the three branches and the golden cup he had brought back as tangible evidence.
The king subsequently summoned the princesses and questioned them about the truth of the soldier's account.
Seeing that their secret was exposed and that denial was futile, they confessed to everything.
The king then asked the soldier to choose which of the princesses he wished to marry.
The soldier, explaining that he was no longer very young, selected the eldest princess.
They were married on that very day, and the soldier was officially declared the king's heir.

events.text_segment: As soon as the time came when he was to declare the secret, he was taken before the king with the three branches and the golden cup; and the twelve princesses stood listening behind the door to hear what he would say. And when the king asked him. ‘Where do my twelve daughters dance at night?’ he answered, ‘With twelve princes in a castle under ground.’ And then he told the king all that had happened, and showed him the three branches and the golden cup which he had brought with him. Then the king called for the princesses, and asked them whether what the soldier said was true: and when they saw that they were discovered, and that it was of no use to deny what had happened, they confessed it all. And the king asked the soldier which of them he would choose for his wife; and he answered, ‘I am not very young, so I will have the eldest.’—And they were married that very day, and the soldier was chosen to be the king’s heir.

events.title: The Fisherman's Encounter with the Enchanted Fish
detailed_summary: A fisherman and his wife reside in a humble pigsty near the sea.
While fishing, the man catches a large fish which, to his surprise, speaks.
The fish reveals itself to be an enchanted prince and implores the fisherman to release it.
The fisherman, stating he wants nothing to do with a talking fish, promptly returns it to the water.
The fish dives to the bottom, leaving a distinct trail of blood in the water.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he put him back into the water, and the fish darted straight down to the bottom, and left a long streak of blood behind him on the wave.

events.text_segment: There was once a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside. The fisherman used to go out all day long a-fishing; and one day, as he sat on the shore with his rod, looking at the sparkling waves and watching his line, all on a sudden his float was dragged away deep into the water: and in drawing it up he pulled out a great fish. But the fish said, ‘Pray let me live! I am not a real fish; I am an enchanted prince: put me in the water again, and let me go!’ ‘Oh, ho!’ said the man, ‘you need not make so many words about the matter; I will have nothing to do with a fish that can talk: so swim away, sir, as soon as you please!’ Then he put him back into the water, and the fish darted straight down to the bottom, and left a long streak of blood behind him on the wave.

events.title: The First Wish: A Cozy Cottage
detailed_summary: Upon returning home, the fisherman recounts his extraordinary catch and its release to his wife, Ilsabill.
Ilsabill chastises him for not requesting anything from the magical creature, lamenting their squalid living conditions.
She insists he return to the fish and ask for a comfortable little cottage.
Though reluctant, the fisherman goes to the seashore, where the water now appears yellow and green.
He calls out to the fish using a specific verse.
The fish surfaces and inquires about his wife's desires.
The fisherman explains Ilsabill's wish for a cottage instead of the pigsty.
The fish informs him that his wife's wish is granted and she is already in the cottage.
The fisherman finds Ilsabill at the door of a neat cottage, complete with a parlor, bedchamber, kitchen, garden, and a courtyard with poultry.
He expresses optimism for their future happiness, to which his wife cautiously agrees they will try.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the fisherman went home to his wife in the pigsty, he told her how he had caught a great fish, and how it had told him it was an enchanted prince, and how, on hearing it speak, he had let it go again.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘We will try to do so, at least,’ said his wife.

events.text_segment:
When the fisherman went home to his wife in the pigsty, he told her how he had caught a great fish, and how it had told him it was an enchanted prince, and how, on hearing it speak, he had let it go again. ‘Did not you ask it for anything?’ said the wife, ‘we live very wretchedly here, in this nasty dirty pigsty; do go back and tell the fish we want a snug little cottage.’
The fisherman did not much like the business: however, he went to the seashore; and when he came back there the water looked all yellow and green. And he stood at the water’s edge, and said:
‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
Then the fish came swimming to him, and said, ‘Well, what is her will? What does your wife want?’ ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘she says that when I had caught you, I ought to have asked you for something before I let you go; she does not like living any longer in the pigsty, and wants a snug little cottage.’ ‘Go home, then,’ said the fish; ‘she is in the cottage already!’ So the man went home, and saw his wife standing at the door of a nice trim little cottage. ‘Come in, come in!’ said she; ‘is not this much better than the filthy pigsty we had?’ And there was a parlour, and a bedchamber, and a kitchen; and behind the cottage there was a little garden, planted with all sorts of flowers and fruits; and there was a courtyard behind, full of ducks and chickens. ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘how happily we shall live now!’ ‘We will try to do so, at least,’ said his wife.

Reluctantly, the fisherman returned to the seashore, where the water now looked yellow and green. He called out to the fish with the special verse, and the fish appeared, asking what his wife desired.

The fisherman explained that his wife wanted a cottage instead of their pigsty. The fish granted her wish, and she was already in a neat little cottage when he returned.

He found her at the door of the cottage, which had a parlor, a bedchamber, a kitchen, a garden, and a courtyard with poultry. The fisherman was hopeful about their future happiness, but his wife, cautious, said they would see how things went.

When the fisherman went home to his wife in the pigsty, he told her how he had caught a great fish, and how it had told him it was an enchanted prince, and how, on hearing it speak, he had let it go again.

His wife, Ilsabill, scolded him for not asking the fish for anything, especially since they were living in such squalor. She said, “Go back and tell the fish to make us a little cottage, so we can live comfortably.”

Reluctantly, the fisherman went to the seashore, where the water now looked yellow and green. He called out:

"Fish, I pray you, good fish, hear my prayer!"

The fish appeared and asked, "What does your wife desire?"

The fisherman explained, "She wishes for a cottage, not a pigsty."

The fish replied, "Go home, your wife’s wish is granted. She is already in the cottage."

The fisherman returned and found his wife at the door of a neat little cottage, with a parlor, a bedchamber, a kitchen, a garden, and a courtyard with poultry. She looked at him and said, "Now we shall be happy," but he, cautious, answered, "We will see how it goes."

detailed_summary: After a brief period of contentment, Ilsabill declares the cottage insufficient, complaining about the small courtyard and garden.
She now desires a large stone castle and commands her husband to request it from the fish.

He recites the verse to summon the fish.

The fish instructs him to return home, informing him that his wife is already at the castle gate.

events.text_segment:
Everything went right for a week or two, and then Dame Ilsabill said, ‘Husband, there is not near room enough for us in this cottage; the courtyard and the garden are a great deal too small; I should like to have a large stone castle to live in: go to the fish again and tell him to give us a castle.’ ‘Wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘I don’t like to go to him again, for perhaps he will be angry; we ought to be easy with this pretty cottage to live in.’ ‘Nonsense!’ said the wife; ‘he will do it very willingly, I know; go along and try!’
The fisherman went, but his heart was very heavy: and when he came to the sea, it looked blue and gloomy, though it was very calm; and he went close to the edge of the waves, and said:
 ‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘Well, what does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the man, dolefully, ‘my wife wants to live in a stone castle.’ ‘Go home, then,’ said the fish; ‘she is standing at the gate of it already.’ So away went the fisherman, and found his wife standing before the gate of a great castle. ‘See,’ said she, ‘is not this grand?’ With that they went into the castle together, and found a great many servants there, and the rooms all richly furnished, and full of golden chairs and tables; and behind the castle was a garden, and around it was a park half a mile long, full of sheep, and goats, and hares, and deer; and in the courtyard were stables and cow-houses. ‘Well,’ said the man, ‘now we will live cheerful and happy in this beautiful castle for the rest of our lives.’ ‘Perhaps we may,’ said the wife; ‘but let us sleep upon it, before we make up our minds to that.’ So they went to bed.

events.title: The Third Wish: To Become King
detailed_summary: The following morning, Ilsabill awakens her husband with a new ambition: they must become king of all the land.
The fisherman questions this desire, stating he has no wish to be king.
Ilsabill retorts that if he won't be king, then she will.

Filled with sorrow at his wife's escalating desires, the man goes to the sea, which has turned a dark grey color, with churning waves and foam.
He calls out to the fish with the familiar chant.
The fish appears and asks what his wife now desires.
The fisherman reveals that his wife wants to be king.
The fish tells him to go home, for his wife is already king.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next morning when Dame Ilsabill awoke it was broad daylight, and she jogged the fisherman with her elbow, and said, ‘Get up, husband, and bestir yourself, for we must be king of all the land.’

events.text_segment:
The next morning when Dame Ilsabill awoke it was broad daylight, and she jogged the fisherman with her elbow, and said, ‘Get up, husband, and bestir yourself, for we must be king of all the land.’ ‘Wife, wife,’ said the man, ‘why should we wish to be the king? I will not be king.’ ‘Then I will,’ said she. ‘But, wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘how can you be king—the fish cannot make you a king?’ ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘say no more about it, but go and try! I will be king.’ So the man went away quite sorrowful to think that his wife should want to be king. This time the sea looked a dark grey colour, and was overspread with curling waves and the ridges of foam as he cried out:
 ‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘Well, what would she have now?’ said the fish. ‘Alas!’ said the poor man, ‘my wife wants to be king.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish; ‘she is king already.’

events.title: The Fourth Wish: To Become Emperor
detailed_summary: The fisherman returns to find a palace, complete with soldiers, drums, and trumpets.
Inside, Ilsabill is seated on a magnificent throne of gold and diamonds, wearing a golden crown and attended by six maidens.
After observing her regal state, the fisherman remarks on the finery of being king, hoping they will finally have no more wishes.
However, Ilsabill, already bored with her current status, declares her intention to become emperor.

Compelled to obey, the fisherman departs, muttering his fears that her excessive demands will lead to ruin.
He arrives at the seashore to find the water black and muddy, with a powerful whirlwind stirring the waves.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then the fisherman went home; and as he came close to the palace he saw a troop of soldiers, and heard the sound of drums and trumpets.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Go home,’ said the fish; ‘she is emperor already.’

events.text_segment:
Then the fisherman went home; and as he came close to the palace he saw a troop of soldiers, and heard the sound of drums and trumpets. And when he went in he saw his wife sitting on a throne of gold and diamonds, with a golden crown upon her head; and on each side of her stood six fair maidens, each a head taller than the other. ‘Well, wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘are you king?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘I am king.’ And when he had looked at her for a long time, he said, ‘Ah, wife! what a fine thing it is to be king! Now we shall never have anything more to wish for as long as we live.’ ‘I don’t know how that may be,’ said she; ‘never is a long time. I am king, it is true; but I begin to be tired of that, and I think I should like to be emperor.’ ‘Alas, wife! why should you wish to be emperor?’ said the fisherman. ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘go to the fish! I say I will be emperor.’ ‘Ah, wife!’ replied the fisherman, ‘the fish cannot make an emperor, I am sure, and I should not like to ask him for such a thing.’ ‘I am king,’ said Ilsabill, ‘and you are my slave; so go at once!’
So the fisherman was forced to go; and he muttered as he went along, ‘This will come to no good, it is too much to ask; the fish will be tired at last, and then we shall be sorry for what we have done.’ He soon came to the seashore; and the water was quite black and muddy, and a mighty whirlwind blew over the waves and rolled them about, but he went as near as he could to the water’s brink, and said:
‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘What would she have now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘she wants to be emperor.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish; ‘she is emperor already.’

events.title: The Fifth Wish: To Become Pope
detailed_summary: Returning home, the fisherman finds Ilsabill enthroned on an even more imposing seat of solid gold, wearing an immense crown, surrounded by guards, attendants, princes, dukes, and earls.

Ilsabill dismisses his objections, reasoning that if the fish could make an emperor, it can make a pope, and orders him to ask.

The fisherman goes to the shore, where a violent storm rages: the wind howls, the sea boils with tumultuous waves, and ships are tossed precariously. The sky is largely red, heralding a terrible storm, though a small patch of blue remains.
Terrified and trembling, he nevertheless approaches the water's edge and calls the fish.
The fish asks what she wants now.

events.text_segment:
So he went home again; and as he came near he saw his wife Ilsabill sitting on a very lofty throne made of solid gold, with a great crown on her head full two yards high; and on each side of her stood her guards and attendants in a row, each one smaller than the other, from the tallest giant down to a little dwarf no bigger than my finger. And before her stood princes, and dukes, and earls: and the fisherman went up to her and said, ‘Wife, are you emperor?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘I am emperor.’ ‘Ah!’ said the man, as he gazed upon her, ‘what a fine thing it is to be emperor!’ ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘why should we stop at being emperor? I will be pope next.’ ‘O wife, wife!’ said he, ‘how can you be pope? there is but one pope at a time in Christendom.’ ‘Husband,’ said she, ‘I will be pope this very day.’ ‘But,’ replied the husband, ‘the fish cannot make you pope.’ ‘What nonsense!’ said she; ‘if he can make an emperor, he can make a pope: go and try him.’
So the fisherman went. But when he came to the shore the wind was raging and the sea was tossed up and down in boiling waves, and the ships were in trouble, and rolled fearfully upon the tops of the billows. In the middle of the heavens there was a little piece of blue sky, but towards the south all was red, as if a dreadful storm was rising. At this sight the fisherman was dreadfully frightened, and he trembled so that his knees knocked together: but still he went down near to the shore, and said:
‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘What does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the fisherman, ‘my wife wants to be pope.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish; ‘she is pope already.’

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
So he went home again; and as he came near he saw his wife Ilsabill sitting on a very lofty throne made of solid gold, with a great crown on her head full two yards high; and on each side of her stood her guards and attendants in a row, each one smaller than the other, from the tallest giant down to a little dwarf no bigger than my finger.

When she saw him, she called him to her and said, "Fisherman, I am now the empress of the world, and I am quite satisfied with my power. But I desire more; I want to be pope."

The fisherman was surprised and said, "My wife, what do you mean? The pope is the highest of all, and only God can make a pope."

"Oh, no," she replied, "the fish can do anything. Go and ask him to make me pope."

The fisherman was afraid but dared not refuse. So he went to the sea and called out to the fish, which asked, "What do you want now?"

"My wife wishes to be pope," he said.

The fish answered, "Go home; she is already pope."

He went back and told his wife, who was very pleased and said, "Now I am satisfied."

But soon she grew restless again and demanded to be king of the land. The fisherman, fearing her, went once more to the sea and called the fish, who asked him what he wanted.

"My wife wishes to be king," he said.

"Go home," said the fish, "she is king already."

And so it went on, until she wished to be emperor of the world, and then to be a god, and finally she wanted to be master of the universe. Each time, the fish granted her wish, and the fisherman returned home, trembling and afraid.

events.text_segment:
Then the fisherman went home, and found Ilsabill sitting on a throne that was two miles high. And she had three great crowns on her head, and around her stood all the pomp and power of the Church. And on each side of her were two rows of burning lights, of all sizes, the greatest as large as the highest and biggest tower in the world, and the least no larger than a small rushlight. ‘Wife,’ said the fisherman, as he looked at all this greatness, ‘are you pope?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘I am pope.’ ‘Well, wife,’ replied he, ‘it is a grand thing to be pope; and now you must be easy, for you can be nothing greater.’ ‘I will think about that,’ said the wife. Then they went to bed: but Dame Ilsabill could not sleep all night for thinking what she should be next. At last, as she was dropping asleep, morning broke, and the sun rose. ‘Ha!’ thought she, as she woke up and looked at it through the window, ‘after all I cannot prevent the sun rising.’ At this thought she was very angry, and wakened her husband, and said, ‘Husband, go to the fish and tell him I must be lord of the sun and moon.’ The fisherman was half asleep, but the thought frightened him so much that he started and fell out of bed. ‘Alas, wife!’ said he, ‘cannot you be easy with being pope?’ ‘No,’ said she, ‘I am very uneasy as long as the sun and moon rise without my leave. Go to the fish at once!’
Then the man went shivering with fear; and as he was going down to the shore a dreadful storm arose, so that the trees and the very rocks shook. And all the heavens became black with stormy clouds, and the lightnings played, and the thunders rolled; and you might have seen in the sea great black waves, swelling up like mountains with crowns of white foam upon their heads. And the fisherman crept towards the sea, and cried out, as well as he could:
‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘What does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said he, ‘she wants to be lord of the sun and moon.’ ‘Go home,’ said the fish, ‘to your pigsty again.’
And there they live to this very day.

events.title: The Bear's Disrespectful Visit and Insult to the Wrens
detailed_summary: While walking in the forest, the bear becomes captivated by a bird's beautiful singing.
The wolf identifies the singer as the King of birds, the willow-wren, and states that they must show reverence.
The bear expresses a keen interest in seeing the willow-wren's royal palace, prompting the wolf to advise him to wait until the Queen wren makes an appearance.
Soon after, the Queen arrives with food, accompanied by the King, and they begin feeding their young.
The bear is eager to approach, but the wolf restrains him, advising they wait until the royal couple departs.
They observe the location of the nest and then leave.
Unable to contain his curiosity, the bear returns to the nest alone a short time later, when the King and Queen have flown out.
He peeps into the nest and sees five or six young wrens.
The bear mockingly questions if this is the royal palace, calling it a 'wretched palace' and deriding the young birds as 'disreputable children' instead of royal offspring.
The young wrens react with extreme anger to the insult, vehemently denying the accusations, asserting the honesty of their parents, and warning the bear that he will be made to pay for his words.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When the young wrens heard that, they were frightfully angry, and screamed: ‘No, that we are not! Our parents are honest people! Bear, you will have to pay for that!’

events.text_segment: Once in summer-time the bear and the wolf were walking in the forest, and the bear heard a bird singing so beautifully that he said: ‘Brother wolf, what bird is it that sings so well?’ ‘That is the King of birds,’ said the wolf, ‘before whom we must bow down.’ In reality the bird was the willow-wren. ‘IF that’s the case,’ said the bear, ‘I should very much like to see his royal palace; come, take me thither.’ ‘That is not done quite as you seem to think,’ said the wolf; ‘you must wait until the Queen comes,’ Soon afterwards, the Queen arrived with some food in her beak, and the lord King came too, and they began to feed their young ones. The bear would have liked to go at once, but the wolf held him back by the sleeve, and said: ‘No, you must wait until the lord and lady Queen have gone away again.’ So they took stock of the hole where the nest lay, and trotted away. The bear, however, could not rest until he had seen the royal palace, and when a short time had passed, went to it again. The King and Queen had just flown out, so he peeped in and saw five or six young ones lying there. ‘Is that the royal palace?’ cried the bear; ‘it is a wretched palace, and you are not King’s children, you are disreputable children!’ When the young wrens heard that, they were frightfully angry, and screamed: ‘No, that we are not! Our parents are honest people! Bear, you will have to pay for that!’

Soon the Queen arrived with food, accompanied by the King, and they began feeding their little ones. The bear wanted to go near, but the wolf held him back, advising him to wait until the royal couple had left. They watched the nest from a distance, then left quietly. events.title: The Wrens' Outrage and the Declaration of War
detailed_summary: The bear and the wolf become apprehensive and retreat to their respective dens.
The young willow-wrens continue their distressed cries and, when their parents return with food, they adamantly refuse to eat.
They declare they will not touch even a fly's leg, even if starving, until their parents settle the matter of their respectability, informing them of the bear's insulting visit.
The old King wren reassures his children, promising that the bear will be punished for his actions.
He and the Queen immediately fly to the bear's cave and call in to him.
The King wren, addressing the bear as 'Old Growler,' demands to know why he insulted his children and declares that he will suffer for it through a 'bloody war.'
With war thus declared upon the Bear, all four-footed animals, including oxen, asses, cows, deer, and every other terrestrial creature, are summoned to participate.
Simultaneously, the willow-wren summons all creatures that fly, not only birds of all sizes but also midges, hornets, bees, and flies, to join his forces.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The bear and the wolf grew uneasy, and turned back and went into their holes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And the willow-wren summoned everything which flew in the air, not only birds, large and small, but midges, and hornets, bees and flies had to come.

events.text_segment: The bear and the wolf grew uneasy, and turned back and went into their holes. The young willow-wrens, however, continued to cry and scream, and when their parents again brought food they said: ‘We will not so much as touch one fly’s leg, no, not if we were dying of hunger, until you have settled whether we are respectable children or not; the bear has been here and has insulted us!’ Then the old King said: ‘Be easy, he shall be punished,’ and he at once flew with the Queen to the bear’s cave, and called in: ‘Old Growler, why have you insulted my children? You shall suffer for it—we will punish you by a bloody war.’ Thus war was announced to the Bear, and all four-footed animals were summoned to take part in it, oxen, asses, cows, deer, and every other animal the earth contained. And the willow-wren summoned everything which flew in the air, not only birds, large and small, but midges, and hornets, bees and flies had to come.

events.title: Espionage Reveals the Enemy's Battle Strategy
detailed_summary: When the time for war to commence drew near, the willow-wren dispatched spies to ascertain the identity of the enemy's commander-in-chief.
The gnat, described as the most cunning spy, flew into the forest where the enemy forces were assembled.
The gnat concealed itself beneath a leaf on the tree where the password and strategic commands were to be issued.
The bear was present and called the fox before him, appointing the fox as general due to his reputation as the most cunning of all animals.
The fox accepted the position of general and then questioned what signal they should agree upon for their maneuvers.
As no one had a suggestion, the fox proposed using his own long, bushy tail, which resembled a plume of red feathers, as the signal.
He explained that if he lifted his tail high, it meant all was going well, and the troops should charge; however, if he let it hang down, they should retreat as quickly as possible.
Having overheard this critical information, the gnat flew back and meticulously reported every detail to the willow-wren.

events.text_segment: When the time came for the war to begin, the willow-wren sent out spies to discover who was the enemy’s commander-in-chief. The gnat, who was the most crafty, flew into the forest where the enemy was assembled, and hid herself beneath a leaf of the tree where the password was to be announced. There stood the bear, and he called the fox before him and said: ‘Fox, you are the most cunning of all animals, you shall be general and lead us.’ ‘Good,’ said the fox, ‘but what signal shall we agree upon?’ No one knew that, so the fox said: ‘I have a fine long bushy tail, which almost looks like a plume of red feathers. When I lift my tail up quite high, all is going well, and you must charge; but if I let it hang down, run away as fast as you can.’ When the gnat had heard that, she flew away again, and revealed everything, down to the minutest detail, to the willow-wren.

events.title: The Decisive Battle: The Hornet's Sting and the Birds' Victory
detailed_summary: At daybreak, as the battle was set to begin, the assembled four-footed animals charged forward, creating a noise so immense that the earth trembled.
The willow-wren, accompanied by his aerial army, also advanced, their movement generating such a humming, whirring, and swarming that it caused unease and fear in all observers.
Both armies moved to engage each other.
The willow-wren issued an order to the hornet, instructing it to position itself beneath the fox's tail and sting with all its might.
When the fox experienced the first sting, he jolted and lifted one leg in pain but managed to endure it, keeping his tail held high.
Upon receiving a second sting, the fox was compelled to lower his tail for a moment.
After the third sting, the fox could no longer bear the pain; he screamed and tucked his tail between his legs.
Witnessing this, the other animals misinterpreted the fox's lowered tail as the signal for retreat, concluded that all was lost, and began to flee, each seeking refuge in its hole.
As a result, the birds emerged victorious from the battle.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When the animals saw that, they thought all was lost, and began to flee, each into his hole, and the birds had won the battle.

events.text_segment: When day broke, and the battle was to begin, all the four-footed animals came running up with such a noise that the earth trembled. The willow-wren with his army also came flying through the air with such a humming, and whirring, and swarming that every one was uneasy and afraid, and on both sides they advanced against each other. But the willow-wren sent down the hornet, with orders to settle beneath the fox’s tail, and sting with all his might. When the fox felt the first string, he started so that he lifted one leg, from pain, but he bore it, and still kept his tail high in the air; at the second sting, he was forced to put it down for a moment; at the third, he could hold out no longer, screamed, and put his tail between his legs. When the animals saw that, they thought all was lost, and began to flee, each into his hole, and the birds had won the battle.

events.title: The Bear's Apology and the Wrens' Final Triumph
detailed_summary: Following the victory, the King and Queen wren flew home to their children, joyfully exclaiming, 'Children, rejoice, eat and drink to your heart's content, we have won the battle!'
However, the young wrens maintained their resolve, stating they would not eat yet.
They insisted that the bear must first come to their nest, beg for their pardon, and explicitly affirm that they are 'honourable children' before they would consider eating.
In response, the willow-wren (King) flew to the bear's hole.
He sternly addressed the bear, 'Growler, you are to come to the nest to my children, and beg their pardon, or else every rib of your body shall be broken.'
Gripped by immense fear, the bear crept to the wrens' nest and formally begged their pardon.
Finally satisfied, the young wrens at last sat down together, ate, drank, and celebrated merrily late into the night.

events.text_segment: Then the King and Queen flew home to their children and cried: ‘Children, rejoice, eat and drink to your heart’s content, we have won the battle!’ But the young wrens said: ‘We will not eat yet, the bear must come to the nest, and beg for pardon and say that we are honourable children, before we will do that.’ Then the willow-wren flew to the bear’s hole and cried: ‘Growler, you are to come to the nest to my children, and beg their pardon, or else every rib of your body shall be broken.’ So the bear crept thither in the greatest fear, and begged their pardon. And now at last the young wrens were satisfied, and sat down together and ate and drank, and made merry till quite late into the night.

events.title: The Lost Ball and the Frog's Conditional Offer
detailed_summary: A young princess, during a solitary walk in a wood, sits by a cool spring to rest.
She plays with her favorite golden ball, tossing it in the air, but eventually throws it too high and it falls into the spring.
The princess is distraught as the spring is too deep to see the bottom, and she laments her loss, offering all her possessions for the ball's return.
A frog emerges from the water and inquires about her sorrow.
The princess dismissively explains her predicament to the 'nasty frog'.
The frog expresses no interest in her clothes or jewels but offers to retrieve the ball if she promises to love him, let him live with her, eat from her plate, and sleep in her bed.
The princess privately scoffs at the frog's conditions, believing he could never leave the spring, and agrees to his terms solely to recover her ball.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One fine evening a young princess put on her bonnet and clogs, and went out to take a walk by herself in a wood; and when she came to a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it, she sat herself down to rest a while.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So she said to the frog, ‘Well, if you will bring me my ball, I will do all you ask.’

events.text_segment:
One fine evening a young princess put on her bonnet and clogs, and went out to take a walk by herself in a wood; and when she came to a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it, she sat herself down to rest a while. Now she had a golden ball in her hand, which was her favourite plaything; and she was always tossing it up into the air, and catching it again as it fell. After a time she threw it up so high that she missed catching it as it fell; and the ball bounded away, and rolled along upon the ground, till at last it fell down into the spring. The princess looked into the spring after her ball, but it was very deep, so deep that she could not see the bottom of it. Then she began to bewail her loss, and said, ‘Alas! if I could only get my ball again, I would give all my fine clothes and jewels, and everything that I have in the world.’
Whilst she was speaking, a frog put its head out of the water, and said, ‘Princess, why do you weep so bitterly?’ ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘what can you do for me, you nasty frog? My golden ball has fallen into the spring.’ The frog said, ‘I want not your pearls, and jewels, and fine clothes; but if you will love me, and let me live with you and eat from off your golden plate, and sleep upon your bed, I will bring you your ball again.’ ‘What nonsense,’ thought the princess, ‘this silly frog is talking! He can never even get out of the spring to visit me, though he may be able to get my ball for me, and therefore I will tell him he shall have what he asks.’ So she said to the frog, ‘Well, if you will bring me my ball, I will do all you ask.’

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
One fine evening a young princess put on her bonnet and clogs, and went out to take a walk by herself in a wood; and when she came to a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it, she sat herself down to rest a while.

While she was sitting there, her golden ball, which she had been playing with, slipped from her hand and fell into the spring. The princess looked into the water, but the spring was so deep that she could not see the bottom, and she was very much distressed.

She sat and wept, and wished she had never gone out into the wood. She promised herself that she would give anything she had in the world if she could only get her ball back.

Just then, a frog came up out of the spring and asked what was the matter.

"Oh, dear frog!" said she, "I have lost my golden ball in the spring, and I cannot get it out."

The frog said, "I will help you if you will love me, and let me come and eat from your plate, and sleep in your bed."

The princess was disgusted at the idea of loving a frog, and she said, "You are a nasty frog, and I will not have you come and eat from my plate, or sleep in my bed."

But the frog was very persistent, and he promised to help her if she would keep her word.

So she promised, and the frog went down into the spring, and soon brought up her golden ball.

The princess was very glad, and she ran home, forgetting all about her promise to the frog.

But the frog came to her palace and reminded her of her promise, and she was very angry, but she kept her word and let him come in.

He ate from her plate, and slept in her bed, and at last she grew to love him, and he became a handsome prince.

But the frog came to her palace and reminded her of her promise, and she was very angry, but she kept her word and let him come in.

He ate from her plate, and slept in her bed, and at last she grew to love him, and he became a handsome prince.

events.title: The Frog's Arrival and the King's Command
detailed_summary: The following day, as the princess is seated for dinner, she hears an unusual tapping and splashing sound approaching, followed by a knock at the door.
A small voice sings a verse, reminding the princess of their agreement made by the cool fountain in the woods.
The princess opens the door to find the frog, whom she had entirely forgotten.
Startled and frightened, she slams the door shut and returns to her seat.
Her father, the king, notices her distress and asks what frightened her.
She explains about the 'nasty frog' who retrieved her ball, the promise she made (believing he couldn't leave the spring), and his current presence at the door demanding entry.
As she speaks, the frog knocks again, repeating his poetic plea.
The king firmly instructs his daughter that she must keep her word and allow the frog inside.

events.text_segment:
The next day, just as the princess had sat down to dinner, she heard a strange noise—tap, tap—plash, plash—as if something was coming up the marble staircase: and soon afterwards there was a gentle knock at the door, and a little voice cried out and said:
‘Open the door, my princess dear,
  Open the door to thy true love here!
  And mind the words that thou and I said
  By the fountain cool, in the greenwood shade.’
Then the princess ran to the door and opened it, and there she saw the frog, whom she had quite forgotten. At this sight she was sadly frightened, and shutting the door as fast as she could came back to her seat. The king, her father, seeing that something had frightened her, asked her what was the matter. ‘There is a nasty frog,’ said she, ‘at the door, that lifted my ball for me out of the spring this morning: I told him that he should live with me here, thinking that he could never get out of the spring; but there he is at the door, and he wants to come in.’
While she was speaking the frog knocked again at the door, and said:
‘Open the door, my princess dear,
  Open the door to thy true love here!
  And mind the words that thou and I said
  By the fountain cool, in the greenwood shade.’
Then the king said to the young princess, ‘As you have given your word you must keep it; so go and let him in.’

events.title: Reluctant Hospitality: The First Night
detailed_summary: The princess obediently opens the door, and the frog hops into the room.
He makes his way across the floor with distinct tapping and splashing sounds until he reaches the princess's table.
The frog requests to be lifted onto her chair to sit beside her.
After she complies, he asks her to move her golden plate closer so he can share her meal.
Once the frog has eaten his fill, he declares he is tired and demands that the princess carry him upstairs to her bed.
The princess, with great reluctance, takes the frog in her hand and places him on the pillow of her own bed, where he remains for the entire night.
As soon as daylight breaks, the frog jumps from the bed, hops downstairs, and leaves the house.
The princess feels a sense of relief, believing her troubles with the frog are finally over.

As soon as it was light he jumped up, hopped downstairs, and went out of the house. ‘Now, then,’ thought the princess, ‘at last he is gone, and I shall be troubled with him no more.’

events.title: An Unlikely Alliance and a Winter Provision Plan
detailed_summary: A cat persuaded a mouse of her profound affection and friendship, which led to the mouse consenting to share a home with her.
The cat highlighted the importance of storing food for the upcoming winter to prevent starvation.
She also warned the mouse about the perils of venturing out independently, specifically mentioning the risk of traps.
Heeding this counsel, they jointly procured a pot of fat.
After careful consideration, the cat suggested hiding the pot of fat within the church, underneath the altar, believing this location would ensure its safety from theft.
They mutually agreed not to access the fat unless they faced a situation of genuine, dire need.

events.text_segment: A certain cat had made the acquaintance of a mouse, and had said so much to her about the great love and friendship she felt for her, that at length the mouse agreed that they should live and keep house together. ‘But we must make a provision for winter, or else we shall suffer from hunger,’ said the cat; ‘and you, little mouse, cannot venture everywhere, or you will be caught in a trap some day.’ The good advice was followed, and a pot of fat was bought, but they did not know where to put it. At length, after much consideration, the cat said: ‘I know no place where it will be better stored up than in the church, for no one dares take anything away from there. We will set it beneath the altar, and not touch it until we are really in need of it.’

events.title: The Cat's First Deception: "Top-Off" Christened
detailed_summary: The pot of fat was securely placed in the church, but the cat soon felt an intense desire for it.
The cat fabricated a story about her cousin having a new son and requiring her to act as godmother at the christening, describing the imaginary infant as white with brown spots.
She asked for permission to leave for the day, entrusting the mouse with household duties.
The mouse willingly agreed, expressing a hopeful wish that the cat would think of her if any delicious food was available, particularly mentioning a longing for sweet red christening wine.
The cat's entire account was untrue; she neither had a cousin nor had she received an invitation to be a godmother.
She proceeded directly to the church, stealthily approached the pot of fat, and licked off the entire top layer.
Subsequently, she strolled along the town's rooftops, basked in the sun, and savored the thought of the pot of fat, only returning to their shared home in the evening.
The mouse welcomed her back, naturally assuming she had enjoyed a delightful day.
When questioned about the baby's name, the cat nonchalantly stated, "Top off!"
The mouse considered the name quite strange and out of the ordinary, inquiring if such a name was customary in the cat's family.
The cat brushed off the mouse's apprehension, retorting that the name was no more peculiar than "Crumb-stealer," a name she attributed to the mouse's own godchildren.

events.text_segment: So the pot was placed in safety, but it was not long before the cat had a great yearning for it, and said to the mouse: ‘I want to tell you something, little mouse; my cousin has brought a little son into the world, and has asked me to be godmother; he is white with brown spots, and I am to hold him over the font at the christening. Let me go out today, and you look after the house by yourself.’ ‘Yes, yes,’ answered the mouse, ‘by all means go, and if you get anything very good to eat, think of me. I should like a drop of sweet red christening wine myself.’ All this, however, was untrue; the cat had no cousin, and had not been asked to be godmother. She went straight to the church, stole to the pot of fat, began to lick at it, and licked the top of the fat off. Then she took a walk upon the roofs of the town, looked out for opportunities, and then stretched herself in the sun, and licked her lips whenever she thought of the pot of fat, and not until it was evening did she return home. ‘Well, here you are again,’ said the mouse, ‘no doubt you have had a merry day.’ ‘All went off well,’ answered the cat. ‘What name did they give the child?’ ‘Top off!’ said the cat quite coolly. ‘Top off!’ cried the mouse, ‘that is a very odd and uncommon name, is it a usual one in your family?’ ‘What does that matter,’ said the cat, ‘it is no worse than Crumb-stealer, as your godchildren are called.’

events.title: The Cat's Second Deception: "Half-Done" Christened
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, the cat experienced another compelling urge for the stored fat.

She once more requested the mouse to look after the house alone for the day, inventing a second godmother invitation for a child she claimed had a distinctive white ring around its neck, an invitation she asserted she could not decline.
The kind-hearted mouse assented to the cat's request.
The cat, however, secretly went behind the town walls to the church and proceeded to eat half of the fat remaining in the pot.
She privately reflected that items kept hidden for oneself often provide the greatest pleasure and felt thoroughly content with her day's clandestine activities.
Upon her return home, the mouse inquired about the name given to this second child.
The cat announced that the child had been christened "Half-done."
The mouse was taken aback by this name, exclaiming that she had never encountered such a name in her entire life and would wager that it was not listed in any calendar.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Before long the cat was seized by another fit of yearning.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I never heard the name in my life, I’ll wager anything it is not in the calendar!’

events.text_segment: Before long the cat was seized by another fit of yearning. She said to the mouse: ‘You must do me a favour, and once more manage the house for a day alone. I am again asked to be godmother, and, as the child has a white ring round its neck, I cannot refuse.’ The good mouse consented, but the cat crept behind the town walls to the church, and devoured half the pot of fat. ‘Nothing ever seems so good as what one keeps to oneself,’ said she, and was quite satisfied with her day’s work. When she went home the mouse inquired: ‘And what was the child christened?’ ‘Half-done,’ answered the cat. ‘Half-done! What are you saying? I never heard the name in my life, I’ll wager anything it is not in the calendar!’

events.title: The Cat's Third Deception: "All-Gone" Christened
detailed_summary: The cat's desire for more of the fat soon resurfaced, making her mouth water.
She rationalized her next departure by stating, "All good things go in threes," and concocted a third invitation to be a godmother.
She described this supposed infant as completely black with the sole exception of white paws, asserting that such a birth was a very infrequent event.
The mouse, already finding the names "Top-off" and "Half-done" peculiar and disquieting, voiced her growing unease.
The cat dismissed the mouse's worries, attributing her fanciful thoughts to her confinement indoors, clad in her "dark-grey fur coat and long tail," and her lack of outdoor experiences.
During the cat's absence, the mouse diligently cleaned their house and set everything in order.
Meanwhile, the insatiable cat consumed every last bit of the fat from the pot.
She mused to herself that a sense of tranquility comes when everything is eaten up, and returned home late in the evening, feeling satisfied and engorged.
The mouse immediately inquired about the name given to the third child.
The cat responded that this new name, "All-gone," was unlikely to please the mouse any more than the previous ones.

The mouse reacted with significant alarm, deeming "All-gone" the most suspicious name of all, one she had never encountered in written form, and pondered its potential meaning before unsettlingly curling up to sleep.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All-gone; what can that mean?’ and she shook her head, curled herself up, and lay down to sleep.

events.text_segment: The cat’s mouth soon began to water for some more licking. ‘All good things go in threes,’ said she, ‘I am asked to stand godmother again. The child is quite black, only it has white paws, but with that exception, it has not a single white hair on its whole body; this only happens once every few years, you will let me go, won’t you?’ ‘Top-off! Half-done!’ answered the mouse, ‘they are such odd names, they make me very thoughtful.’ ‘You sit at home,’ said the cat, ‘in your dark-grey fur coat and long tail, and are filled with fancies, that’s because you do not go out in the daytime.’ During the cat’s absence the mouse cleaned the house, and put it in order, but the greedy cat entirely emptied the pot of fat. ‘When everything is eaten up one has some peace,’ said she to herself, and well filled and fat she did not return home till night. The mouse at once asked what name had been given to the third child. ‘It will not please you more than the others,’ said the cat. ‘He is called All-gone.’ ‘All-gone,’ cried the mouse ‘that is the most suspicious name of all! I have never seen it in print. All-gone; what can that mean?’ and she shook her head, curled herself up, and lay down to sleep.

events.title: The Truth Revealed and the Mouse's Demise
detailed_summary: Following these events, the cat received no more (fabricated) invitations to be a godmother.
When winter arrived and external food sources disappeared, the mouse recalled their carefully stored provision.
She cheerfully proposed to the cat that they retrieve their pot of fat and enjoy its contents.
The cat replied with a biting sarcasm, suggesting the mouse would derive as much pleasure from it as she would from sticking her tongue out the window, implying there would be nothing to enjoy.
They journeyed to the church, and although the pot of fat was still in its designated spot, it was completely empty.
The mouse, aghast, exclaimed that she now understood the situation and that the cat's duplicity had come to light.
She accused the cat of having consumed all the fat during her supposed godmother excursions, beginning to recount the deceptive names: "First top off, then half-done, then—".
The cat furiously cut her off, threatening to devour the mouse as well if she uttered another word.
The name "All-gone" was already on the unfortunate mouse's lips; the moment she spoke it, the cat leaped upon her, captured her, and consumed her.
The narrator concludes with the somber reflection that this, indeed, reflects the nature of the world.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Verily, that is the way of the world.

events.text_segment: From this time forth no one invited the cat to be godmother, but when the winter had come and there was no longer anything to be found outside, the mouse thought of their provision, and said: ‘Come, cat, we will go to our pot of fat which we have stored up for ourselves—we shall enjoy that.’ ‘Yes,’ answered the cat, ‘you will enjoy it as much as you would enjoy sticking that dainty tongue of yours out of the window.’ They set out on their way, but when they arrived, the pot of fat certainly was still in its place, but it was empty. ‘Alas!’ said the mouse, ‘now I see what has happened, now it comes to light! You are a true friend! You have devoured all when you were standing godmother. First top off, then half-done, then—’ ‘Will you hold your tongue,’ cried the cat, ‘one word more, and I will eat you too.’ ‘All-gone’ was already on the poor mouse’s lips; scarcely had she spoken it before the cat sprang on her, seized her, and swallowed her down. Verily, that is the way of the world.

events.title: The Princess's Royal Upbringing and Journey Preparations with a Fairy's Gift
detailed_summary: Following the king's demise, the queen devotedly raised their exceptionally beautiful daughter, aided by a benevolent fairy.
When the princess reached adulthood, she was betrothed to a prince from a distant land.

As the time for her marriage and departure neared, the queen meticulously assembled a vast collection of costly items suitable for a royal bride, including jewels, precious metals, trinkets, and fine garments.
The queen also appointed a waiting-maid to accompany the princess on her journey and formally present her to the bridegroom.
Each was provided with a horse for travel; the princess's horse, named Falada, was a unique gift from the fairy and possessed the magical ability to speak.

Prior to the princess setting out, the good fairy visited her bed-chamber, carefully cut a lock of her own hair, and presented it to the princess, explaining it was a charm that could offer assistance during the journey.
After a poignant farewell ceremony involving all present, the princess placed the lock of hair in her bosom, mounted Falada, and embarked on her voyage to her bridegroom’s kingdom.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The king of a great land died, and left his queen to take care of their only child.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they all took a sorrowful leave of the princess; and she put the lock of hair into her bosom, got upon her horse, and set off on her journey to her bridegroom’s kingdom.

events.text_segment:
The king of a great land died, and left his queen to take care of their only child. This child was a daughter, who was very beautiful; and her mother loved her dearly, and was very kind to her. And there was a good fairy too, who was fond of the princess, and helped her mother to watch over her. When she grew up, she was betrothed to a prince who lived a great way off; and as the time drew near for her to be married, she got ready to set off on her journey to his country. Then the queen her mother, packed up a great many costly things; jewels, and gold, and silver; trinkets, fine dresses, and in short everything that became a royal bride. And she gave her a waiting-maid to ride with her, and give her into the bridegroom’s hands; and each had a horse for the journey. Now the princess’s horse was the fairy’s gift, and it was called Falada, and could speak.
When the time came for them to set out, the fairy went into her bed-chamber, and took a little knife, and cut off a lock of her hair, and gave it to the princess, and said, ‘Take care of it, dear child; for it is a charm that may be of use to you on the road.’ Then they all took a sorrowful leave of the princess; and she put the lock of hair into her bosom, got upon her horse, and set off on her journey to her bridegroom’s kingdom.

As the time for her departure drew near, the queen packed a great many costly things—jewels, gold, silver, trinkets, and fine garments—everything suitable for a royal bride. events.title: The Maid's First Act of Defiance and the Charm's Ominous Warning
detailed_summary: While traveling alongside a brook one day, the princess experienced great thirst and politely asked her waiting-maid to fetch her some water from the brook using her golden cup.
The maid defiantly retorted that if the princess was thirsty, she should dismount and get the water herself, declaring she would no longer act as her waiting-maid.
Feeling intensely thirsty and intimidated, the princess dismounted, knelt by the brook, and drank the water directly, too frightened to use her golden cup.

She wept in distress, questioning what would happen to her, at which point the lock of hair responded with a rhyming verse, lamenting how her mother would grieve if she knew of the princess's situation.
Being inherently gentle and meek, the princess did not comment on her maid's disrespectful conduct and simply remounted her horse to continue the journey.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One day, as they were riding along by a brook, the princess began to feel very thirsty: and she said to her maid, ‘Pray get down, and fetch me some water in my golden cup out of yonder brook, for I want to drink.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But the princess was very gentle and meek, so she said nothing to her maid’s ill behaviour, but got upon her horse again.

events.text_segment:
One day, as they were riding along by a brook, the princess began to feel very thirsty: and she said to her maid, ‘Pray get down, and fetch me some water in my golden cup out of yonder brook, for I want to drink.’ ‘Nay,’ said the maid, ‘if you are thirsty, get off yourself, and stoop down by the water and drink; I shall not be your waiting-maid any longer.’ Then she was so thirsty that she got down, and knelt over the little brook, and drank; for she was frightened, and dared not bring out her golden cup; and she wept and said, ‘Alas! what will become of me?’ And the lock answered her, and said:
‘Alas! alas! if thy mother knew it,
  Sadly, sadly, would she rue it.’
But the princess was very gentle and meek, so she said nothing to her maid’s ill behaviour, but got upon her horse again.

events.title: The Loss of the Protective Charm and the Maid's Complete Usurpation of the Princess's Identity
detailed_summary: The party continued their journey until the day became exceedingly warm and the sun oppressively hot, causing the princess to feel extremely thirsty once more.
Upon reaching a river, having momentarily forgotten the maid's earlier rudeness, she requested water in her golden cup.
The maid responded with even greater insolence than before, firmly stating her refusal to act as a waiting-maid.
Overwhelmed by thirst, the princess dismounted, lay down, and leaned her head over the flowing stream to drink, crying out and wondering about her fate.
The lock of hair again offered its rhyming admonition.
As she bent down to drink, the precious lock of hair slipped from her bosom and was carried away by the water, an event the princess did not notice due to her distress.
Her maid, however, witnessed the loss of the hair, understood it was the charm, and gleefully realized that with the charm gone, the unfortunate bride would be entirely under her control.
Consequently, when the princess finished drinking and prepared to remount Falada, the maid asserted that she would ride Falada, compelling the princess to take the maid's horse instead.
Shortly thereafter, the maid forced the princess to relinquish her royal garments and wear the maid's own shabby attire.

events.text_segment:
Then all rode farther on their journey, till the day grew so warm, and the sun so scorching, that the bride began to feel very thirsty again; and at last, when they came to a river, she forgot her maid’s rude speech, and said, ‘Pray get down, and fetch me some water to drink in my golden cup.’ But the maid answered her, and even spoke more haughtily than before: ‘Drink if you will, but I shall not be your waiting-maid.’ Then the princess was so thirsty that she got off her horse, and lay down, and held her head over the running stream, and cried and said, ‘What will become of me?’ And the lock of hair answered her again:
‘Alas! alas! if thy mother knew it,
  Sadly, sadly, would she rue it.’
And as she leaned down to drink, the lock of hair fell from her bosom, and floated away with the water. Now she was so frightened that she did not see it; but her maid saw it, and was very glad, for she knew the charm; and she saw that the poor bride would be in her power, now that she had lost the hair. So when the bride had done drinking, and would have got upon Falada again, the maid said, ‘I shall ride upon Falada, and you may have my horse instead’; so she was forced to give up her horse, and soon afterwards to take off her royal clothes and put on her maid’s shabby ones.

events.title: Arrival at the Royal Court and the Deceptive Presentation of the False Bride
detailed_summary: As they neared the conclusion of their journey, the treacherous waiting-maid threatened to end her mistress's life if the princess dared to reveal to anyone the events that had transpired.
Falada, the sentient horse, observed and carefully noted all of these wicked actions.
Upon their arrival at the royal court, there was widespread rejoicing.
The prince eagerly rushed to meet them and, mistaking the waiting-maid for his intended bride, lifted her from her horse.
The imposter maid was then escorted upstairs to the royal chamber, while the true princess was instructed to remain behind in the courtyard below.

events.title: The True Princess is Noticed by the Old King and Assigned as a Goose-Girl
detailed_summary: The old king, who happened to be unoccupied at that moment, was amusing himself by observing the courtyard activities from his kitchen window when he noticed the true princess.
He remarked on her striking beauty and delicate demeanor, which seemed incongruous for a mere waiting-maid.
Consequently, he ascended to the royal chamber to inquire of the (false) bride about the identity of the young woman she had brought and left standing in the court.
The false bride deceptively stated she had brought the girl for companionship on the road and requested that some work be assigned to her to prevent idleness.
After contemplating for a while, the old king decided that the princess could assist a lad named Curdken, who was responsible for tending the king's geese.

events.title: Falada's Execution Orchestrated by the False Bride and the Princess's Sorrowful Request
detailed_summary: The false bride approached the prince and requested, as a supposed act of kindness, that he order the execution of the horse she had ridden (Falada).
She falsely claimed the horse had been unruly and had caused her considerable trouble during the journey.
Her true motivation, however, was a deep-seated fear that Falada might one day speak and reveal her treachery towards the princess.
Her request was granted, and the faithful Falada was consequently killed.
Upon learning of Falada's demise, the true princess was overcome with grief and wept.
She implored the slaughterer to nail Falada's severed head against a large, dark city gate, a route she had to traverse every morning and evening, so that she might still have a chance to see him.
The slaughterer agreed to her wish, decapitated Falada, and securely nailed the head beneath the designated dark gate.

She carried her point, and the faithful Falada was killed; but when the true princess heard of it, she wept, and begged the man to nail up Falada’s head against a large dark gate of the city, through which she had to pass every morning and evening, that there she might still see him sometimes. events.title: The Goose-Girl's Daily Rituals: Conversations with Falada's Head and Magical Hair Care
detailed_summary: Early the subsequent morning, as the princess (now a goose-girl) and Curdken passed through the city gate, she addressed Falada's mounted head with sorrow.
The head responded with a rhyming couplet, acknowledging her passage and lamenting that her mother was unaware of her current suffering.
They then proceeded out of the city to guide the geese to pasture.
Upon reaching the meadow, the princess sat down and let down her flowing locks of hair, which were all of pure silver.
When Curdken observed her hair glittering in the sunlight, he ran towards her with the intention of pulling some of the locks.
She, however, cried out a magical verse, imploring the breezes to blow away Curdken's hat.
A strong wind instantly arose, sweeping Curdken's hat off his head and carrying it far over the hills, compelling him to chase after it.
By the time Curdken managed to retrieve his hat and return, the princess had finished combing and curling her hair, securing it safely again.

events.text_segment:
Early the next morning, as she and Curdken went out through the gate, she said sorrowfully:
‘Falada, Falada, there thou hangest!’
and the head answered:
‘Bride, bride, there thou gangest!
  Alas! alas! if thy mother knew it,
  Sadly, sadly, would she rue it.’
Then they went out of the city, and drove the geese on. And when she came to the meadow, she sat down upon a bank there, and let down her waving locks of hair, which were all of pure silver; and when Curdken saw it glitter in the sun, he ran up, and would have pulled some of the locks out, but she cried:
‘Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let Curdken’s hat go!
  Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let him after it go!
  O’er hills, dales, and rocks,
  Away be it whirl’d
  Till the silvery locks
  Are all comb’d and curl’d!
Then there came a wind, so strong that it blew off Curdken’s hat; and away it flew over the hills: and he was forced to turn and run after it; till, by the time he came back, she had done combing and curling her hair, and had put it up again safe. Then he was very angry and sulky, and would not speak to her at all; but they watched the geese until it grew dark in the evening, and then drove them homewards.
The next morning, as they were going through the dark gate, the poor girl looked up at Falada’s head, and cried:
‘Falada, Falada, there thou hangest!’
and the head answered:
‘Bride, bride, there thou gangest!
  Alas! alas! if thy mother knew it,
  Sadly, sadly, would she rue it.’
Then she drove on the geese, and sat down again in the meadow, and began to comb out her hair as before; and Curdken ran up to her, and wanted to take hold of it; but she cried out quickly:
‘Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let Curdken’s hat go!
  Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let him after it go!
  O’er hills, dales, and rocks,
  Away be it whirl’d
  Till the silvery locks
  Are all comb’d and curl’d!
Then the wind came and blew away his hat; and off it flew a great way, over the hills and far away, so that he had to run after it; and when he came back she had bound up her hair again, and all was safe. So they watched the geese till it grew dark.

Curious, she pointed it out to Curdken, who looked up and said, "It might be a sign or perhaps a fairy's lantern. Let us follow it and see where it leads." Beneath its sprawling branches, they found a curious sight: a tiny door carved into the trunk, adorned with intricate patterns and a small brass handle. She hesitated, then gently pushed the door open. Inside, they discovered a cozy little room filled with shimmering treasures—gems, gold coins, and beautiful trinkets. events.title: Curdken's Complaint Leads to the Old King's Secret Investigation and Confrontation
detailed_summary: Upon their return home in the evening, Curdken approached the old king, stating he could no longer tolerate working with the 'strange girl' to keep the geese.
When the king inquired why, Curdken explained that instead of helping, she did nothing but tease him throughout the day.
The king then prompted Curdken to recount what had happened.

Curdken described their morning passage through the dark gate, where the girl would cry out and converse with a horse's head mounted on the wall, which would then reply, and he recited their typical exchange.

He continued, detailing the events in the meadow where the geese fed: how his hat was blown away, forcing him to run after it and leave the flock unattended, all because she was interacting with her hair.
The old king, however, instructed the boy to go out with her again the next day.
The following morning, the king secretly positioned himself behind the dark gate and personally heard her speak to Falada's head and Falada's subsequent response.
He then proceeded to the field and concealed himself in a bush by the meadow's edge.
There, he soon witnessed with his own eyes how they drove the flock of geese, how after a short while she let down her hair that glittered in the sun, and then he heard her recite her magical verses.
A strong gust of wind immediately carried away Curdken's hat, and Curdken ran after it, while the girl continued combing and curling her hair.
Having seen all this, the old king returned home without being detected.

When the little goose-girl came back in the evening, he called her aside and asked her why she engaged in such behaviors, but she burst into tears and declared that she must not reveal this to him or any man, for doing so would cost her her life.

events.text_segment:
In the evening, after they came home, Curdken went to the old king, and said, ‘I cannot have that strange girl to help me to keep the geese any longer.’ ‘Why?’ said the king. ‘Because, instead of doing any good, she does nothing but tease me all day long.’ Then the king made him tell him what had happened. And Curdken said, ‘When we go in the morning through the dark gate with our flock of geese, she cries and talks with the head of a horse that hangs upon the wall, and says:
‘Falada, Falada, there thou hangest!’
and the head answers:
‘Bride, bride, there thou gangest!
  Alas! alas! if thy mother knew it,
  Sadly, sadly, would she rue it.’
And Curdken went on telling the king what had happened upon the meadow where the geese fed; how his hat was blown away; and how he was forced to run after it, and to leave his flock of geese to themselves. But the old king told the boy to go out again the next day: and when morning came, he placed himself behind the dark gate, and heard how she spoke to Falada, and how Falada answered. Then he went into the field, and hid himself in a bush by the meadow’s side; and he soon saw with his own eyes how they drove the flock of geese; and how, after a little time, she let down her hair that glittered in the sun. And then he heard her say:
‘Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let Curdken’s hat go!
  Blow, breezes, blow!
  Let him after it go!
  O’er hills, dales, and rocks,
  Away be it whirl’d
  Till the silvery locks
  Are all comb’d and curl’d!
And soon came a gale of wind, and carried away Curdken’s hat, and away went Curdken after it, while the girl went on combing and curling her hair. All this the old king saw: so he went home without being seen; and when the little goose-girl came back in the evening he called her aside, and asked her why she did so: but she burst into tears, and said, ‘That I must not tell you or any man, or I shall lose my life.’

And so, they lived happily, their lives enriched by understanding and love, reminding all that true nobility comes from within.

events.title: The Goose-Girl Reveals Her True Story, is Recognized, and the King Plans a Public Revelation
detailed_summary: The old king persisted with his gentle entreaties, giving the goose-girl no peace until she finally recounted her entire story to him, from the very beginning to the end, word for word.
Her decision to confide in him proved to be very fortunate, as upon hearing her tale, the king immediately ordered that royal clothes be brought for her.
He gazed upon her with wonder, marveling at her beauty, now fully apparent in her proper attire.

The king then summoned his son, the young king, and revealed to him that he had been deceived: the woman he believed to be his bride was merely a waiting-maid, while the true bride stood there before them.
The young king rejoiced immensely upon seeing her beauty and hearing of her gentle and patient nature.
Without alerting the false bride to these developments, the old king commanded that a great feast be prepared for the entire court.

At the feast, the bridegroom was seated at the head of the table, with the false princess on one side and the true princess on the other; however, no one recognized the true princess, as her beauty was quite dazzling to their eyes, and she seemed entirely different from the little goose-girl now that she wore her brilliant dress.

Then he called his son and told him that he had only a false bride; for that she was merely a waiting-maid, while the true bride stood by. And the young king rejoiced when he saw her beauty, and heard how meek and patient she had been; and without saying anything to the false bride, the king ordered a great feast to be got ready for all his court. The bridegroom sat at the top, with the false princess on one side, and the true one on the other; but nobody knew her again, for her beauty was quite dazzling to their eyes; and she did not seem at all like the little goose-girl, now that she had her brilliant dress on.

events.title: The Imposter's Self-Condemnation, the True Couple's Marriage, and Falada's Restoration
detailed_summary: Once everyone had eaten and drunk and were in high spirits, the old king announced he would tell them a tale.
He then proceeded to narrate the entire story of the princess's ordeals, presenting it as if it were a story he had once heard.
Upon concluding, he turned to the true waiting-maid (the imposter bride) and asked her what she believed would be an appropriate punishment for someone who would behave in such a treacherous manner.

The false bride, oblivious to her own impending doom, declared that such a person deserved nothing better than to be thrown into a cask studded all around with sharp nails, and then have two white horses drag the cask from street to street until she was dead.
The old king then solemnly declared, 'Thou art she! And as thou has judged thyself, so shall it be done to thee.'
Following this judgment, the young king was married to his true wife, and they reigned together over the kingdom in peace and happiness for all their lives.
The good fairy later came to visit them and, in a final act of benevolence, restored the faithful Falada to life again.

She, unaware of her impending doom, declared that she deserved to be thrown into a cask studded with sharp nails, and then dragged through the streets by two white horses until she perished. The old king then declared solemnly, 'Thou art she! And as thou hast judged thyself, so shall it be done to thee.' After this, the young king married his true bride, and they ruled peacefully and happily. Later, the good fairy visited them and, in a final act of kindness, restored Falada, the faithful horse, to life.

chapters.chapter_title: THE ADVENTURES OF CHANTICLEER AND PARTLET

events.title: A Journey to the Mountains and a Forced Cart Driver
detailed_summary: Chanticleer suggests to his wife Partlet that they go to the mountains to eat ripe nuts before the squirrel gets them all, and Partlet agrees.
They spend a lovely day in the mountains and stay until evening.
Having eaten so many nuts, or perhaps due to laziness, they decide against walking home.
Chanticleer constructs a small carriage from nutshells.
Partlet gets into the carriage and tells Chanticleer to harness himself and pull her home.
Chanticleer refuses, stating he would rather walk, but offers to be the coachman if Partlet pulls, an offer which is implicitly rejected.
A duck appears, quacking angrily and accusing them of trespassing on her grounds.
The duck attacks Chanticleer.
Chanticleer, being brave, retaliates effectively with his spurs, forcing the duck to beg for mercy.
Mercy is granted on the condition that the duck pulls their carriage home.
The duck agrees, Chanticleer gets on the box as coachman, and they set off at a good speed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ‘The nuts are quite ripe now,’ said Chanticleer to his wife Partlet, ‘suppose we go together to the mountains, and eat as many as we can, before the squirrel takes them all away.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And away they went at a pretty good pace.

events.text_segment:
‘The nuts are quite ripe now,’ said Chanticleer to his wife Partlet, ‘suppose we go together to the mountains, and eat as many as we can, before the squirrel takes them all away.’ ‘With all my heart,’ said Partlet, ‘let us go and make a holiday of it together.’
So they went to the mountains; and as it was a lovely day, they stayed there till the evening. Now, whether it was that they had eaten so many nuts that they could not walk, or whether they were lazy and would not, I do not know: however, they took it into their heads that it did not become them to go home on foot. So Chanticleer began to build a little carriage of nutshells: and when it was finished, Partlet jumped into it and sat down, and bid Chanticleer harness himself to it and draw her home. ‘That’s a good joke!’ said Chanticleer; ‘no, that will never do; I had rather by half walk home; I’ll sit on the box and be coachman, if you like, but I’ll not draw.’ While this was passing, a duck came quacking up and cried out, ‘You thieving vagabonds, what business have you in my grounds? I’ll give it you well for your insolence!’ and upon that she fell upon Chanticleer most lustily. But Chanticleer was no coward, and returned the duck’s blows with his sharp spurs so fiercely that she soon began to cry out for mercy; which was only granted her upon condition that she would draw the carriage home for them. This she agreed to do; and Chanticleer got upon the box, and drove, crying, ‘Now, duck, get on as fast as you can.’ And away they went at a pretty good pace.

After having eaten so many nuts, or perhaps because they felt too lazy to walk back, they decided not to go home on foot. Chanticleer then made a little carriage from nutshells, and Partlet got into it, telling Chanticleer to harness himself and pull her home.

Chanticleer refused, saying he would rather walk, but he offered to be the coachman if Partlet pulled the carriage herself, an offer she implicitly declined. Suddenly, a duck appeared, quacking angrily and accusing them of trespassing on her grounds. The duck attacked Chanticleer, but being brave, he fought back with his spurs, making the duck beg for mercy.

Mercy was granted on the condition that the duck would pull their carriage home. The duck agreed, Chanticleer took his place on the box as coachman, and they set off at a good speed.
