events.title: Acquiring New Passengers and Reaching the Inn
detailed_summary: While travelling, they encounter a needle and a pin walking together.
The needle calls for them to stop, explaining it's very dark, the path is muddy, and they can hardly see.
The needle recounts that he and the pin had been drinking at a public-house and lost track of time.
He requests a ride in their carriage for himself and the pin.
Chanticleer, seeing they are thin and won't take up much space, agrees to give them a lift.
He makes them promise not to dirty the carriage wheels or step on Partlet’s toes.
Late at night, they arrive at an inn.
Deciding it's too difficult to travel in the dark and noting the duck's exhaustion (as it waddled significantly), they decide to stay at the inn.
The landlord is initially reluctant, saying his inn is full, suspecting they might not be respectable guests.
However, they speak politely to him and offer him an egg Partlet laid en route, and also promise him the duck, mentioning its habit of laying an egg daily.
Persuaded, the landlord allows them in; they order a fine supper and enjoy a merry evening.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After they had travelled along a little way, they met a needle and a pin walking together along the road: and the needle cried out, ‘Stop, stop!’ and said it was so dark that they could hardly find their way, and such dirty walking they could not get on at all: he told them that he and his friend, the pin, had been at a public-house a few miles off, and had sat drinking till they had forgotten how late it was; he begged therefore that the travellers would be so kind as to give them a lift in their carriage.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: so at last he let them come in, and they bespoke a handsome supper, and spent the evening very jollily.

events.text_segment:
After they had travelled along a little way, they met a needle and a pin walking together along the road: and the needle cried out, ‘Stop, stop!’ and said it was so dark that they could hardly find their way, and such dirty walking they could not get on at all: he told them that he and his friend, the pin, had been at a public-house a few miles off, and had sat drinking till they had forgotten how late it was; he begged therefore that the travellers would be so kind as to give them a lift in their carriage. Chanticleer observing that they were but thin fellows, and not likely to take up much room, told them they might ride, but made them promise not to dirty the wheels of the carriage in getting in, nor to tread on Partlet’s toes.
Late at night they arrived at an inn; and as it was bad travelling in the dark, and the duck seemed much tired, and waddled about a good deal from one side to the other, they made up their minds to fix their quarters there: but the landlord at first was unwilling, and said his house was full, thinking they might not be very respectable company: however, they spoke civilly to him, and gave him the egg which Partlet had laid by the way, and said they would give him the duck, who was in the habit of laying one every day: so at last he let them come in, and they bespoke a handsome supper, and spent the evening very jollily.

events.title: Morning Mischief and Stealthy Departure
detailed_summary: Very early the next morning, before daylight and while everyone else in the inn is asleep, Chanticleer wakes Partlet.
They retrieve the egg they had given the landlord, peck a hole in it, eat it, and discard the shells into the fireplace.
They then approach the pin and needle, who are sound asleep.
They seize the pin and needle by their heads and stick one into the landlord's easy chair and the other into his handkerchief.
After completing their mischief, Chanticleer and Partlet sneak away as quietly as possible.
The duck, who was sleeping outside in the yard, hears them leaving.
The duck jumps into a nearby brook and swims away, out of their reach.

events.title: The Innkeeper's Painful Discoveries and Vow
detailed_summary: About an hour or two later, the landlord gets up.
He takes his handkerchief to wipe his face but is pricked by the pin hidden within it.
He then goes to the kitchen to light his pipe at the fire.
When he stirs the fire, the eggshells (left by Chanticleer and Partlet) fly into his eyes, nearly blinding him.
The landlord exclaims in distress, feeling as if the entire world is conspiring against his head that morning.
Still upset, he throws himself sulkily into his easy chair.
He is then painfully pricked by the needle hidden in the chair, with the pain not being in his head this time.
Enraged, and suspecting the guests from the previous night, he goes to find them but discovers they have all left.
He furiously swears never again to accommodate such a group of troublemakers, who consumed much, paid nothing, and only left behind their malicious pranks as 'thanks'.

He now flew into a very great passion, and, suspecting the company who had come in the night before, he went to look after them, but they were all off; so he swore that he never again would take in such a troop of vagabonds, who ate a great deal, paid no reckoning, and gave him nothing for his trouble but their apish tricks.

events.title: A New Carriage and a Growing Entourage for Mr. Korbes's Visit
detailed_summary: On another occasion, Chanticleer and Partlet wanted to go for a ride together.
Chanticleer constructed an impressive carriage equipped with four red wheels and harnessed six mice to pull it.
He and Partlet then boarded the carriage and set off.
Shortly after, they encountered a cat, who inquired about their destination.
Chanticleer poetically replied that they were on their way to visit Mr. Korbes, the fox.
The cat asked to accompany them.
Chanticleer agreed willingly, instructing the cat to get up behind and to be careful not to fall off.
He then gave a rhyming command, urging care for his coach and wheels, and readiness from the mice, as they journeyed to Mr. Korbes.
Soon after, a millstone, an egg, a duck, and a pin also approached, and Chanticleer permitted all of them to join the group in the carriage for the visit.

events.text_segment:
Another day, Chanticleer and Partlet wished to ride out together; so Chanticleer built a handsome carriage with four red wheels, and harnessed six mice to it; and then he and Partlet got into the carriage, and away they drove. Soon afterwards a cat met them, and said, ‘Where are you going?’ And Chanticleer replied,
‘All on our way
  A visit to pay
  To Mr Korbes, the fox, today.’
Then the cat said, ‘Take me with you,’ Chanticleer said, ‘With all my heart: get up behind, and be sure you do not fall off.’
‘Take care of this handsome coach of mine,
  Nor dirty my pretty red wheels so fine!
  Now, mice, be ready,
  And, wheels, run steady!
  For we are going a visit to pay
  To Mr Korbes, the fox, today.’
Soon after came up a millstone, an egg, a duck, and a pin; and Chanticleer gave them all leave to get into the carriage and go with them.

events.title: Arrival at Mr. Korbes's Empty House and Setting a Trap
detailed_summary: Upon reaching Mr. Korbes's house, they discovered he was not present.
The mice guided the carriage into the coach-house.
Chanticleer and Partlet flew up to rest on a beam.
The cat settled down in the fireplace.
The duck found a spot in the washing cistern.
The pin embedded itself in the bed pillow.
The millstone positioned itself above the house door.
The egg concealed itself by rolling up within a towel.

events.title: Mr. Korbes's Fatal Welcome Home
detailed_summary: When Mr. Korbes returned home, he went to the fireplace intending to start a fire.
However, the cat, hidden there, threw all the ashes into his eyes.
Mr. Korbes then rushed to the kitchen to wash his face.
There, the duck splashed all the water into his face.
As he attempted to dry himself with a towel, the egg, hidden within, broke, smearing its contents all over his face and eyes.
Infuriated by these events, Mr. Korbes decided to skip supper and go straight to bed.
But as he laid his head on the pillow, the pin stuck into his cheek.
This made him completely furious; he jumped up and tried to flee the house.
As he reached the door, the millstone, positioned above, fell down onto his head, killing him instantly.

events.title: Partlet's Fatal Greed and Chanticleer's Desperate Quest for Water
detailed_summary: On another occasion, Chanticleer and Partlet decided to return to the mountains for nuts, agreeing to share their findings equally.
Partlet discovered an exceptionally large nut but chose not to tell Chanticleer, keeping it for herself.
The nut was so large that she couldn't swallow it, and it became lodged in her throat.
Terrified, she cried out to Chanticleer, begging him to run quickly and fetch water to prevent her from choking.
Chanticleer ran as fast as possible to the river, pleading for water for Partlet, who was on the mountain choking on a large nut.
The river instructed him to first go to a bride and ask her for a silken cord to draw the water.
Chanticleer hurried to the bride, requesting the silken cord so the river would give him water for the choking Partlet.
The bride, in turn, told him to first retrieve her garland, which was hanging on a willow in the garden.
Chanticleer ran to the garden, took the garland from the bough, and brought it to the bride.
The bride then gave him the silken cord.
He took the cord to the river, and the river provided the water.
Chanticleer carried the water to Partlet, but by then, she had already choked to death on the nut and lay completely still.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Another day Chanticleer and Partlet agreed to go again to the mountains to eat nuts; and it was settled that all the nuts which they found should be shared equally between them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: but in the meantime she was choked by the great nut, and lay quite dead, and never moved any more.

events.text_segment: Another day Chanticleer and Partlet agreed to go again to the mountains to eat nuts; and it was settled that all the nuts which they found should be shared equally between them. Now Partlet found a very large nut; but she said nothing about it to Chanticleer, and kept it all to herself: however, it was so big that she could not swallow it, and it stuck in her throat. Then she was in a great fright, and cried out to Chanticleer, ‘Pray run as fast as you can, and fetch me some water, or I shall be choked.’ Chanticleer ran as fast as he could to the river, and said, ‘River, give me some water, for Partlet lies in the mountain, and will be choked by a great nut.’ The river said, ‘Run first to the bride, and ask her for a silken cord to draw up the water.’ Chanticleer ran to the bride, and said, ‘Bride, you must give me a silken cord, for then the river will give me water, and the water I will carry to Partlet, who lies on the mountain, and will be choked by a great nut.’ But the bride said, ‘Run first, and bring me my garland that is hanging on a willow in the garden.’ Then Chanticleer ran to the garden, and took the garland from the bough where it hung, and brought it to the bride; and then the bride gave him the silken cord, and he took the silken cord to the river, and the river gave him water, and he carried the water to Partlet; but in the meantime she was choked by the great nut, and lay quite dead, and never moved any more.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: As they journeyed through the lush, green woods, Chanticleer and Partlet marveled at the beauty of the blooming flowers and the cheerful songs of the birds. They soon came upon a tall oak tree laden with a bounty of ripe nuts. Excited, they began to gather the nuts, each carefully collecting as many as they could carry. When they had filled their baskets, they sat down beneath the shade of the tree to divide their treasure. Chanticleer suggested they split the nuts equally, so they could both enjoy the fruits of their labor. As they began to share, a wise old owl, who had been watching from a nearby branch, hooted softly and said, 'Remember, friends, that sharing is the true treasure. When you divide your nuts fairly, you not only enjoy the bounty but also strengthen your friendship.' Chanticleer and Partlet listened carefully and nodded in agreement. They divided the nuts into two equal parts, each taking their share happily. After their meal, they continued their adventure, feeling grateful for the day's bounty and the lesson learned about fairness and friendship. As they made their way home, they sang cheerful songs, their hearts full of joy and their minds eager for the next adventure. From that day on, they always remembered the wise owl's words and shared everything they found, knowing that kindness and fairness made their friendship even stronger.

events.title: Partlet's Funeral Procession Begins
detailed_summary: Chanticleer was overcome with sorrow and wept intensely.
All the beasts of the area gathered and mourned with him over Partlet's death.
Six mice constructed a small hearse to transport Partlet to her grave.
Once the hearse was ready, the mice harnessed themselves to it, and Chanticleer drove them.
During their journey, they encountered the fox.
The fox inquired where Chanticleer was going, and Chanticleer replied he was going to bury Partlet.
The fox asked if he could join them.
Chanticleer agreed but stipulated that the fox must get up behind, as his 'horses' (the mice) wouldn't be able to pull his weight otherwise.
The fox complied, and soon after, the wolf, the bear, the goat, and all the other animals of the wood arrived and also climbed onto the hearse.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then Chanticleer was very sorry, and cried bitterly; and all the beasts came and wept with him over poor Partlet.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the fox got up behind; and presently the wolf, the bear, the goat, and all the beasts of the wood, came and climbed upon the hearse.

events.text_segment: Then Chanticleer was very sorry, and cried bitterly; and all the beasts came and wept with him over poor Partlet. And six mice built a little hearse to carry her to her grave; and when it was ready they harnessed themselves before it, and Chanticleer drove them. On the way they met the fox. ‘Where are you going, Chanticleer?’ said he. ‘To bury my Partlet,’ said the other. ‘May I go with you?’ said the fox. ‘Yes; but you must get up behind, or my horses will not be able to draw you.’ Then the fox got up behind; and presently the wolf, the bear, the goat, and all the beasts of the wood, came and climbed upon the hearse.

events.title: Tragedy at the Stream and Chanticleer's Final Demise
detailed_summary: The funeral procession continued until they reached a swiftly flowing stream.
Chanticleer wondered how they would cross.
A straw offered to lay itself across the stream for them to pass over.
However, as the mice were crossing, the straw slipped and fell into the water, causing all six mice to fall in and drown.
Faced with this dilemma, a large log of wood appeared, declaring itself big enough to serve as a bridge.
The log laid itself across the stream, but due to clumsy maneuvering, it too fell into the water and was swept away.
Then, a stone that had witnessed these events kindly offered to help by laying itself across the stream.
This time, Chanticleer managed to get safely to the other side with the hearse and retrieve Partlet's body from it.

Unfortunately, the fox and the other mourners (wolf, bear, goat, etc.) who were riding behind on the hearse were too heavy; the hearse presumably tipped or they fell, and they all tumbled into the water, were carried away by the current, and drowned.
Chanticleer was thus left entirely alone with the deceased Partlet.
He dug a grave for her, laid her in it, and created a small mound over her.
He then sat by her grave, weeping and mourning, until he eventually died as well, marking the death of everyone involved in this final story.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he sat down by the grave, and wept and mourned, till at last he died too; and so all were dead.

events.text_segment:
So on they went till they came to a rapid stream. ‘How shall we get over?’ said Chanticleer. Then said a straw, ‘I will lay myself across, and you may pass over upon me.’ But as the mice were going over, the straw slipped away and fell into the water, and the six mice all fell in and were drowned. What was to be done? Then a large log of wood came and said, ‘I am big enough; I will lay myself across the stream, and you shall pass over upon me.’ So he laid himself down; but they managed so clumsily, that the log of wood fell in and was carried away by the stream. Then a stone, who saw what had happened, came up and kindly offered to help poor Chanticleer by laying himself across the stream; and this time he got safely to the other side with the hearse, and managed to get Partlet out of it; but the fox and the other mourners, who were sitting behind, were too heavy, and fell back into the water and were all carried away by the stream and drowned.
Thus Chanticleer was left alone with his dead Partlet; and having dug a grave for her, he laid her in it, and made a little hillock over her. Then he sat down by the grave, and wept and mourned, till at last he died too; and so all were dead.

Sitting by her grave, he wept and mourned until he himself died, marking the end of all involved in this final story.

events.title: The Rampion Craving and the Fateful Bargain
detailed_summary: A husband and wife had long wished for a child without success.
Eventually, the wife became pregnant and developed an overwhelming craving for rampion she saw in a neighboring enchantress's garden.
She felt she would die if she couldn't eat it, becoming pale and miserable.
Her alarmed husband, prioritizing her health, decided to get the rampion for her, whatever the cost.
At twilight, he climbed the wall into the enchantress's garden, quickly gathered a handful of rampion, and brought it to his wife.
She immediately prepared a salad from it and ate it with great satisfaction.
The rampion tasted so exceptionally good that the next day her craving became three times stronger.
To find peace, the husband knew he had to venture into the garden again.
As he let himself down into the garden in the evening gloom, he was terrified to find the enchantress standing before him.
The enchantress angrily accused him of thievery and threatened punishment.
The husband pleaded for mercy, explaining his actions were born of necessity as his wife would have died from her longing for the rampion.
The enchantress's anger softened, and she proposed a deal: he could take all the rampion he wished, on the condition that he give her the child his wife would soon bear.
She promised to treat the child well and care for it like a mother.
In his terror, the man agreed to everything.
When the woman gave birth, the enchantress appeared immediately, named the child Rapunzel, and took her away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There were once a man and a woman who had long in vain wished for a child.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The man in his terror consented to everything, and when the woman was brought to bed, the enchantress appeared at once, gave the child the name of Rapunzel, and took it away with her.

events.text_segment: There were once a man and a woman who had long in vain wished for a child. At length the woman hoped that God was about to grant her desire. These people had a little window at the back of their house from which a splendid garden could be seen, which was full of the most beautiful flowers and herbs. It was, however, surrounded by a high wall, and no one dared to go into it because it belonged to an enchantress, who had great power and was dreaded by all the world. One day the woman was standing by this window and looking down into the garden, when she saw a bed which was planted with the most beautiful rampion (rapunzel), and it looked so fresh and green that she longed for it, she quite pined away, and began to look pale and miserable. Then her husband was alarmed, and asked: ‘What ails you, dear wife?’ ‘Ah,’ she replied, ‘if I can’t eat some of the rampion, which is in the garden behind our house, I shall die.’ The man, who loved her, thought: ‘Sooner than let your wife die, bring her some of the rampion yourself, let it cost what it will.’ At twilight, he clambered down over the wall into the garden of the enchantress, hastily clutched a handful of rampion, and took it to his wife. She at once made herself a salad of it, and ate it greedily. It tasted so good to her—so very good, that the next day she longed for it three times as much as before. If he was to have any rest, her husband must once more descend into the garden. In the gloom of evening therefore, he let himself down again; but when he had clambered down the wall he was terribly afraid, for he saw the enchantress standing before him. ‘How can you dare,’ said she with angry look, ‘descend into my garden and steal my rampion like a thief? You shall suffer for it!’ ‘Ah,’ answered he, ‘let mercy take the place of justice, I only made up my mind to do it out of necessity. My wife saw your rampion from the window, and felt such a longing for it that she would have died if she had not got some to eat.’ Then the enchantress allowed her anger to be softened, and said to him: ‘If the case be as you say, I will allow you to take away with you as much rampion as you will, only I make one condition, you must give me the child which your wife will bring into the world; it shall be well treated, and I will care for it like a mother.’ The man in his terror consented to everything, and when the woman was brought to bed, the enchantress appeared at once, gave the child the name of Rapunzel, and took it away with her.

events.title: Rapunzel's Tower Imprisonment
detailed_summary: Rapunzel blossomed into the most beautiful child imaginable.
Upon her twelfth birthday, the enchantress imprisoned her in a tower situated in a forest.
This tower was unique as it had no stairs or door, only a small window at its very peak.
When the enchantress wished to enter, she would position herself beneath the window and call out: ‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,  Let down your hair to me.’
Rapunzel possessed magnificent long hair, as fine as spun gold.
Upon hearing the enchantress's voice, she would unfasten her braided tresses, loop them around a window hook, and let her hair cascade twenty ells down, enabling the enchantress to climb up.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Rapunzel grew into the most beautiful child under the sun.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Rapunzel had magnificent long hair, fine as spun gold, and when she heard the voice of the enchantress she unfastened her braided tresses, wound them round one of the hooks of the window above, and then the hair fell twenty ells down, and the enchantress climbed up by it.

events.text_segment:
Rapunzel grew into the most beautiful child under the sun. When she was twelve years old, the enchantress shut her into a tower, which lay in a forest, and had neither stairs nor door, but quite at the top was a little window. When the enchantress wanted to go in, she placed herself beneath it and cried:
‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,
  Let down your hair to me.’
Rapunzel had magnificent long hair, fine as spun gold, and when she heard the voice of the enchantress she unfastened her braided tresses, wound them round one of the hooks of the window above, and then the hair fell twenty ells down, and the enchantress climbed up by it.

events.title: The Prince Discovers Rapunzel and Her Song
detailed_summary: A year or two later, a king's son chanced upon the tower while riding through the forest.
He was captivated by a charming song and paused to listen; it was Rapunzel, singing to alleviate her solitude.
The prince desired to reach her and searched for an entrance to the tower but found none.
He returned home, yet the memory of her singing deeply affected him, compelling him to visit the forest daily to hear it.
During one such visit, while concealed behind a tree, he observed an enchantress approach the tower.
He heard her call out: ‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,  Let down your hair to me.’
He then watched as Rapunzel lowered her braids, allowing the enchantress to ascend.
Realizing this was the method of entry, the prince resolved to try his luck.
The following day, as twilight approached, he went to the tower and made the same call: ‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,  Let down your hair to me.’
Instantly, the hair descended, and the king's son climbed up.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After a year or two, it came to pass that the king’s son rode through the forest and passed by the tower.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Immediately the hair fell down and the king’s son climbed up.

events.text_segment:
After a year or two, it came to pass that the king’s son rode through the forest and passed by the tower. Then he heard a song, which was so charming that he stood still and listened. This was Rapunzel, who in her solitude passed her time in letting her sweet voice resound. The king’s son wanted to climb up to her, and looked for the door of the tower, but none was to be found. He rode home, but the singing had so deeply touched his heart, that every day he went out into the forest and listened to it. Once when he was thus standing behind a tree, he saw that an enchantress came there, and he heard how she cried:
‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,
  Let down your hair to me.’
Then Rapunzel let down the braids of her hair, and the enchantress climbed up to her. ‘If that is the ladder by which one mounts, I too will try my fortune,’ said he, and the next day when it began to grow dark, he went to the tower and cried:
‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,
  Let down your hair to me.’
Immediately the hair fell down and the king’s son climbed up.

events.title: The Prince and Rapunzel's Secret Love and Escape Plan
detailed_summary: Rapunzel was initially terrified by the sight of the prince, a type of man she had never encountered before.
However, the king's son spoke to her gently, as a friend, explaining that her captivating song had stirred his heart so deeply he had no rest until he saw her.
His kind words allayed Rapunzel's fear.
When he asked her to be his wife, she considered his youth and handsome appearance and thought he would offer more love than 'old Dame Gothel' (the enchantress).
She agreed to his proposal and placed her hand in his.
Rapunzel expressed her desire to leave with him but acknowledged the challenge of escaping the tower.
She proposed a plan: he should bring a skein of silk with him on each visit, which she would use to weave a ladder.
Once the ladder was complete, she would descend, and he would carry her away on his horse.
They arranged for him to visit her every evening, as the enchantress only came during the day.

Then Rapunzel lost her fear, and when he asked her if she would take him for her husband, and she saw that he was young and handsome, she thought: ‘He will love me more than old Dame Gothel does’; and she said yes, and laid her hand in his. She said: ‘I will willingly go away with you, but I do not know how to get down. Bring with you a skein of silk every time that you come, and I will weave a ladder with it, and when that is ready I will descend, and you will take me on your horse.’ They agreed that until that time he should come to her every evening, for the old woman came by day.

events.title: Discovery of the Secret and Rapunzel's Banishment
detailed_summary: The enchantress remained unaware of these developments for some time.
However, Rapunzel inadvertently revealed the secret one day.
She asked Dame Gothel why she was so much heavier to pull up the tower compared to the young king's son, who ascended in an instant.
The enchantress reacted with outrage, exclaiming at Rapunzel's wickedness and perceived betrayal.
She lamented that despite her efforts to isolate Rapunzel from the world, she had been deceived.
In a fit of anger, she seized Rapunzel's beautiful hair, wrapped it twice around her left hand, took a pair of scissors, and cut off the braids, which fell to the ground.
Her cruelty extended further as she then transported poor Rapunzel to a desert, condemning her to a life of profound grief and misery.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The enchantress remarked nothing of this, until once Rapunzel said to her: ‘Tell me, Dame Gothel, how it happens that you are so much heavier for me to draw up than the young king’s son—he is with me in a moment.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And she was so pitiless that she took poor Rapunzel into a desert where she had to live in great grief and misery.

events.text_segment: The enchantress remarked nothing of this, until once Rapunzel said to her: ‘Tell me, Dame Gothel, how it happens that you are so much heavier for me to draw up than the young king’s son—he is with me in a moment.’ ‘Ah! you wicked child,’ cried the enchantress. ‘What do I hear you say! I thought I had separated you from all the world, and yet you have deceived me!’ In her anger she clutched Rapunzel’s beautiful tresses, wrapped them twice round her left hand, seized a pair of scissors with the right, and snip, snap, they were cut off, and the lovely braids lay on the ground. And she was so pitiless that she took poor Rapunzel into a desert where she had to live in great grief and misery.

events.title: The Enchantress's Deception and the Prince's Blinding
detailed_summary: On the same day she exiled Rapunzel, the enchantress took the severed braids of hair and attached them to the window hook.
When the king's son arrived and called out the familiar request for Rapunzel to let down her hair.
The enchantress lowered the cut braids.
The king's son climbed up, only to be met not by his beloved Rapunzel, but by the enchantress, who glared at him with malicious and poisonous looks.
She taunted him, saying his 'dearest' was gone, like a bird flown from its nest, and that the 'cat' (herself) had taken it and would also harm him.
She declared that Rapunzel was lost to him forever and he would never see her again.
Overcome with immense pain and despair, the king's son leaped from the tower.
He survived the fall, but the thorns he landed in pierced his eyes, leaving him blind.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He escaped with his life, but the thorns into which he fell pierced his eyes.

events.text_segment:
On the same day that she cast out Rapunzel, however, the enchantress fastened the braids of hair, which she had cut off, to the hook of the window, and when the king’s son came and cried:
 ‘Rapunzel, Rapunzel,
  Let down your hair to me.’
she let the hair down. The king’s son ascended, but instead of finding his dearest Rapunzel, he found the enchantress, who gazed at him with wicked and venomous looks. ‘Aha!’ she cried mockingly, ‘you would fetch your dearest, but the beautiful bird sits no longer singing in the nest; the cat has got it, and will scratch out your eyes as well. Rapunzel is lost to you; you will never see her again.’ The king’s son was beside himself with pain, and in his despair he leapt down from the tower. He escaped with his life, but the thorns into which he fell pierced his eyes.

events.title: Years of Suffering, Reunion, and Joyful Restoration
detailed_summary: The prince, now blind, wandered aimlessly through the forest for several years.
He subsisted on nothing but roots and berries, his existence consumed by lamentation and weeping over the loss of his dearest Rapunzel.
After years of miserable roaming, he eventually found himself in the desert where Rapunzel had been banished.
She was living in wretchedness with their twin children, a boy and a girl, to whom she had given birth.
He heard a voice that sounded deeply familiar and moved towards its source.
Upon his approach, Rapunzel recognized him.
She embraced him and wept on his neck.
Two of her tears fell upon his eyes, miraculously clearing them and restoring his sight to what it was before.
He then led Rapunzel and their children to his kingdom, where they received a joyful welcome.
They lived together for a long time thereafter, in happiness and contentment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then he wandered quite blind about the forest, ate nothing but roots and berries, and did naught but lament and weep over the loss of his dearest wife.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He led her to his kingdom where he was joyfully received, and they lived for a long time afterwards, happy and contented.

events.text_segment: Then he wandered quite blind about the forest, ate nothing but roots and berries, and did naught but lament and weep over the loss of his dearest wife. Thus he roamed about in misery for some years, and at length came to the desert where Rapunzel, with the twins to which she had given birth, a boy and a girl, lived in wretchedness. He heard a voice, and it seemed so familiar to him that he went towards it, and when he approached, Rapunzel knew him and fell on his neck and wept. Two of her tears wetted his eyes and they grew clear again, and he could see with them as before. He led her to his kingdom where he was joyfully received, and they lived for a long time afterwards, happy and contented.

events.title: The Forester's Discovery and Fundevogel's Upbringing
detailed_summary: A forester, while engaged in hunting, was drawn by the sound of a child's screams emanating from the forest.
He discovered the child situated high up in a tree.
It was revealed that the child's mother had dozed off, allowing a bird of prey to seize the child from her arms and deposit it onto the tall tree.
The forester successfully retrieved the child from the tree.
He resolved to bring the child to his home, intending for the child to be raised alongside his own daughter, Lina.
The discovered child was given the name Fundevogel, a name reflecting that a bird had carried him.
Fundevogel and Lina cultivated a deep and loving bond, experiencing sadness whenever they were not in each other's presence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once a forester who went into the forest to hunt, and as he entered it he heard a sound of screaming as if a little child were there.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Fundevogel and Lina loved each other so dearly that when they did not see each other they were sad.

events.text_segment:
There was once a forester who went into the forest to hunt, and as he entered it he heard a sound of screaming as if a little child were there. He followed the sound, and at last came to a high tree, and at the top of this a little child was sitting, for the mother had fallen asleep under the tree with the child, and a bird of prey had seen it in her arms, had flown down, snatched it away, and set it on the high tree.
The forester climbed up, brought the child down, and thought to himself: ‘You will take him home with you, and bring him up with your Lina.’ He took it home, therefore, and the two children grew up together. And the one, which he had found on a tree was called Fundevogel, because a bird had carried it away. Fundevogel and Lina loved each other so dearly that when they did not see each other they were sad.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: There was once a forester who went into the forest to hunt, and as he entered it he heard a sound of screaming as if a little child were there. Curious and concerned, he followed the noise and soon discovered a small child sitting high up in a tree, crying and frightened. The child’s mother had fallen asleep nearby, and a bird of prey had swooped down, snatched the child from her arms, and carried him up into the branches of the tall tree. The forester quickly climbed up and rescued the child, bringing him down safely. He decided to take the child home with him, intending to raise him alongside his own daughter, Lina. They named the child Fundevogel, meaning 'bird's little boy,' because a bird had carried him away. Fundevogel and Lina grew up together, forming a close and loving bond, and they were always sad when they were apart.

The forester's kindness was remembered by all in the village, and he was praised for his good heart.

events.title: The Cook's Sinister Plot Revealed to Lina
detailed_summary: The forester had in his employ an elderly cook.
One evening, this cook repeatedly carried pails of water from the spring, a task she performed multiple times.
Lina observed this unusual activity and questioned the cook, Sanna, about the reason for fetching so much water.
Sanna consented to explain, but only if Lina promised never to disclose the information to anyone.
Lina gave her word that she would maintain secrecy.

The cook then revealed her gruesome intention: the following morning, while the forester was away on his hunt, she planned to heat the water and, once it was boiling in the kettle, to throw Fundevogel in and boil him.

events.title: Lina and Fundevogel's Vow and Escape
detailed_summary: The next morning, after the forester had risen and departed for his hunting trip, the children remained in their beds.
Lina addressed Fundevogel, proposing a pact: if he vowed never to leave her, she too would never leave him.
Fundevogel solemnly promised, affirming his loyalty then and for all time.
Following this exchange of vows, Lina disclosed the cook's dreadful plan, explaining that Sanna's numerous trips for water were in preparation to boil Fundevogel when their father was absent.
Lina insisted that they must act swiftly, get dressed, and escape together.
Consequently, the two children rose, quickly dressed themselves, and departed from the house.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The two children therefore got up, dressed themselves quickly, and went away.

events.text_segment:
Early next morning the forester got up and went out hunting, and when he was gone the children were still in bed. Then Lina said to Fundevogel: ‘If you will never leave me, I too will never leave you.’ Fundevogel said: ‘Neither now, nor ever will I leave you.’ Then said Lina: ‘Then will I tell you. Last night, old Sanna carried so many buckets of water into the house that I asked her why she was doing that, and she said that if I would promise not to tell anyone, and she said that early tomorrow morning when father was out hunting, she would set the kettle full of water, throw you into it and boil you; but we will get up quickly, dress ourselves, and go away together.’
The two children therefore got up, dressed themselves quickly, and went away.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Early next morning the forester got up and went out hunting, and when he was gone the children were still in bed. Lina addressed Fundevogel, proposing a pact: if he vowed never to leave her, she too would never leave him. Fundevogel solemnly promised, affirming his loyalty then and for all time. Following this exchange of vows, Lina disclosed the cook's dreadful plan, explaining that Sanna's numerous trips for water were in preparation to boil Fundevogel when their father was absent. Lina insisted that they must act swiftly, get dressed, and escape together. Consequently, the two children rose, quickly dressed themselves, and departed from the house.

She whispered softly to the children, telling them of a hidden treasure deep in the forest, guarded by a wise old owl. The children, eager for adventure, decided to follow her guidance. They tiptoed out of bed, dressed quickly, and tiptoed past their sleeping parents. As they entered the forest, the fairy led them along a secret path lined with blooming flowers and singing birds. Overjoyed, they thanked the fairy and hurried home, their hearts full of wonder and happiness.

events.title: The Cook's Fury and the Pursuit Begins
detailed_summary: When the water in the kettle reached a boil, the cook proceeded to the bedroom to retrieve Fundevogel with the intention of putting him in it.
However, upon entering the room and approaching the beds, she discovered that both children had vanished.
This realization caused her immense alarm.
She began to worry about how she would explain the children's absence to the forester upon his return.
She concluded that the children needed to be pursued without delay to bring them back.
As a result, the cook dispatched three servants, instructing them to run and catch up with the children.

events.text_segment:
When the water in the kettle was boiling, the cook went into the bedroom to fetch Fundevogel and throw him into it. But when she came in, and went to the beds, both the children were gone. Then she was terribly alarmed, and she said to herself: ‘What shall I say now when the forester comes home and sees that the children are gone? They must be followed instantly to get them back again.’
Then the cook sent three servants after them, who were to run and overtake the children.

events.title: The First Magical Transformation: Rose-Bush and Rose
detailed_summary: The children, who were situated outside the forest, observed the three servants running towards them from a distance.
Lina once again asked Fundevogel to pledge never to leave her, a promise he readily affirmed.
Lina then proposed their first magical defense: Fundevogel should transform into a rose-tree, and she would become a rose on its branches.
When the three servants arrived at that location in the forest, they found only a rose-tree bearing a single rose; the children were nowhere in sight.
Concluding their search was futile, they returned to the cook and reported seeing nothing but a small rose-bush with one rose.
The old cook reacted with anger, berating them as simpletons for not having cut the rose-bush and brought the rose back with them.
She then commanded them to go out again and carry out this task.

events.text_segment: The children, however, were sitting outside the forest, and when they saw from afar the three servants running, Lina said to Fundevogel: ‘Never leave me, and I will never leave you.’ Fundevogel said: ‘Neither now, nor ever.’ Then said Lina: ‘Do you become a rose-tree, and I the rose upon it.’ When the three servants came to the forest, nothing was there but a rose-tree and one rose on it, but the children were nowhere. Then said they: ‘There is nothing to be done here,’ and they went home and told the cook that they had seen nothing in the forest but a little rose-bush with one rose on it. Then the old cook scolded and said: ‘You simpletons, you should have cut the rose-bush in two, and have broken off the rose and brought it home with you; go, and do it at once.’ They had therefore to go out and look for the second time.

events.title: The Second Magical Transformation: Church and Chandelier
detailed_summary: From a distance, the children again spotted the servants approaching.
Lina and Fundevogel reaffirmed their mutual pledge of loyalty.
Lina then suggested a new transformation: Fundevogel was to become a church, and she would be the chandelier within it.
Upon reaching the spot, the three servants found only a church containing a chandelier; there was no trace of the children.
They conferred amongst themselves, decided there was nothing more they could accomplish, and opted to return home.
When they arrived, the cook asked if they had located the children.
They replied that they had found nothing except a church with a chandelier inside.
The cook flew into a rage, scolding them as fools and questioning why they hadn't dismantled the church and brought the chandelier home.

events.title: The Final Transformation and the Witch's Defeat
detailed_summary: At this point, the old cook herself got up and, along with the three servants, went in pursuit of the children.
The children, from afar, observed the three servants approaching, with the cook laboriously following them.
Lina and Fundevogel once more exchanged their vows of unwavering loyalty.
Lina then proposed their next transformation: Fundevogel should become a fishpond, and she would be a duck upon its surface.
The cook arrived at their location, and upon seeing the pond, she lay down beside it, intending to drink all the water.
However, the duck (Lina) swam to her swiftly, grabbed the cook's head with its beak, and pulled her into the water, where the old witch subsequently drowned.

events.title: Seven at One Stroke: The Tailor's Accidental Feat and Bold Proclamation
detailed_summary: A little tailor, while sewing with enthusiasm, hears a peasant woman selling jams.
He calls her up and, after inspecting her wares, buys a very small quantity of jam, much to the woman's displeasure as she had hoped for a larger sale.
The tailor anticipates enjoying the jam on bread but decides to complete his current sewing project, a jacket, before eating.
While he sews, the aroma of the jam attracts a large number of flies, which begin to settle on it.
Initially, the tailor tries to shoo them away, but the flies, undeterred, return in greater numbers.
Losing his patience, the tailor takes a piece of cloth and strikes the swarm of flies.
Upon counting, he discovers he has killed seven flies with this single blow.
Immensely pleased with his own perceived bravery, he declares that the entire town, and indeed the world, must learn of his feat.
He quickly fashions a girdle and embroiders the words 'Seven at one stroke!' onto it in large letters, his heart swelling with pride.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One summer’s morning a little tailor was sitting on his table by the window; he was in good spirits, and sewed with all his might.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘What, the town!’ he continued, ‘the whole world shall hear of it!’ and his heart wagged with joy like a lamb’s tail.

events.text_segment: One summer’s morning a little tailor was sitting on his table by the window; he was in good spirits, and sewed with all his might. Then came a peasant woman down the street crying: ‘Good jams, cheap! Good jams, cheap!’ This rang pleasantly in the tailor’s ears; he stretched his delicate head out of the window, and called: ‘Come up here, dear woman; here you will get rid of your goods.’ The woman came up the three steps to the tailor with her heavy basket, and he made her unpack all the pots for him. He inspected each one, lifted it up, put his nose to it, and at length said: ‘The jam seems to me to be good, so weigh me out four ounces, dear woman, and if it is a quarter of a pound that is of no consequence.’ The woman who had hoped to find a good sale, gave him what he desired, but went away quite angry and grumbling. ‘Now, this jam shall be blessed by God,’ cried the little tailor, ‘and give me health and strength’; so he brought the bread out of the cupboard, cut himself a piece right across the loaf and spread the jam over it. ‘This won’t taste bitter,’ said he, ‘but I will just finish the jacket before I take a bite.’ He laid the bread near him, sewed on, and in his joy, made bigger and bigger stitches. In the meantime the smell of the sweet jam rose to where the flies were sitting in great numbers, and they were attracted and descended on it in hosts. ‘Hi! who invited you?’ said the little tailor, and drove the unbidden guests away. The flies, however, who understood no German, would not be turned away, but came back again in ever-increasing companies. The little tailor at last lost all patience, and drew a piece of cloth from the hole under his work-table, and saying: ‘Wait, and I will give it to you,’ struck it mercilessly on them. When he drew it away and counted, there lay before him no fewer than seven, dead and with legs stretched out. ‘Are you a fellow of that sort?’ said he, and could not help admiring his own bravery. ‘The whole town shall know of this!’ And the little tailor hastened to cut himself a girdle, stitched it, and embroidered on it in large letters: ‘Seven at one stroke!’ ‘What, the town!’ he continued, ‘the whole world shall hear of it!’ and his heart wagged with joy like a lamb’s tail.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: One summer’s morning a little tailor was sitting on his table by the window; he was in good spirits, and sewed with all his might. As he worked, he heard a street cry: 'Jam! fresh jam!' and looked out. A peasant woman was walking down the street, calling out her wares. The tailor called her up and, when she came to his door, he beckoned her to come in. She climbed the steps, and he asked her to show him her jams. She unpacked all her pots, and he examined each one carefully. 'How much do you want for this jar?' he asked, pointing to a small pot. 'A penny,' she replied. 'Then I will take a little,' said the tailor, and he measured out a small quantity of jam, which displeased the woman, for she had hoped to sell more. The tailor blessed the jam, saying it would give him health and strength, and spread some bread on his plate. He took a piece of bread, cut it, and spread the jam on it, then sat down to enjoy his treat. While he was eating, the aroma of the jam attracted a great number of flies, which began to settle on it. He tried to shoo them away, but they returned in greater numbers. At last, losing patience, he took a cloth and struck at the flies. When he looked at his hand, he saw that he had killed seven flies with one blow. He was very pleased with himself, and his heart wagged with joy. 'Seven at one stroke!' he exclaimed, and he quickly made a girdle, on which he embroidered in large letters, 'Seven at one stroke!'

Suddenly, a fly buzzed into the room and settled on the table. The little tailor, seeing it, took his scissors and, with a quick stroke, killed it. Then he looked at the blood on his cloth and exclaimed, 'Seven at one blow!' This was his boast, for he thought himself so clever that he had slain seven flies with one stroke. His boast soon spread among the townspeople, and they all marveled at his wit.

Encouraged by his reputation, the tailor decided to set out on an adventure to seek his fortune. He packed his little bag and bade farewell to his family. As he journeyed through the forest, he came upon a giant who was blocking the path.

The giant looked down at the tiny tailor and sneered, 'What do you want here, little man?' The tailor, not afraid, replied boldly, 'I am on my way to seek my fortune, and I will pass.' The giant, amused by the tiny fellow's courage, challenged him to a contest of strength.

The tailor, quick-witted, proposed, 'Let us see who can jump the farthest.' The giant agreed, and they took turns. The giant leapt a great distance, but the tailor, with a clever leap, managed to outdo him. Impressed, the giant let him pass, and the tailor continued his journey.

Further along, he encountered a castle guarded by a fierce dragon. The dragon roared and threatened to burn the castle down if anyone dared to approach. The tailor, thinking quickly, took a mirror from his pocket and held it up to the dragon. The dragon, seeing his own reflection, was so frightened that he fled.

Inside the castle, the tailor found a princess who was held captive by an evil sorcerer. Using his wit, he devised a plan to rescue her. He disguised himself as a merchant and offered the sorcerer a trade: his finest cloth for the princess's freedom. The sorcerer, deceived by the fine fabric, agreed.

The tailor freed the princess and returned her to her kingdom. His cleverness and bravery earned him great fame and a noble title. From that day on, he was known as the cleverest and bravest of all the land, and he lived happily ever after, always ready for his next adventure.

events.title: The Tailor's Cunning Triumphs Over a Giant's Might
detailed_summary: Wearing his newly embroidered girdle, the tailor decides his workshop is too confining for his newfound valor and resolves to venture into the world.
Before departing, he searches his house for provisions and finds only an old cheese and a bird caught in a thicket, both of which he puts in his pocket.
He travels boldly and without fatigue until he reaches a mountain where a large giant is sitting.
The tailor confidently addresses the giant, proposing they journey together.

The giant initially dismisses the tailor contemptuously, but upon seeing the girdle proclaiming 'Seven at one stroke,' he mistakes this for seven men killed and develops a degree of respect for the small tailor.
Wishing to test him, the giant squeezes a stone until water drips from it and challenges the tailor to do the same.
The tailor nonchalantly pulls out his soft cheese and squeezes it until the whey runs out, claiming it's child's play.
Next, the giant throws a stone so high it's barely visible.
The tailor counters by taking the bird from his pocket and throwing it into the air; the bird flies away, never to return, which the tailor presents as throwing a stone that never comes down.
Impressed, the giant then challenges the tailor to help carry a massive felled oak tree.
The tailor cleverly suggests the giant carry the trunk while he handles the 'heavier' branches and twigs. He then seats himself on a branch, letting the giant unknowingly carry both the tree and him.
When the giant tires and says he must drop the tree, the tailor quickly jumps down and pretends to have been supporting it all along, chiding the giant for his lack of strength.
Continuing together, they reach a cherry tree. The giant bends down a branch laden with ripe fruit for the tailor.
The tailor, too weak to hold the branch, is flung into the air when the giant releases it.
He quickly recovers, claiming he intentionally leaped over the tree because huntsmen were shooting nearby, thereby maintaining his facade of strength and agility before the perplexed giant.

events.text_segment:
The tailor put on the girdle, and resolved to go forth into the world, because he thought his workshop was too small for his valour. Before he went away, he sought about in the house to see if there was anything which he could take with him; however, he found nothing but an old cheese, and that he put in his pocket. In front of the door he observed a bird which had caught itself in the thicket. It had to go into his pocket with the cheese. Now he took to the road boldly, and as he was light and nimble, he felt no fatigue. The road led him up a mountain, and when he had reached the highest point of it, there sat a powerful giant looking peacefully about him. The little tailor went bravely up, spoke to him, and said: ‘Good day, comrade, so you are sitting there overlooking the wide-spread world! I am just on my way thither, and want to try my luck. Have you any inclination to go with me?’ The giant looked contemptuously at the tailor, and said: ‘You ragamuffin! You miserable creature!’
‘Oh, indeed?’ answered the little tailor, and unbuttoned his coat, and showed the giant the girdle, ‘there may you read what kind of a man I am!’ The giant read: ‘Seven at one stroke,’ and thought that they had been men whom the tailor had killed, and began to feel a little respect for the tiny fellow. Nevertheless, he wished to try him first, and took a stone in his hand and squeezed it together so that water dropped out of it. ‘Do that likewise,’ said the giant, ‘if you have strength.’ ‘Is that all?’ said the tailor, ‘that is child’s play with us!’ and put his hand into his pocket, brought out the soft cheese, and pressed it until the liquid ran out of it. ‘Faith,’ said he, ‘that was a little better, wasn’t it?’ The giant did not know what to say, and could not believe it of the little man. Then the giant picked up a stone and threw it so high that the eye could scarcely follow it. ‘Now, little mite of a man, do that likewise,’ ‘Well thrown,’ said the tailor, ‘but after all the stone came down to earth again; I will throw you one which shall never come back at all,’ and he put his hand into his pocket, took out the bird, and threw it into the air. The bird, delighted with its liberty, rose, flew away and did not come back. ‘How does that shot please you, comrade?’ asked the tailor. ‘You can certainly throw,’ said the giant, ‘but now we will see if you are able to carry anything properly.’ He took the little tailor to a mighty oak tree which lay there felled on the ground, and said: ‘If you are strong enough, help me to carry the tree out of the forest.’ ‘Readily,’ answered the little man; ‘take you the trunk on your shoulders, and I will raise up the branches and twigs; after all, they are the heaviest.’ The giant took the trunk on his shoulder, but the tailor seated himself on a branch, and the giant, who could not look round, had to carry away the whole tree, and the little tailor into the bargain: he behind, was quite merry and happy, and whistled the song: ‘Three tailors rode forth from the gate,’ as if carrying the tree were child’s play. The giant, after he had dragged the heavy burden part of the way, could go no further, and cried: ‘Hark you, I shall have to let the tree fall!’ The tailor sprang nimbly down, seized the tree with both arms as if he had been carrying it, and said to the giant: ‘You are such a great fellow, and yet cannot even carry the tree!’
They went on together, and as they passed a cherry-tree, the giant laid hold of the top of the tree where the ripest fruit was hanging, bent it down, gave it into the tailor’s hand, and bade him eat. But the little tailor was much too weak to hold the tree, and when the giant let it go, it sprang back again, and the tailor was tossed into the air with it. When he had fallen down again without injury, the giant said: ‘What is this? Have you not strength enough to hold the weak twig?’ ‘There is no lack of strength,’ answered the little tailor. ‘Do you think that could be anything to a man who has struck down seven at one blow? I leapt over the tree because the huntsmen are shooting down there in the thicket. Jump as I did, if you can do it.’ The giant made the attempt but he could not get over the tree, and remained hanging in the branches, so that in this also the tailor kept the upper hand.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
The tailor put on the girdle, and resolved to go forth into the world, because he thought his workshop was too small for his valour. Wearing his newly embroidered girdle, he searched his house for provisions and found only an old cheese and a bird caught in a thicket, which he put in his pocket. He then whistled a merry tune and set out boldly.

He traveled until he reached a mountain where a large giant was sitting. The tailor approached and said, "Good day, sir! I am a brave little tailor, and I propose we journey together." The giant looked at him contemptuously and said, "What can a tiny fellow like you do?" The tailor, showing his girdle, replied, "Seven at one stroke!" The giant, mistaking this for having slain seven men, was impressed.

The giant then challenged the tailor to squeeze a stone until water drips from it. The tailor pulled out his soft cheese, squeezed it until the whey ran out, and said, "That’s child's play!" The giant was silent, not knowing what to say.

Next, the giant threw a stone so high it was barely visible. The tailor took the bird from his pocket, threw it into the air, and the bird flew away, never to return. The tailor then said, "There goes a stone that never comes down!"

The giant, eager to test the tailor further, asked him to help carry a huge felled oak tree. The tailor suggested, "You carry the trunk, and I will take the branches and twigs." The giant agreed, and the tailor climbed onto a branch, pretending to help. When the giant tired and said he must drop the tree, the tailor quickly jumped down, seized the tree with both arms, and declared, "See how I carry it!"

They continued their journey and reached a cherry tree laden with ripe fruit. The giant bent down a branch for the tailor. The tailor, too weak to hold the branch, was flung into the air when the giant released it. He quickly recovered, claiming he had leaped over the tree to avoid the huntsmen shooting nearby, and thus maintained his strength and agility, much to the giant’s confusion.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- Early in the passage, the completion does not mention the tailor's specific search for items to take with him, only summarizing it as searching for provisions, which omits the process and the fact that he found nothing else.
- The completion lacks the detail of the tailor observing the bird in front of the door and the process of putting it in his pocket, instead combining the cheese and bird discovery.
- The completion does not include the tailor's direct speech to the giant, which is present in the original and helps characterize their interaction.
- The completion omits the giant's direct speech when he first insults the tailor, as well as the tailor's response and the act of showing the girdle.
- The completion does not include the giant's reaction of not knowing what to say after the cheese trick.
- The completion omits the detail of the tailor seizing the tree with both arms after jumping down, pretending to have carried it.
- The completion does not mention the giant's failed attempt to jump over the tree and getting stuck in the branches, which is the final demonstration of the tailor's cleverness.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately states that the tailor found both the cheese and the bird while searching the house, whereas the original separates these events and locations.
- The completion condenses and paraphrases the sequence of challenges, sometimes losing the order and nuance of the original exchanges.

- The completion summarizes the tailor's explanation after being flung by the cherry tree, but does not accurately represent the original's reasoning or the giant's subsequent attempt and failure.
- The completion sometimes merges or omits the sequence of actions and reactions, leading to a loss of the original's step-by-step progression and interplay between the characters.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He had heard of distant lands and marvelous adventures, and he longed to see them with his own eyes. As he stepped out of his humble workshop, he felt a thrill of excitement and a touch of apprehension. The sun shone brightly, and the birds sang sweet melodies, as if encouraging him on his journey.

He traveled through forests and over hills, meeting many people along the way. Some were kind and offered him food and shelter, while others were suspicious and wary of strangers. The tailor, however, remained brave and courteous, always ready to lend a helping hand or share a kind word.

One day, he came upon a village where the people were troubled by a terrible giant who had taken up residence in the mountains nearby. The giant was said to be fierce and greedy, demanding tribute from the villagers and destroying their crops. The villagers begged the tailor to help them, for they had heard of his cleverness and courage.

The tailor, moved by their plight, decided to face the giant. He thought to himself, "I may be a simple tailor, but I have wit and bravery. I will find a way to outsmart this beast." He asked the villagers if they had any clues or stories about the giant, and they told him that he was fond of riddles and puzzles.

Armed with this knowledge, the tailor devised a plan. He took with him a bag of fine needles and a spool of bright thread, which he thought might serve as tools or weapons. He climbed the mountain cautiously, keeping an eye out for the giant.

When he reached the giant's lair, he called out boldly, "Oh mighty giant, I come in peace and with a challenge!" The giant, hearing the voice, came out grumbling and eyeing the stranger suspiciously.

"What do you want, little man?" roared the giant.

"I have a riddle for you," said the tailor. "If you can solve it, I will leave you in peace. But if you cannot, you must promise not to harm the villagers anymore."

The giant, intrigued and proud, agreed to the challenge. The tailor then asked, "What is it that has keys but cannot open locks, and space but no room?"

The giant pondered, scratching his head. He guessed many things, but could not find the answer. The tailor smiled and said, "The answer is a piano."

The giant, humiliated but amused, admitted defeat. He promised to cease his depredations and to leave the villagers in peace. The tailor, pleased with his cleverness, bade farewell to the giant and returned to the village.

The villagers rejoiced and celebrated the brave tailor's success. They offered him a feast and thanked him for his courage and wit. The tailor, humble as ever, declined any reward, saying that he was happy to help.

He continued his journey, eager to see more of the world and to help those in need. His adventures took him to many places, where he used his skills and intelligence to solve problems and outwit foes.

Eventually, he returned to his workshop, but he was no longer just a simple tailor. He was a hero in the eyes of many, and his stories were told for generations. The tailor learned that even the smallest person can achieve great things with courage, cleverness, and a kind heart.

events.title: A Night in the Giants' Cave and a Narrow Escape
detailed_summary: The giant, perhaps still partly convinced of the tailor's prowess, invites him to spend the night in the giants' cave.
The tailor agrees and follows him, observing that the cave, inhabited by other giants eating roasted sheep, is much larger than his workshop.
The giant directs him to a bed, but it is far too large for the tailor, who opts to sleep in a corner instead of lying in it.
Around midnight, the giant, believing the tailor is fast asleep in the bed, gets up and smashes the bed with a great iron bar, intending to kill the 'grasshopper'.
The following morning, as the giants prepare to go into the forest, having forgotten about the tailor, he suddenly appears before them, cheerful and bold.
The giants are utterly terrified, convinced he will kill them all, and they flee in a great hurry.

events.text_segment: The giant said: ‘If you are such a valiant fellow, come with me into our cavern and spend the night with us.’ The little tailor was willing, and followed him. When they went into the cave, other giants were sitting there by the fire, and each of them had a roasted sheep in his hand and was eating it. The little tailor looked round and thought: ‘It is much more spacious here than in my workshop.’ The giant showed him a bed, and said he was to lie down in it and sleep. The bed, however, was too big for the little tailor; he did not lie down in it, but crept into a corner. When it was midnight, and the giant thought that the little tailor was lying in a sound sleep, he got up, took a great iron bar, cut through the bed with one blow, and thought he had finished off the grasshopper for good. With the earliest dawn the giants went into the forest, and had quite forgotten the little tailor, when all at once he walked up to them quite merrily and boldly. The giants were terrified, they were afraid that he would strike them all dead, and ran away in a great hurry.

events.title: A Warrior's Reputation Precedes Him: The Tailor Enters Royal Service
detailed_summary: The little tailor continues his journey, eventually arriving at the courtyard of a royal palace.
Feeling weary, he lies down on the grass and falls asleep.
While he sleeps, people from the palace gather and inspect him, noticing the inscription 'Seven at one stroke' on his girdle.
Interpreting this as a sign of a great warrior, they wonder about his presence in a time of peace and conclude he must be a mighty lord.
They report their findings to the king, suggesting that such a man would be invaluable if war were to break out and should not be allowed to leave.
The king is pleased with this counsel and dispatches one of his courtiers to offer the tailor military service when he awakens.
The courtier waits by the sleeping tailor, and upon the tailor waking and stretching, conveys the king's proposal.
The tailor replies that this was precisely his reason for coming and readily accepts the offer to enter the king's service.
Consequently, he is received with honor and assigned a special dwelling.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The little tailor went onwards, always following his own pointed nose.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was therefore honourably received, and a special dwelling was assigned him.

events.text_segment: The little tailor went onwards, always following his own pointed nose. After he had walked for a long time, he came to the courtyard of a royal palace, and as he felt weary, he lay down on the grass and fell asleep. Whilst he lay there, the people came and inspected him on all sides, and read on his girdle: ‘Seven at one stroke.’ ‘Ah!’ said they, ‘what does the great warrior want here in the midst of peace? He must be a mighty lord.’ They went and announced him to the king, and gave it as their opinion that if war should break out, this would be a weighty and useful man who ought on no account to be allowed to depart. The counsel pleased the king, and he sent one of his courtiers to the little tailor to offer him military service when he awoke. The ambassador remained standing by the sleeper, waited until he stretched his limbs and opened his eyes, and then conveyed to him this proposal. ‘For this very reason have I come here,’ the tailor replied, ‘I am ready to enter the king’s service.’ He was therefore honourably received, and a special dwelling was assigned him.

events.title: Envy, a Royal Dilemma, and the Task of Two Giants
detailed_summary: The king's soldiers quickly grow resentful of the little tailor, fearing his supposed ability to kill seven at a blow and feeling unable to stand against him if a quarrel arose.
They collectively approach the king and request their dismissal, stating they are unprepared to serve alongside such a formidable individual.
The king is dismayed at the thought of losing all his loyal servants for one man and regrets having encountered the tailor, wishing to be rid of him.
However, he dares not dismiss the tailor directly, fearing the tailor might kill him and his people and seize the throne.
After much thought, the king devises a plan. He summons the tailor and, acknowledging him as a great warrior, requests a service: to deal with two giants who cause immense destruction in a forest.
The king promises his only daughter in marriage and half his kingdom as a dowry if the tailor succeeds, also offering one hundred horsemen for assistance.
The tailor, seeing this as a magnificent opportunity, confidently accepts, boasting that he who can hit seven at one blow needs no help against two.
He sets off with the horsemen but tells them to wait at the forest's edge, claiming he will handle the giants alone.
Inside the forest, he finds both giants asleep under a tree, snoring loudly.
The tailor, having gathered two pockets full of stones, climbs the tree and positions himself above the sleeping giants.
He drops stones onto the chest of one giant, who awakens and accuses his companion of hitting him; the other denies it, and they go back to sleep.
The tailor then drops a stone on the second giant, who also wakes up and accuses the first of pelting him, leading to a dispute before they fall asleep again from weariness.
Finally, the tailor hurls his largest stone with all his might onto the chest of the first giant.
This giant springs up enraged and attacks his companion, and the two giants engage in a furious battle, tearing up trees and fighting until they both fall dead.
The tailor then descends, stabs each giant a few times with his sword, and returns to the horsemen, claiming a hard-fought victory where the giants defended themselves fiercely with uprooted trees.
When asked if he is wounded, he dismisses the concern. The skeptical horsemen ride into the forest and find the giants dead, surrounded by torn-up trees, seemingly confirming the tailor's story.

events.text_segment:
The soldiers, however, were set against the little tailor, and wished him a thousand miles away. ‘What is to be the end of this?’ they said among themselves. ‘If we quarrel with him, and he strikes about him, seven of us will fall at every blow; not one of us can stand against him.’ They came therefore to a decision, betook themselves in a body to the king, and begged for their dismissal. ‘We are not prepared,’ said they, ‘to stay with a man who kills seven at one stroke.’ The king was sorry that for the sake of one he should lose all his faithful servants, wished that he had never set eyes on the tailor, and would willingly have been rid of him again. But he did not venture to give him his dismissal, for he dreaded lest he should strike him and all his people dead, and place himself on the royal throne. He thought about it for a long time, and at last found good counsel. He sent to the little tailor and caused him to be informed that as he was a great warrior, he had one request to make to him. In a forest of his country lived two giants, who caused great mischief with their robbing, murdering, ravaging, and burning, and no one could approach them without putting himself in danger of death. If the tailor conquered and killed these two giants, he would give him his only daughter to wife, and half of his kingdom as a dowry, likewise one hundred horsemen should go with him to assist him. ‘That would indeed be a fine thing for a man like me!’ thought the little tailor. ‘One is not offered a beautiful princess and half a kingdom every day of one’s life!’ ‘Oh, yes,’ he replied, ‘I will soon subdue the giants, and do not require the help of the hundred horsemen to do it; he who can hit seven with one blow has no need to be afraid of two.’
The little tailor went forth, and the hundred horsemen followed him. When he came to the outskirts of the forest, he said to his followers: ‘Just stay waiting here, I alone will soon finish off the giants.’ Then he bounded into the forest and looked about right and left. After a while he perceived both giants. They lay sleeping under a tree, and snored so that the branches waved up and down. The little tailor, not idle, gathered two pocketsful of stones, and with these climbed up the tree. When he was halfway up, he slipped down by a branch, until he sat just above the sleepers, and then let one stone after another fall on the breast of one of the giants. For a long time the giant felt nothing, but at last he awoke, pushed his comrade, and said: ‘Why are you knocking me?’ ‘You must be dreaming,’ said the other, ‘I am not knocking you.’ They laid themselves down to sleep again, and then the tailor threw a stone down on the second. ‘What is the meaning of this?’ cried the other ‘Why are you pelting me?’ ‘I am not pelting you,’ answered the first, growling. They disputed about it for a time, but as they were weary they let the matter rest, and their eyes closed once more. The little tailor began his game again, picked out the biggest stone, and threw it with all his might on the breast of the first giant. ‘That is too bad!’ cried he, and sprang up like a madman, and pushed his companion against the tree until it shook. The other paid him back in the same coin, and they got into such a rage that they tore up trees and belaboured each other so long, that at last they both fell down dead on the ground at the same time. Then the little tailor leapt down. ‘It is a lucky thing,’ said he, ‘that they did not tear up the tree on which I was sitting, or I should have had to sprint on to another like a squirrel; but we tailors are nimble.’ He drew out his sword and gave each of them a couple of thrusts in the breast, and then went out to the horsemen and said: ‘The work is done; I have finished both of them off, but it was hard work! They tore up trees in their sore need, and defended themselves with them, but all that is to no purpose when a man like myself comes, who can kill seven at one blow.’ ‘But are you not wounded?’ asked the horsemen. ‘You need not concern yourself about that,’ answered the tailor, ‘they have not bent one hair of mine.’ The horsemen would not believe him, and rode into the forest; there they found the giants swimming in their blood, and all round about lay the torn-up trees.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
But the little tailor, quick-witted and brave, did not despair. Instead, he thought of a clever plan to turn the tables on his enemies. The little tailor, undeterred, crept closer and threw his net over the boar, trapping it. Then, with great skill, he speared the animal and secured it. He dragged the boar back to the soldiers, who were astonished to see such a small man accomplish such a mighty deed.

The little tailor, proud and triumphant, continued on his adventures, proving that wit and bravery can overcome even the greatest odds.

events.title: The King's Reluctance: Capturing a Unicorn and a Wild Boar
detailed_summary: The tailor requests his promised reward from the king, but the king, regretting his pledge, devises another task for the 'hero'.
He tells the tailor that before receiving his daughter and half the kingdom, he must capture a destructive unicorn roaming the forest.
The tailor, undaunted, states he fears a unicorn even less than two giants, as 'Seven at one blow' is his specialty.
Taking a rope and an axe, he ventures into the forest, again instructing his escorts to wait outside.
He soon encounters the unicorn, which charges directly at him.
The tailor calmly waits until the unicorn is close, then nimbly springs behind a tree.
The unicorn, unable to stop, impales the tree with its horn, becoming stuck.
The tailor declares he has 'got the bird,' emerges, puts the rope around the unicorn's neck, hews its horn from the tree with his axe, and leads the captured beast to the king.
Still reluctant, the king makes a third demand: the tailor must catch a wild boar causing great havoc in the forest, with the assistance of royal huntsmen.
The tailor agrees, calling it 'child's play,' and again declines the huntsmen's help, much to their relief as they had previous unpleasant encounters with the boar.
When the boar spots the tailor, it charges with foaming mouth and whetted tusks.
The tailor flees into a nearby chapel, jumps up to a window, and leaps out.
The boar rushes into the chapel after him, whereupon the tailor quickly runs around the outside and shuts the door, trapping the enraged beast, which is too heavy to escape through the window.
He then summons the huntsmen to witness the captured boar.
The king, now with no further recourse, is compelled to honor his promise, giving the tailor his daughter and half the kingdom.
The narrative notes that had the king known he was dealing with a mere tailor rather than a warrior, his dismay would have been even greater.
A magnificent wedding is held, though with little joy, and thus, a tailor is made into a king.
