events.title: The Dwarfs' Welcome and Snowdrop's New Home
detailed_summary: After some time, the occupants of the cottage, who are seven small dwarfs that search for gold in the mountains, return home.
They light their seven lamps and immediately notice that something is amiss.

The first dwarf asks who sat on his stool, the second who ate from his plate, the third who took his bread, the fourth who touched his spoon, the fifth who handled his fork, the sixth who cut with his knife, and the seventh who drank his wine.
Then, the first dwarf looks around and asks who has been lying on his bed.
The other dwarfs rush to him, each exclaiming that someone has been on their bed.
However, the seventh dwarf spots Snowdrop and calls his brothers to see her.
They exclaim in wonder and astonishment at her loveliness, bringing their lamps closer for a better look.
Pleased to see her, they take care not to disturb her sleep, and the seventh dwarf sleeps for an hour with each of the other dwarfs in turn until morning.
In the morning, Snowdrop shares her entire story with the dwarfs.
They feel sorry for her and propose that if she manages their household tasks like cooking, washing, knitting, and spinning, she can stay with them, and they will ensure her well-being.
The dwarfs then depart for their daily work of seeking gold and silver in the mountains, leaving Snowdrop at home.
Before leaving, they caution her that the queen will soon discover her whereabouts and advise her to be careful and not allow anyone into the cottage.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they went out all day long to their work, seeking for gold and silver in the mountains: but Snowdrop was left at home; and they warned her, and said, ‘The queen will soon find out where you are, so take care and let no one in.’

events.text_segment:
By and by in came the masters of the cottage. Now they were seven little dwarfs, that lived among the mountains, and dug and searched for gold. They lighted up their seven lamps, and saw at once that all was not right. The first said, ‘Who has been sitting on my stool?’ The second, ‘Who has been eating off my plate?’ The third, ‘Who has been picking my bread?’ The fourth, ‘Who has been meddling with my spoon?’ The fifth, ‘Who has been handling my fork?’ The sixth, ‘Who has been cutting with my knife?’ The seventh, ‘Who has been drinking my wine?’ Then the first looked round and said, ‘Who has been lying on my bed?’ And the rest came running to him, and everyone cried out that somebody had been upon his bed. But the seventh saw Snowdrop, and called all his brethren to come and see her; and they cried out with wonder and astonishment and brought their lamps to look at her, and said, ‘Good heavens! what a lovely child she is!’ And they were very glad to see her, and took care not to wake her; and the seventh dwarf slept an hour with each of the other dwarfs in turn, till the night was gone.
In the morning Snowdrop told them all her story; and they pitied her, and said if she would keep all things in order, and cook and wash and knit and spin for them, she might stay where she was, and they would take good care of her. Then they went out all day long to their work, seeking for gold and silver in the mountains: but Snowdrop was left at home; and they warned her, and said, ‘The queen will soon find out where you are, so take care and let no one in.’

events.title: The Queen's First Murder Attempt: The Laced Bodice
detailed_summary: The queen, under the impression that Snowdrop is dead, believes herself to be the most beautiful woman in the land and consults her mirror.
The mirror, however, reveals that the queen is the fairest in her immediate vicinity, but Snowdrop is hiding with the seven dwarfs over the hills and is far lovelier.
The queen is deeply frightened, knowing the mirror always speaks truth, and realizes her servant must have betrayed her.
Unable to bear the thought of someone more beautiful being alive, she disguises herself as an old pedlar woman and travels to the dwarfs' dwelling.
She knocks on the door, crying out that she has fine wares for sale.
Snowdrop looks out the window and inquires about the goods.
The disguised queen offers laces and bobbins of all colors.
Snowdrop, thinking the old woman seems kind, decides to let her in.
The old woman comments on how poorly Snowdrop's stays are laced and offers to lace them properly with one of her new, nice laces.
Snowdrop, suspecting no ill intent, stands before the old woman, who quickly and tightly pulls the lace, causing Snowdrop to lose her breath and fall as if dead.
The spiteful queen, believing Snowdrop's beauty finished, departs for home.
In the evening, the seven dwarfs return and are greatly grieved to find Snowdrop motionless on the ground.
They lift her, discover the constricting lace, cut it, and Snowdrop soon begins to breathe and revives.
The dwarfs then identify the old woman as the queen herself and warn Snowdrop again not to let anyone in when they are absent.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence:
But the queen, now that she thought Snowdrop was dead, believed that she must be the handsomest lady in the land; and she went to her glass and said:
‘Tell me, glass, tell me true!
  Of all the ladies in the land,
  Who is fairest, tell me, who?’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they said, ‘The old woman was the queen herself; take care another time, and let no one in when we are away.’

events.text_segment:
But the queen, now that she thought Snowdrop was dead, believed that she must be the handsomest lady in the land; and she went to her glass and said:
‘Tell me, glass, tell me true!
  Of all the ladies in the land,
  Who is fairest, tell me, who?’
And the glass answered:
‘Thou, queen, art the fairest in all this land:
  But over the hills, in the greenwood shade,
  Where the seven dwarfs their dwelling have made,
  There Snowdrop is hiding her head; and she
  Is lovelier far, O queen! than thee.’
Then the queen was very much frightened; for she knew that the glass always spoke the truth, and was sure that the servant had betrayed her. And she could not bear to think that anyone lived who was more beautiful than she was; so she dressed herself up as an old pedlar, and went her way over the hills, to the place where the dwarfs dwelt. Then she knocked at the door, and cried, ‘Fine wares to sell!’ Snowdrop looked out at the window, and said, ‘Good day, good woman! what have you to sell?’ ‘Good wares, fine wares,’ said she; ‘laces and bobbins of all colours.’ ‘I will let the old lady in; she seems to be a very good sort of body,’ thought Snowdrop, as she ran down and unbolted the door. ‘Bless me!’ said the old woman, ‘how badly your stays are laced! Let me lace them up with one of my nice new laces.’ Snowdrop did not dream of any mischief; so she stood before the old woman; but she set to work so nimbly, and pulled the lace so tight, that Snowdrop’s breath was stopped, and she fell down as if she were dead. ‘There’s an end to all thy beauty,’ said the spiteful queen, and went away home.
In the evening the seven dwarfs came home; and I need not say how grieved they were to see their faithful Snowdrop stretched out upon the ground, as if she was quite dead. However, they lifted her up, and when they found what ailed her, they cut the lace; and in a little time she began to breathe, and very soon came to life again. Then they said, ‘The old woman was the queen herself; take care another time, and let no one in when we are away.’

And the glass replied, 'Thou art the fairest, lady mine, but Snowdrop, the youngest, is more divine.' The queen, hearing this, was filled with rage and despair, for her beauty was her greatest pride. She could not bear the thought that someone else might surpass her, especially Snowdrop, who was so gentle and kind.

In her fury, the queen devised a wicked plan to rid herself of Snowdrop forever. She summoned her huntsman and commanded him to take the girl into the woods and to kill her, bringing back her heart as proof. The huntsman, however, was moved by Snowdrop's innocence and beauty, and he could not bring himself to kill her. Instead, he let her go, telling her to run far away and hide.

Snowdrop fled into the forest, trembling and frightened, but she was also brave and clever. She wandered until she found a tiny cottage, where seven little dwarfs lived. They took her in and cared for her, and she became their dear friend. Snowdrop kept her safety a secret from the wicked queen, who continued to be jealous and cruel.

Meanwhile, the queen, upon discovering that Snowdrop was still alive, was furious. She disguised herself as an old woman and went to the dwarfs' cottage, bringing with her a poisoned comb. She tricked Snowdrop into taking the comb, and the girl fell into a deep sleep. The dwarfs, upon finding her, placed her in a glass coffin, believing she was dead.

Time passed, and a prince, passing through the woods, saw Snowdrop in her glass coffin. He was struck by her beauty and leaned over to kiss her. The magic of his kiss broke the spell, and Snowdrop awoke. She opened her eyes, and they looked into the prince's kind face. The dwarfs rejoiced, and the wicked queen's wickedness was revealed.

Snowdrop and the prince were married, and they lived happily ever after, while the wicked queen faced her own downfall, her vanity and cruelty bringing her to her doom.

events.title: The Queen's Second Murder Attempt: The Poisoned Comb

events.text_segment:
Meantime the queen went home to her glass, and shook with rage when she read the very same answer as before; and she said, ‘Snowdrop shall die, if it cost me my life.’ So she went by herself into her chamber, and got ready a poisoned apple: the outside looked very rosy and tempting, but whoever tasted it was sure to die. Then she dressed herself up as a peasant’s wife, and travelled over the hills to the dwarfs’ cottage, and knocked at the door; but Snowdrop put her head out of the window and said, ‘I dare not let anyone in, for the dwarfs have told me not.’ ‘Do as you please,’ said the old woman, ‘but at any rate take this pretty apple; I will give it you.’ ‘No,’ said Snowdrop, ‘I dare not take it.’ ‘You silly girl!’ answered the other, ‘what are you afraid of? Do you think it is poisoned? Come! do you eat one part, and I will eat the other.’ Now the apple was so made up that one side was good, though the other side was poisoned. Then Snowdrop was much tempted to taste, for the apple looked so very nice; and when she saw the old woman eat, she could wait no longer. But she had scarcely put the piece into her mouth, when she fell down dead upon the ground. ‘This time nothing will save thee,’ said the queen; and she went home to her glass, and at last it said:
‘Thou, queen, art the fairest of all the fair.’
And then her wicked heart was glad, and as happy as such a heart could be.

events.title: Snowdrop's Apparent Death and Vigil in the Glass Coffin
detailed_summary: When evening arrived and the dwarfs returned home, they found Snowdrop lying on the ground; no breath came from her lips, and they feared she was quite dead.
They lifted her, combed her hair, and washed her face with wine and water, but all their efforts were in vain, as the little girl appeared entirely lifeless.
They laid her down upon a bier and all seven watched over and lamented her for three entire days.
After three days, they considered burying her, but her cheeks were still rosy, and her face looked just as it did when she was alive.
Therefore, they decided they would never bury her in the cold ground.
Instead, they constructed a coffin of glass, so they could always look at her, and inscribed upon it in golden letters her name and that she was a king's daughter.
The coffin was set among the hills, and one of the dwarfs always remained by it to watch.
Birds of the air also came to mourn Snowdrop; first an owl, then a raven, and finally a dove, all sat by her side.

events.text_segment: When evening came, and the dwarfs had gone home, they found Snowdrop lying on the ground: no breath came from her lips, and they were afraid that she was quite dead. They lifted her up, and combed her hair, and washed her face with wine and water; but all was in vain, for the little girl seemed quite dead. So they laid her down upon a bier, and all seven watched and bewailed her three whole days; and then they thought they would bury her: but her cheeks were still rosy; and her face looked just as it did while she was alive; so they said, ‘We will never bury her in the cold ground.’ And they made a coffin of glass, so that they might still look at her, and wrote upon it in golden letters what her name was, and that she was a king’s daughter. And the coffin was set among the hills, and one of the dwarfs always sat by it and watched. And the birds of the air came too, and bemoaned Snowdrop; and first of all came an owl, and then a raven, and at last a dove, and sat by her side.

events.title: Snowdrop's Revival by the Prince
detailed_summary: Snowdrop lay in this state for a very long time, appearing only as if she were asleep, her complexion still as white as snow, red as blood, and her hair as black as ebony.
At last, a prince came by and called at the dwarfs' house.
He saw Snowdrop in the coffin and read the golden inscription detailing who she was.
He then offered the dwarfs money and earnestly pleaded with them to allow him to take her away.
The dwarfs initially refused, stating they would not part with her for all the gold in the world.
Eventually, however, they felt pity for him and granted his request, giving him the coffin.
The moment his attendants lifted the coffin to carry it home with him, the piece of poisoned apple fell from between Snowdrop's lips.
Snowdrop awoke and asked, ‘Where am I?’
The prince reassured her, saying, ‘Thou art quite safe with me.’

events.title: Snowdrop's Marriage and the Evil Queen's Final Demise
detailed_summary: The prince then recounted to Snowdrop everything that had occurred.
He declared his love for her, saying he loved her more than anything in the world, and asked her to come with him to his father's palace and become his wife.
Snowdrop consented and accompanied the prince home.
Preparations for their wedding were made with great pomp and splendor.
Among those invited to the feast was Snowdrop's old enemy, the queen.
As the queen was dressing in fine, rich clothes, she looked in her mirror and asked who was the fairest in the land.
The mirror replied that while she, the lady, was lovely, the new-made queen was far lovelier.
Upon hearing this, the queen was startled with rage, but her envy and curiosity were so powerful that she could not resist setting out to see the bride.
When she arrived and saw that the bride was none other than Snowdrop, whom she had long believed to be dead, she choked with rage, fell down, and died.
Snowdrop and the prince, however, lived and reigned happily over that land for many, many years.
Sometimes they would travel to the mountains to visit the little dwarfs who had been so kind to Snowdrop during her time of need.

To the feast was asked, among the rest, Snowdrop’s old enemy the queen; and as she was dressing herself in fine rich clothes, she looked in the glass and said:
‘Tell me, glass, tell me true!
  Of all the ladies in the land,
  Who is fairest, tell me, who?’
And the glass answered:
‘Thou, lady, art loveliest here, I ween;
  But lovelier far is the new-made queen.’
When she heard this she started with rage; but her envy and curiosity were so great, that she could not help setting out to see the bride. And when she got there, and saw that it was no other than Snowdrop, who, as she thought, had been dead a long while, she choked with rage, and fell down and died: but Snowdrop and the prince lived and reigned happily over that land many, many years; and sometimes they went up into the mountains, and paid a visit to the little dwarfs, who had been so kind to Snowdrop in her time of need.

events.title: The Barren Queen's Wish and the Prophetic Birth
detailed_summary: A queen, saddened by her childlessness, prayed daily for a child.
An angel appeared to her, prophesying that she would have a son endowed with the power to make any wish come true.
The queen shared this joyful news with the king.
In due time, she gave birth to a son, which brought immense happiness to the king.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then she went to the king, and told him the joyful tidings, and when the time was come she gave birth to a son, and the king was filled with gladness.

events.text_segment: There was once upon a time a queen to whom God had given no children. Every morning she went into the garden and prayed to God in heaven to bestow on her a son or a daughter. Then an angel from heaven came to her and said: ‘Be at rest, you shall have a son with the power of wishing, so that whatsoever in the world he wishes for, that shall he have.’ Then she went to the king, and told him the joyful tidings, and when the time was come she gave birth to a son, and the king was filled with gladness.

events.title: The Cook's Deceit, the Child's Abduction, and the Queen's Unjust Imprisonment
detailed_summary: The queen habitually took her young son to a garden with wild animals, where she would bathe in a clear stream.
During one such visit, while the queen slept with the child in her arms, the old cook, aware of the child's wish-granting ability, abducted him.
To frame the queen, the cook slaughtered a hen and stained her apron and dress with its blood.
He then falsely reported to the king that wild beasts had snatched the child.
The king, convinced by the blood evidence, reacted with fury, ordering the queen to be imprisoned in a high, dark tower for seven years without food or water, expecting her to perish.
However, two angels, appearing as white doves, miraculously delivered food to the queen twice a day, sustaining her throughout her seven-year confinement.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Every morning she went with the child to the garden where the wild beasts were kept, and washed herself there in a clear stream.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But God sent two angels from heaven in the shape of white doves, which flew to her twice a day, and carried her food until the seven years were over.

events.text_segment: Every morning she went with the child to the garden where the wild beasts were kept, and washed herself there in a clear stream. It happened once when the child was a little older, that it was lying in her arms and she fell asleep. Then came the old cook, who knew that the child had the power of wishing, and stole it away, and he took a hen, and cut it in pieces, and dropped some of its blood on the queen’s apron and on her dress. Then he carried the child away to a secret place, where a nurse was obliged to suckle it, and he ran to the king and accused the queen of having allowed her child to be taken from her by the wild beasts. When the king saw the blood on her apron, he believed this, fell into such a passion that he ordered a high tower to be built, in which neither sun nor moon could be seen and had his wife put into it, and walled up. Here she was to stay for seven years without meat or drink, and die of hunger. But God sent two angels from heaven in the shape of white doves, which flew to her twice a day, and carried her food until the seven years were over.

events.title: The Cook's Exploitation, the Maiden's Mercy, and the Cook's Canine Transformation
detailed_summary: The cook, fearing the child's wishing power could expose his villainy, departed from the palace.
He located the boy, who was now old enough to speak, and prompted him to wish for a magnificent palace with a garden, which instantly materialized.
Sometime later, the cook suggested the boy wish for a beautiful girl as a companion, leading to the immediate appearance of a lovely maiden.
The boy and the maiden developed a close bond, playing together and loving each other, while the old cook enjoyed a life of leisure, hunting like a nobleman.
Concerned that the prince might eventually wish to reunite with his father, thus putting the cook in danger, the cook devised a plan.
He privately instructed the maiden to kill the sleeping boy that night by plunging a knife into his heart and to bring him the boy's heart and tongue, threatening her life if she failed.
The next day, when the cook returned, the maiden had not complied, questioning why she should harm an innocent boy.
The cook reiterated his threat, stating her life depended on obedience.
After the cook left, the maiden had a young deer (hind) killed, took its heart and tongue, and placed them on a plate to deceive him.
She instructed the boy to feign sleep in his bed, covered by clothes.
When the cook entered and demanded the boy's heart and tongue, the maiden presented the plate, but the prince suddenly threw off his covers.

The prince confronted the cook, questioning his murderous intent, and then pronounced his sentence: the cook would transform into a black poodle with a gold collar and be forced to eat burning coals until flames erupted from his throat.
Upon these words, the cook was instantly changed into a poodle and compelled by other cooks to eat live coals until his throat burst into flames.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The cook, however, thought to himself: ‘If the child has the power of wishing, and I am here, he might very easily get me into trouble.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And when he had spoken these words, the old man was changed into a poodle dog, and had a gold collar round his neck, and the cooks were ordered to bring up some live coals, and these he ate, until the flames broke forth from his throat.

events.text_segment: The cook, however, thought to himself: ‘If the child has the power of wishing, and I am here, he might very easily get me into trouble.’ So he left the palace and went to the boy, who was already big enough to speak, and said to him: ‘Wish for a beautiful palace for yourself with a garden, and all else that pertains to it.’ Scarcely were the words out of the boy’s mouth, when everything was there that he had wished for. After a while the cook said to him: ‘It is not well for you to be so alone, wish for a pretty girl as a companion.’ Then the king’s son wished for one, and she immediately stood before him, and was more beautiful than any painter could have painted her. The two played together, and loved each other with all their hearts, and the old cook went out hunting like a nobleman. The thought occurred to him, however, that the king’s son might some day wish to be with his father, and thus bring him into great peril. So he went out and took the maiden aside, and said: ‘Tonight when the boy is asleep, go to his bed and plunge this knife into his heart, and bring me his heart and tongue, and if you do not do it, you shall lose your life.’ Thereupon he went away, and when he returned next day she had not done it, and said: ‘Why should I shed the blood of an innocent boy who has never harmed anyone?’ The cook once more said: ‘If you do not do it, it shall cost you your own life.’ When he had gone away, she had a little hind brought to her, and ordered her to be killed, and took her heart and tongue, and laid them on a plate, and when she saw the old man coming, she said to the boy: ‘Lie down in your bed, and draw the clothes over you.’ Then the wicked wretch came in and said: ‘Where are the boy’s heart and tongue?’ The girl reached the plate to him, but the king’s son threw off the quilt, and said: ‘You old sinner, why did you want to kill me? Now will I pronounce thy sentence. You shall become a black poodle and have a gold collar round your neck, and shall eat burning coals, till the flames burst forth from your throat.’ And when he had spoken these words, the old man was changed into a poodle dog, and had a gold collar round his neck, and the cooks were ordered to bring up some live coals, and these he ate, until the flames broke forth from his throat.

The next day, when the cook returned, the maiden had not yet carried out his command. She questioned why she should harm an innocent boy, but the cook reiterated his threat, insisting her life depended on obedience. To deceive him, the maiden had a young deer (hind) killed, and took its heart and tongue, placing them on a plate to fool the cook. She then instructed the boy to feign sleep in his bed, covered by clothes, so that the cook would not suspect.

When the cook entered and demanded the boy's heart and tongue, the maiden presented the plate. Suddenly, the prince threw off his covers, confronting the cook with courage. He questioned the cook's murderous intent, and then pronounced his own judgment: the cook would be transformed into a black poodle with a gold collar and be forced to eat burning coals until flames erupted from his throat. As soon as the words left the prince's mouth, the cook was instantly changed into a poodle, and other cooks compelled him to eat live coals until his throat burst into flames.

events.title: The Prince's Journey Home and Miraculous Reunion at the Tower
detailed_summary: The prince, after some time, began to think of his mother and wondered about her fate.
He decided to return to his homeland and invited the maiden to join him, offering to provide for her.
The maiden expressed reluctance due to the long journey and the prospect of being a stranger in a foreign land.
Unwilling to be separated, the prince wished for her to become a beautiful pink flower, which he then carried with him.
He journeyed back to his country, with the poodle (the transformed cook) following him.
Upon reaching the tower where his mother was imprisoned, he found it very tall and wished for a ladder to reach the top.
He ascended the ladder, looked inside, and called out to his mother, inquiring if she was still alive.
She replied that she had just eaten and was satisfied, believing it was the angels who brought her sustenance.
The prince then revealed his identity, stating he was her son, falsely reported as torn apart by wild beasts, but was alive and would soon liberate her.

events.text_segment: The king’s son remained there a short while longer, and he thought of his mother, and wondered if she were still alive. At length he said to the maiden: ‘I will go home to my own country; if you will go with me, I will provide for you.’ ‘Ah,’ she replied, ‘the way is so long, and what shall I do in a strange land where I am unknown?’ As she did not seem quite willing, and as they could not be parted from each other, he wished that she might be changed into a beautiful pink, and took her with him. Then he went away to his own country, and the poodle had to run after him. He went to the tower in which his mother was confined, and as it was so high, he wished for a ladder which would reach up to the very top. Then he mounted up and looked inside, and cried: ‘Beloved mother, Lady Queen, are you still alive, or are you dead?’ She answered: ‘I have just eaten, and am still satisfied,’ for she thought the angels were there. Said he: ‘I am your dear son, whom the wild beasts were said to have torn from your arms; but I am alive still, and will soon set you free.’

events.title: The Prince's Guise as a Huntsman and a Miraculous Hunt
detailed_summary: After speaking with his mother, the prince descended from the tower and went to his father, the king.
He had himself announced as a foreign huntsman seeking employment.
The king agreed to hire him if he was skillful and could provide game, mentioning the long-standing scarcity of deer in the area.
The prince confidently promised to procure an abundant supply of game for the royal table.
He then gathered all the royal huntsmen and led them into the forest.
He instructed them to form a large circle, open at one end where he stood, and then he made a wish.
Instantly, more than two hundred deer ran into the circle, where they were shot by the huntsmen.
The massive haul of game was loaded onto sixty carts and transported back to the king.
This allowed the king, after many years, to finally serve game at his table.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they were all placed on sixty country carts, and driven home to the king, and for once he was able to deck his table with game, after having had none at all for years.

events.text_segment: Then he descended again, and went to his father, and caused himself to be announced as a strange huntsman, and asked if he could offer him service. The king said yes, if he was skilful and could get game for him, he should come to him, but that deer had never taken up their quarters in any part of the district or country. Then the huntsman promised to procure as much game for him as he could possibly use at the royal table. So he summoned all the huntsmen together, and bade them go out into the forest with him. And he went with them and made them form a great circle, open at one end where he stationed himself, and began to wish. Two hundred deer and more came running inside the circle at once, and the huntsmen shot them. Then they were all placed on sixty country carts, and driven home to the king, and for once he was able to deck his table with game, after having had none at all for years.

events.title: The Royal Feast, the Prince's Revelation, and the Cook's Exposure
detailed_summary: Delighted by the successful hunt, the king commanded a great feast for his entire household the next day.
During the feast, he insisted that the skilled huntsman (the prince in disguise) sit beside him, despite the huntsman's modest protests.
While seated, the prince wished for one of the king's principal servants to bring up the subject of his mother in the tower.
As soon as he made the wish, the marshal spoke up, asking about the queen's condition and whether she was still alive.
The king angrily retorted that she had allowed his son to be killed by wild beasts and forbade any mention of her.
At this, the huntsman rose and revealed his true identity as the king's son.
He clarified that he was not taken by wild beasts but abducted by the treacherous old cook, who had framed the queen using chicken blood.
He then presented the dog with the golden collar, identifying it as the cook, and had live coals brought for the dog to eat in front of everyone until flames erupted from its throat.
The prince then asked the king if he wished to see the cook in his true form, and with a wish, restored the cook to his human appearance, complete with his white apron and knife.
The king, enraged upon seeing the cook, ordered him to be cast into the deepest dungeon.
The prince further spoke of the maiden who had cared for him and had refused to murder him despite threats to her own life.
He first revealed her to the king as a beautiful flower from his pocket, which he placed on the royal table.
Then, he wished her back into her human form, and she appeared before them, exceptionally beautiful.

events.text_segment: Now the king felt great joy at this, and commanded that his entire household should eat with him next day, and made a great feast. When they were all assembled together, he said to the huntsman: ‘As you are so clever, you shall sit by me.’ He replied: ‘Lord King, your majesty must excuse me, I am a poor huntsman.’ But the king insisted on it, and said: ‘You shall sit by me,’ until he did it. Whilst he was sitting there, he thought of his dearest mother, and wished that one of the king’s principal servants would begin to speak of her, and would ask how it was faring with the queen in the tower, and if she were alive still, or had perished. Hardly had he formed the wish than the marshal began, and said: ‘Your majesty, we live joyously here, but how is the queen living in the tower? Is she still alive, or has she died?’ But the king replied: ‘She let my dear son be torn to pieces by wild beasts; I will not have her named.’ Then the huntsman arose and said: ‘Gracious lord father she is alive still, and I am her son, and I was not carried away by wild beasts, but by that wretch the old cook, who tore me from her arms when she was asleep, and sprinkled her apron with the blood of a chicken.’ Thereupon he took the dog with the golden collar, and said: ‘That is the wretch!’ and caused live coals to be brought, and these the dog was compelled to devour before the sight of all, until flames burst forth from its throat. On this the huntsman asked the king if he would like to see the dog in his true shape, and wished him back into the form of the cook, in which he stood immediately, with his white apron, and his knife by his side. When the king saw him he fell into a passion, and ordered him to be cast into the deepest dungeon. Then the huntsman spoke further and said: ‘Father, will you see the maiden who brought me up so tenderly and who was afterwards to murder me, but did not do it, though her own life depended on it?’ The king replied: ‘Yes, I would like to see her.’ The son said: ‘Most gracious father, I will show her to you in the form of a beautiful flower,’ and he thrust his hand into his pocket and brought forth the pink, and placed it on the royal table, and it was so beautiful that the king had never seen one to equal it. Then the son said: ‘Now will I show her to you in her own form,’ and wished that she might become a maiden, and she stood there looking so beautiful that no painter could have made her look more so.

They traveled through thick forests, crossed bubbling streams, and climbed steep hills, all the while searching for the elusive creature. The king often visited the forest, ensuring that the harmony between humans and nature was maintained. And so, the kingdom enjoyed peace and happiness, all thanks to the brave search and the mysterious creature that brought them good fortune.

events.title: The Queen's Release and Tragic Death, Final Justice, and the Prince's New Life
detailed_summary: The king sent servants to the tower to retrieve the queen and bring her to the royal table.
When the queen was brought in, she refused to eat, declaring that the merciful God who had sustained her in the tower would soon grant her ultimate freedom.
She lived for only three more days before dying peacefully.
At her burial, the two white doves, recognized as angels from heaven who had provided her food, followed her body and settled on her grave.
The aged king ordered that the cook be executed by being torn into four pieces.
However, grief over these events consumed the king's heart, and he died soon after.
The prince married the beautiful maiden whom he had carried with him as a flower.
The narrator concludes that whether they are still alive is a matter known only to God.

events.text_segment: And the king sent two waiting-maids and two attendants into the tower, to fetch the queen and bring her to the royal table. But when she was led in she ate nothing, and said: ‘The gracious and merciful God who has supported me in the tower, will soon set me free.’ She lived three days more, and then died happily, and when she was buried, the two white doves which had brought her food to the tower, and were angels of heaven, followed her body and seated themselves on her grave. The aged king ordered the cook to be torn in four pieces, but grief consumed the king’s own heart, and he soon died. His son married the beautiful maiden whom he had brought with him as a flower in his pocket, and whether they are still alive or not, is known to God.

events.title: Elsie's Betrothal and an Ominous Vision in the Cellar
detailed_summary: - Elsie's parents expressed their desire for her to get married.
- A suitor named Hans appeared, specifying that his future wife, Elsie, must be exceptionally intelligent.
- Elsie's father asserted her good sense, while her mother made hyperbolic claims about her perceptive abilities, such as detecting wind and hearing flies cough.
- Hans reiterated that he would only marry her if she was truly smart.
- During dinner, Elsie was instructed by her mother to go to the cellar to fetch beer.
- Elsie took a pitcher and, to make the time pass quickly, tapped the lid as she descended.
- In the cellar, she arranged a chair by the barrel to avoid straining herself while drawing the beer.
- As the beer flowed, she scanned her surroundings and noticed a pick-axe left precariously above her by masons.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once a man who had a daughter who was called Clever Elsie.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then she placed the can before her, and turned the tap, and while the beer was running she would not let her eyes be idle, but looked up at the wall, and after much peering here and there, saw a pick-axe exactly above her, which the masons had accidentally left there.

events.text_segment: There was once a man who had a daughter who was called Clever Elsie. And when she had grown up her father said: ‘We will get her married.’ ‘Yes,’ said the mother, ‘if only someone would come who would have her.’ At length a man came from a distance and wooed her, who was called Hans; but he stipulated that Clever Elsie should be really smart. ‘Oh,’ said the father, ‘she has plenty of good sense’; and the mother said: ‘Oh, she can see the wind coming up the street, and hear the flies coughing.’ ‘Well,’ said Hans, ‘if she is not really smart, I won’t have her.’ When they were sitting at dinner and had eaten, the mother said: ‘Elsie, go into the cellar and fetch some beer.’ Then Clever Elsie took the pitcher from the wall, went into the cellar, and tapped the lid briskly as she went, so that the time might not appear long. When she was below she fetched herself a chair, and set it before the barrel so that she had no need to stoop, and did not hurt her back or do herself any unexpected injury. Then she placed the can before her, and turned the tap, and while the beer was running she would not let her eyes be idle, but looked up at the wall, and after much peering here and there, saw a pick-axe exactly above her, which the masons had accidentally left there.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
There was once a man who had a daughter called Clever Elsie. Her parents often said to each other that it was hard to find a man who would marry her, for she was so clever. One day, a young man named Hans came to see her. He said, 'I will marry Elsie, but only if she is very smart.' Elsie's father replied, 'Elsie has good sense,' but her mother added, 'Oh, she can hear flies cough and tell which way the wind blows.' Hans said, 'If she is not truly clever, I will not marry her.'

At dinner, Elsie's mother told her to go down to the cellar to fetch some beer. Elsie took a pitcher from the wall and, to pass the time, tapped the lid as she went down. When she reached the cellar, she set the pitcher on the floor and arranged a chair by the barrel so she wouldn't strain herself while drawing the beer. As she drew the beer, she looked around and saw a pick-axe left hanging above her by the masons, leaning precariously.

Elsie understood and asked for the strength to help others. The bird granted her wish, and Elsie returned home, her heart full of joy.

From that day on, Clever Elsie used her newfound strength to help her neighbors and friends, earning their love and respect. Her cleverness and kindness made her a true treasure in her village, and she lived happily ever after.

events.title: The Cascade of Sympathetic Sorrow in the Cellar
detailed_summary: - Upon seeing the pick-axe, Elsie began to cry, imagining a future scenario where her and Hans's child would be sent to the cellar and killed by the falling tool.
- She remained in the cellar, weeping and lamenting loudly over this projected misfortune.
- When Elsie didn't return, her mother sent the servant to check on her.
- The maid found Elsie crying and, upon hearing Elsie's fears about the pick-axe and her future child, declared Elsie clever and joined in the weeping.
- As the maid also failed to return, the father sent the boy to investigate.
- The boy discovered both Elsie and the maid weeping; Elsie reiterated her concern, prompting the boy to also call her clever and join their lament.
- With the boy not returning, the mother went down herself, found all three crying, and learned of Elsie's fear for her future child.
- The mother too proclaimed Elsie clever and sat down to weep with them.
- Finally, the father, driven by thirst and the continued absence of his wife, went to the cellar.

- He found everyone crying, heard Elsie's elaborate fear about a potential child being killed by the pick-axe under very specific future circumstances, and he too exclaimed at Elsie's cleverness before joining the collective weeping.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then Clever Elsie began to weep and said: ‘If I get Hans, and we have a child, and he grows big, and we send him into the cellar here to draw beer, then the pick-axe will fall on his head and kill him.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But when he got into the cellar, and they were all sitting together crying, and he heard the reason, and that Elsie’s child was the cause, and the Elsie might perhaps bring one into the world some day, and that he might be killed by the pick-axe, if he should happen to be sitting beneath it, drawing beer just at the very time when it fell down, he cried: ‘Oh, what a clever Elsie!’ and sat down, and likewise wept with them.

events.text_segment: Then Clever Elsie began to weep and said: ‘If I get Hans, and we have a child, and he grows big, and we send him into the cellar here to draw beer, then the pick-axe will fall on his head and kill him.’ Then she sat and wept and screamed with all the strength of her body, over the misfortune which lay before her. Those upstairs waited for the drink, but Clever Elsie still did not come. Then the woman said to the servant: ‘Just go down into the cellar and see where Elsie is.’ The maid went and found her sitting in front of the barrel, screaming loudly. ‘Elsie why do you weep?’ asked the maid. ‘Ah,’ she answered, ‘have I not reason to weep? If I get Hans, and we have a child, and he grows big, and has to draw beer here, the pick-axe will perhaps fall on his head, and kill him.’ Then said the maid: ‘What a clever Elsie we have!’ and sat down beside her and began loudly to weep over the misfortune. After a while, as the maid did not come back, and those upstairs were thirsty for the beer, the man said to the boy: ‘Just go down into the cellar and see where Elsie and the girl are.’ The boy went down, and there sat Clever Elsie and the girl both weeping together. Then he asked: ‘Why are you weeping?’ ‘Ah,’ said Elsie, ‘have I not reason to weep? If I get Hans, and we have a child, and he grows big, and has to draw beer here, the pick-axe will fall on his head and kill him.’ Then said the boy: ‘What a clever Elsie we have!’ and sat down by her, and likewise began to howl loudly. Upstairs they waited for the boy, but as he still did not return, the man said to the woman: ‘Just go down into the cellar and see where Elsie is!’ The woman went down, and found all three in the midst of their lamentations, and inquired what was the cause; then Elsie told her also that her future child was to be killed by the pick-axe, when it grew big and had to draw beer, and the pick-axe fell down. Then said the mother likewise: ‘What a clever Elsie we have!’ and sat down and wept with them. The man upstairs waited a short time, but as his wife did not come back and his thirst grew ever greater, he said: ‘I must go into the cellar myself and see where Elsie is.’ But when he got into the cellar, and they were all sitting together crying, and he heard the reason, and that Elsie’s child was the cause, and the Elsie might perhaps bring one into the world some day, and that he might be killed by the pick-axe, if he should happen to be sitting beneath it, drawing beer just at the very time when it fell down, he cried: ‘Oh, what a clever Elsie!’ and sat down, and likewise wept with them.

events.title: Hans's Curious Approval and the Unlikely Wedding
detailed_summary: - Hans, the bridegroom, waited alone upstairs for a considerable time.
- Believing the others might be waiting for him below, he decided to go to the cellar to see what was happening.
- Upon descending, he found all five individuals—Elsie, the maid, the boy, Elsie's mother, and Elsie's father—loudly screaming and lamenting.
- Hans inquired about the cause of their misfortune.
- Elsie explained her fear: if they married and had a child who was later sent to the cellar for a drink, the pick-axe might fall and kill him.
- Hans declared that such foresight was all the understanding needed for his household.
- Impressed by her perceived cleverness, he affirmed he would marry her, took her hand, and they went upstairs and were wed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The bridegroom stayed upstairs alone for a long time; then as no one would come back he thought: ‘They must be waiting for me below: I too must go there and see what they are about.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Come,’ said Hans, ‘more understanding than that is not needed for my household, as you are such a clever Elsie, I will have you,’ and seized her hand, took her upstairs with him, and married her.

events.text_segment: The bridegroom stayed upstairs alone for a long time; then as no one would come back he thought: ‘They must be waiting for me below: I too must go there and see what they are about.’ When he got down, the five of them were sitting screaming and lamenting quite piteously, each out-doing the other. ‘What misfortune has happened then?’ asked he. ‘Ah, dear Hans,’ said Elsie, ‘if we marry each other and have a child, and he is big, and we perhaps send him here to draw something to drink, then the pick-axe which has been left up there might dash his brains out if it were to fall down, so have we not reason to weep?’ ‘Come,’ said Hans, ‘more understanding than that is not needed for my household, as you are such a clever Elsie, I will have you,’ and seized her hand, took her upstairs with him, and married her.

events.title: Elsie's Unconventional Approach to Farm Work
detailed_summary: - Sometime after their marriage, Hans told Elsie he was going out to earn money and instructed her to go to the field to cut corn for bread.
- Elsie agreed to do so.
- After Hans left, she prepared some broth and took it with her to the field.
- Upon arriving at the field, she debated whether to cut the corn first or eat first, ultimately deciding to eat.
- After finishing her broth and feeling satisfied, she then deliberated between cutting the corn and sleeping, choosing to sleep.
- She lay down among the corn and fell asleep.
- Hans, having been home for a while and noting Elsie's absence, ironically praised her supposed diligence, assuming she was too busy working to return for a meal.
- When evening arrived and Elsie had still not returned, Hans went to the field to see her progress.
- He discovered that no corn had been cut and found Elsie asleep in the field.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After Hans had had her some time, he said: ‘Wife, I am going out to work and earn some money for us; go into the field and cut the corn that we may have some bread.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But when evening came and she still stayed away, Hans went out to see what she had cut, but nothing was cut, and she was lying among the corn asleep.

events.text_segment: After Hans had had her some time, he said: ‘Wife, I am going out to work and earn some money for us; go into the field and cut the corn that we may have some bread.’ ‘Yes, dear Hans, I will do that.’ After Hans had gone away, she cooked herself some good broth and took it into the field with her. When she came to the field she said to herself: ‘What shall I do; shall I cut first, or shall I eat first? Oh, I will eat first.’ Then she drank her cup of broth and when she was fully satisfied, she once more said: ‘What shall I do? Shall I cut first, or shall I sleep first? I will sleep first.’ Then she lay down among the corn and fell asleep. Hans had been at home for a long time, but Elsie did not come; then said he: ‘What a clever Elsie I have; she is so industrious that she does not even come home to eat.’ But when evening came and she still stayed away, Hans went out to see what she had cut, but nothing was cut, and she was lying among the corn asleep.

events.title: The Jingling Bells and Elsie's Existential Crisis
detailed_summary: - Upon finding Elsie asleep, Hans quickly returned home and brought a fowler's net adorned with little bells, which he hung around her while she continued to sleep.
- He then ran back home, shut the house door, sat in his chair, and resumed working.
- When it was quite dark, Clever Elsie finally awoke.
- As she stood up, she was surrounded by a jingling sound, with bells ringing at her every step.
- This alarmed her and made her deeply uncertain about her own identity, causing her to wonder aloud if she was truly Clever Elsie.
- Unable to resolve this doubt, she decided to go home and ask, believing they would know.
- She ran to her house door but found it shut; she knocked on the window and called out to Hans, asking if Elsie was inside.
- Hans replied from within that Elsie was indeed inside.
- This terrified Elsie, convincing her that she was not herself.
- She then went to another door, but the people there, hearing the jingling bells, refused to open it, leaving her unable to find entry anywhere.
- Consequently, she fled the village, and her whereabouts thereafter remained unknown.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then Hans hastened home and brought a fowler’s net with little bells and hung it round about her, and she still went on sleeping.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then she ran out of the village, and no one has seen her since.

events.text_segment: Then Hans hastened home and brought a fowler’s net with little bells and hung it round about her, and she still went on sleeping. Then he ran home, shut the house-door, and sat down in his chair and worked. At length, when it was quite dark, Clever Elsie awoke and when she got up there was a jingling all round about her, and the bells rang at each step which she took. Then she was alarmed, and became uncertain whether she really was Clever Elsie or not, and said: ‘Is it I, or is it not I?’ But she knew not what answer to make to this, and stood for a time in doubt; at length she thought: ‘I will go home and ask if it be I, or if it be not I, they will be sure to know.’ She ran to the door of her own house, but it was shut; then she knocked at the window and cried: ‘Hans, is Elsie within?’ ‘Yes,’ answered Hans, ‘she is within.’ Hereupon she was terrified, and said: ‘Ah, heavens! Then it is not I,’ and went to another door; but when the people heard the jingling of the bells they would not open it, and she could get in nowhere. Then she ran out of the village, and no one has seen her since.

events.title: The Servant's Departure with Meager Pay
detailed_summary: A loyal servant, after three years of dedicated but unpaid labor for his master, finally requested the wages he was owed.
The master, characterized as a severe miser, recognized his servant's simple nature and decided to exploit it, giving him only three pence – one penny for each year of service.
The naive servant, believing this to be a substantial amount of money, felt a sense of newfound wealth and freedom.
He resolved to abandon his difficult life of hard work and poor sustenance, deciding instead to travel the world and enjoy himself.
With this resolution, he placed his meager earnings into his purse and embarked on his journey, wandering through the countryside.

events.text_segment: A farmer had a faithful and diligent servant, who had worked hard for him three years, without having been paid any wages. At last it came into the man’s head that he would not go on thus without pay any longer; so he went to his master, and said, ‘I have worked hard for you a long time, I will trust to you to give me what I deserve to have for my trouble.’ The farmer was a sad miser, and knew that his man was very simple-hearted; so he took out threepence, and gave him for every year’s service a penny. The poor fellow thought it was a great deal of money to have, and said to himself, ‘Why should I work hard, and live here on bad fare any longer? I can now travel into the wide world, and make myself merry.’ With that he put his money into his purse, and set out, roaming over hill and valley.

He handed him only three pence—one penny for each year of service—knowing the servant would consider it a generous reward. The servant, naive and pleased with this small sum, believed he had received a fortune. Filled with joy and a sense of newfound independence, he decided to leave his hard life behind. He placed his meager earnings into his purse, bid farewell to his master, and set out to explore the world, eager to enjoy the freedom he thought he had earned.

events.title: Encounter with the Dwarf and the Granting of Three Wishes
detailed_summary: As the countryman journeyed cheerfully, singing and dancing, he was approached by a small dwarf who questioned the source of his happiness.
The countryman explained that his joy stemmed from his good health and his supposed riches, revealing his three pence savings.
The dwarf, stating he was very poor, requested the money from the countryman.
Moved by pity, the kind-hearted countryman gave the dwarf all of his money.

As a reward for his generosity and honest heart, the dwarf granted him three wishes: a bow that would never miss its target, a fiddle whose music would compel anyone who heard it to dance, and the ability to have any request he made granted.
The dwarf then provided the magical bow and fiddle to the countryman and departed.

events.text_segment: As he jogged along over the fields, singing and dancing, a little dwarf met him, and asked him what made him so merry. ‘Why, what should make me down-hearted?’ said he; ‘I am sound in health and rich in purse, what should I care for? I have saved up my three years’ earnings and have it all safe in my pocket.’ ‘How much may it come to?’ said the little man. ‘Full threepence,’ replied the countryman. ‘I wish you would give them to me,’ said the other; ‘I am very poor.’ Then the man pitied him, and gave him all he had; and the little dwarf said in return, ‘As you have such a kind honest heart, I will grant you three wishes—one for every penny; so choose whatever you like.’ Then the countryman rejoiced at his good luck, and said, ‘I like many things better than money: first, I will have a bow that will bring down everything I shoot at; secondly, a fiddle that will set everyone dancing that hears me play upon it; and thirdly, I should like that everyone should grant what I ask.’ The dwarf said he should have his three wishes; so he gave him the bow and fiddle, and went his way.

events.title: The Countryman Outwits a Miser Using His Magical Gifts
detailed_summary: The countryman continued his journey, his spirits even higher than before, and soon encountered an old miser.
Nearby, a thrush sang joyfully from the top of a tree, and the miser expressed a strong desire to possess the bird, claiming he would pay a great sum for it.
The countryman offered to retrieve the bird and, using his magical bow, shot the thrush, causing it to fall into a thorny bush at the tree's base.
As the miser ventured into the dense bush to find the bird, the countryman began to play his magical fiddle.
The music irresistibly forced the miser to dance and leap among the thorns, which tore his clothes to shreds and left him scratched and bleeding.
The miser, in agony, begged the countryman to stop the music, pleading his innocence and asking what he had done to deserve such treatment.
The countryman retorted that the miser was merely receiving his due for having exploited many poor people, and he continued to play.

Desperate, the miser started offering money for his release, gradually increasing his bids as the countryman played faster tunes, until he finally offered a hundred florins – money he had recently acquired by cheating someone.
Seeing this substantial sum, the countryman agreed, took the purse, ceased playing, and contentedly resumed his travels.

events.text_segment: Our honest friend journeyed on his way too; and if he was merry before, he was now ten times more so. He had not gone far before he met an old miser: close by them stood a tree, and on the topmost twig sat a thrush singing away most joyfully. ‘Oh, what a pretty bird!’ said the miser; ‘I would give a great deal of money to have such a one.’ ‘If that’s all,’ said the countryman, ‘I will soon bring it down.’ Then he took up his bow, and down fell the thrush into the bushes at the foot of the tree. The miser crept into the bush to find it; but directly he had got into the middle, his companion took up his fiddle and played away, and the miser began to dance and spring about, capering higher and higher in the air. The thorns soon began to tear his clothes till they all hung in rags about him, and he himself was all scratched and wounded, so that the blood ran down. ‘Oh, for heaven’s sake!’ cried the miser, ‘Master! master! pray let the fiddle alone. What have I done to deserve this?’ ‘Thou hast shaved many a poor soul close enough,’ said the other; ‘thou art only meeting thy reward’: so he played up another tune. Then the miser began to beg and promise, and offered money for his liberty; but he did not come up to the musician’s price for some time, and he danced him along brisker and brisker, and the miser bid higher and higher, till at last he offered a round hundred of florins that he had in his purse, and had just gained by cheating some poor fellow. When the countryman saw so much money, he said, ‘I will agree to your proposal.’ So he took the purse, put up his fiddle, and travelled on very pleased with his bargain.

events.title: The Miser's Revenge Plot and the Countryman's Arrest
detailed_summary: Meanwhile, the miser, emerging from the bush half-dressed and in a wretched state, began to plot how he could exact revenge on the countryman.
He proceeded to the local judge and lodged a complaint, accusing a scoundrel of robbing him of his money and assaulting him, describing the culprit as carrying a bow and a fiddle.
Acting on this complaint, the judge dispatched his officers with instructions to find and apprehend the man matching the description.
The countryman was soon located by the officers, arrested, and brought before the judge to stand trial.

events.title: The Final Request and the Fiddle's Compulsory Dance
detailed_summary: As he stood on the steps of the gallows, the countryman made a final request to the judge.
The judge agreed to grant any request except for his life; the countryman clarified he only wished to play his fiddle one last time.
The miser vehemently protested, begging the judge not to allow it.
Despite the miser's pleas, the judge consented, stating it would be brief; this compliance was influenced by the dwarf's third gift, which compelled people to grant the countryman's requests.
Panicked, the miser cried out to be tied securely.
The countryman then took his fiddle and began to play. Instantly, the judge, clerks, and jailer started to move and caper, and no one could restrain the miser.

At the second note, the hangman released the countryman and also began dancing. By the time the first bar of the tune was played, everyone present—judge, court officials, the miser, and all the spectators—was dancing uncontrollably.
Initially, the scene was somewhat amusing, but as the music and dancing continued without end, the participants began to cry out, begging the countryman to stop.
He paid no heed to their pleas until the judge not only granted him his life but also promised the return of the hundred florins.

events.text_segment:
So away he was taken; but as he stood on the steps he said, ‘My Lord Judge, grant me one last request.’ ‘Anything but thy life,’ replied the other. ‘No,’ said he, ‘I do not ask my life; only to let me play upon my fiddle for the last time.’ The miser cried out, ‘Oh, no! no! for heaven’s sake don’t listen to him! don’t listen to him!’ But the judge said, ‘It is only this once, he will soon have done.’ The fact was, he could not refuse the request, on account of the dwarf’s third gift.
Then the miser said, ‘Bind me fast, bind me fast, for pity’s sake.’ But the countryman seized his fiddle, and struck up a tune, and at the first note judge, clerks, and jailer were in motion; all began capering, and no one could hold the miser. At the second note the hangman let his prisoner go, and danced also, and by the time he had played the first bar of the tune, all were dancing together—judge, court, and miser, and all the people who had followed to look on. At first the thing was merry and pleasant enough; but when it had gone on a while, and there seemed to be no end of playing or dancing, they began to cry out, and beg him to leave off; but he stopped not a whit the more for their entreaties, till the judge not only gave him his life, but promised to return him the hundred florins.

The miser, hearing this, cried out vehemently, ‘Do not allow him to play! It will be the ruin of us all!’ But the judge, bound by the gift, nodded, and the countryman took his fiddle and began to play. events.title: Justice Restored and the Miser's Public Confession
detailed_summary: Once the judge had agreed to spare his life and return the money, the countryman addressed the miser directly.
He warned the miser, whom he called a vagabond, to reveal how he had obtained the gold, threatening to resume playing the fiddle solely for the miser's torment if he refused.
Compelled and in the presence of all the assembled people, the miser confessed that he had stolen the gold.
The miser also acknowledged that the countryman had earned the money fairly.
Having extracted this public confession, the countryman ceased playing his fiddle, thereby leaving the now-exposed thief, the miser, to face execution in his stead.

events.title: Mother's Death, Father's Remarriage, and Ashputtel's Torment
detailed_summary: A wealthy man's wife, on her deathbed, instructed her only daughter to always be good, promising to watch over her from heaven.
Following her mother's death and burial in the garden, the little girl visited the grave daily, wept, and remained consistently good and kind.
After snow covered the grave and melted with the spring, the girl's father remarried.
The new wife brought her two daughters, who were fair-faced but malevolent at heart, marking the beginning of a difficult time for the little girl.
The stepsisters demeaned her, questioning her place in the parlor and asserting that she should earn her keep, ultimately calling for her to be a kitchen-maid.
They confiscated her fine clothes, gave her an old grey frock, mocked her, and confined her to the kitchen.
She was compelled to perform arduous labor: waking before dawn, carrying water, tending the fire, cooking, and washing.
Additionally, her stepsisters tormented her relentlessly and ridiculed her.
In the evenings, tired from her work, she had no bed and was forced to sleep by the hearth among the ashes, which made her perpetually dusty and dirty, leading them to call her Ashputtel.

events.text_segment:
The wife of a rich man fell sick; and when she felt that her end drew nigh, she called her only daughter to her bed-side, and said, ‘Always be a good girl, and I will look down from heaven and watch over you.’ Soon afterwards she shut her eyes and died, and was buried in the garden; and the little girl went every day to her grave and wept, and was always good and kind to all about her. And the snow fell and spread a beautiful white covering over the grave; but by the time the spring came, and the sun had melted it away again, her father had married another wife. This new wife had two daughters of her own, that she brought home with her; they were fair in face but foul at heart, and it was now a sorry time for the poor little girl. ‘What does the good-for-nothing want in the parlour?’ said they; ‘they who would eat bread should first earn it; away with the kitchen-maid!’ Then they took away her fine clothes, and gave her an old grey frock to put on, and laughed at her, and turned her into the kitchen.
There she was forced to do hard work; to rise early before daylight, to bring the water, to make the fire, to cook and to wash. Besides that, the sisters plagued her in all sorts of ways, and laughed at her. In the evening when she was tired, she had no bed to lie down on, but was made to lie by the hearth among the ashes; and as this, of course, made her always dusty and dirty, they called her Ashputtel.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
The wife of a rich man fell sick; and when she felt that her end drew nigh, she called her only daughter to her bed-side, and said, ‘Always be a good girl, and I will look down from heaven and watch over you.’ Soon afterwards, she died and was buried in the garden. The little girl often visited her mother's grave, wept, and was always good and kind to everyone about her. When the snow covered the grave with a beautiful white blanket, and the cold winter passed, the spring came with its warm sun and blooming flowers.

After this, the father married again. The new wife brought her two daughters, who were fair of face but wicked at heart. They began to torment the poor girl, questioning her, saying, ‘What right have you to sit in the parlor with us? You should be in the kitchen earning your bread!’ They took her fine clothes, gave her an old grey frock, and mocked her, turning her into the kitchen. She was forced to wake before dawn, carry water, tend the fire, cook, and wash. Her stepsisters teased her and called her names. In the evening, when her work was done, she had no bed of her own, but was forced to sleep by the hearth among the ashes, which made her always dusty and dirty. Because of this, they called her Ashputtel.

events.title: The Hazel Twig and the Magical Tree
detailed_summary: On one occasion, the father, planning to attend a fair, asked his wife's daughters what gifts they desired.
The first requested 'Fine clothes,' while the second asked for 'Pearls and diamonds.'
Addressing his own daughter, Ashputtel, he asked for her wish.
She requested the first twig that would brush against his hat as he turned to come homewards.
He purchased the fine clothes, pearls, and diamonds for the stepdaughters.
On his way home, riding through a green copse, a hazel twig struck his hat, nearly dislodging it; he broke off the twig and took it with him.
Upon reaching home, he gave the twig to his daughter.
She took the twig, planted it on her mother's grave, and wept so profusely that her tears watered it.
The twig grew into a fine tree.
Ashputtel visited the tree three times daily and wept; soon, a little bird built its nest on the tree, communicated with her, watched over her, and brought her whatever she wished for.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It happened once that the father was going to the fair, and asked his wife’s daughters what he should bring them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Three times every day she went to it and cried; and soon a little bird came and built its nest upon the tree, and talked with her, and watched over her, and brought her whatever she wished for.

events.text_segment: It happened once that the father was going to the fair, and asked his wife’s daughters what he should bring them. ‘Fine clothes,’ said the first; ‘Pearls and diamonds,’ cried the second. ‘Now, child,’ said he to his own daughter, ‘what will you have?’ ‘The first twig, dear father, that brushes against your hat when you turn your face to come homewards,’ said she. Then he bought for the first two the fine clothes and pearls and diamonds they had asked for: and on his way home, as he rode through a green copse, a hazel twig brushed against him, and almost pushed off his hat: so he broke it off and brought it away; and when he got home he gave it to his daughter. Then she took it, and went to her mother’s grave and planted it there; and cried so much that it was watered with her tears; and there it grew and became a fine tree. Three times every day she went to it and cried; and soon a little bird came and built its nest upon the tree, and talked with her, and watched over her, and brought her whatever she wished for.

events.title: The King's Feast and Ashputtel's Plea for Attendance
detailed_summary: The king of the land announced a feast lasting three days, from which his son would choose a bride.
Ashputtel's two stepsisters were invited to attend.
They summoned Ashputtel, ordering her to comb their hair, brush their shoes, and tie their sashes for the king's feast.
Ashputtel complied, but afterwards, she couldn't help crying because she dearly wished to go to the ball with them.
She persistently begged her stepmother to allow her to go.
The stepmother derided her, pointing out Ashputtel's lack of clothes and inability to dance.
When Ashputtel continued begging, the stepmother, to get rid of her, proposed a challenge: if Ashputtel could pick a dishful of peas from the ash-heap within two hours, she could attend the feast.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘I will throw this dishful of peas into the ash-heap, and if in two hours’ time you have picked them all out, you shall go to the feast too.’

events.text_segment: Now it happened that the king of that land held a feast, which was to last three days; and out of those who came to it his son was to choose a bride for himself. Ashputtel’s two sisters were asked to come; so they called her up, and said, ‘Now, comb our hair, brush our shoes, and tie our sashes for us, for we are going to dance at the king’s feast.’ Then she did as she was told; but when all was done she could not help crying, for she thought to herself, she should so have liked to have gone with them to the ball; and at last she begged her mother very hard to let her go. ‘You, Ashputtel!’ said she; ‘you who have nothing to wear, no clothes at all, and who cannot even dance—you want to go to the ball? And when she kept on begging, she said at last, to get rid of her, ‘I will throw this dishful of peas into the ash-heap, and if in two hours’ time you have picked them all out, you shall go to the feast too.’

They ordered her to comb their hair, brush their shoes, and tie their sashes, so that they might look their best for the king's feast. Ashputtel obeyed, but as she watched her stepsisters depart, she could not help but cry, longing to go with them. She begged her stepmother to let her attend, but was met with scorn. 'You, Ashputtel,' said the stepmother, 'have no fine clothes, and you cannot dance. You would only be a burden.' Still, Ashputtel persisted, and her tears fell fast. To get rid of her, the stepmother proposed a challenge: if Ashputtel could pick a dishful of peas from the ash-heap within two hours, she might go to the feast.

events.title: First Pea-Picking Task, Magical Aid, and Stepmother's Escalating Challenge
detailed_summary: The stepmother scattered the peas into the ashes.
Ashputtel went out the back door into the garden and called for turtle-doves, linnets, blackbirds, thrushes, chaffinches, and all birds to come and help her pick the peas.
Two white doves arrived first at the kitchen window, followed by two turtle-doves, and then all the small birds from heaven, chirping and fluttering.
The birds flew down into the ashes, and the doves began picking, followed by the others.
Collectively, they quickly sorted all the good grain into a dish, leaving the ashes behind.
The task was completed well before the allocated two hours, and all the birds flew out the windows.
Ashputtel, overjoyed at the prospect of attending the ball, brought the dish to her stepmother.
The stepmother, however, dismissed her, stating she had no clothes and couldn't dance, so she would not go.
When Ashputtel pleaded intensely, the stepmother, intending to dissuade her, set a new condition: Ashputtel must pick two dishes of peas from the ashes in one hour to be allowed to go.
The stepmother thought this would finally rid her of Ashputtel's pestering, so she poured two dishes of peas into the ashes.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then she threw the peas down among the ashes, but the little maiden ran out at the back door into the garden, and cried out:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So she shook two dishes of peas into the ashes.

events.text_segment:
Then she threw the peas down among the ashes, but the little maiden ran out at the back door into the garden, and cried out:
‘Hither, hither, through the sky,
  Turtle-doves and linnets, fly!
  Blackbird, thrush, and chaffinch gay,
  Hither, hither, haste away!
  One and all come help me, quick!
  Haste ye, haste ye!—pick, pick, pick!’
Then first came two white doves, flying in at the kitchen window; next came two turtle-doves; and after them came all the little birds under heaven, chirping and fluttering in: and they flew down into the ashes. And the little doves stooped their heads down and set to work, pick, pick, pick; and then the others began to pick, pick, pick: and among them all they soon picked out all the good grain, and put it into a dish but left the ashes. Long before the end of the hour the work was quite done, and all flew out again at the windows.
Then Ashputtel brought the dish to her mother, overjoyed at the thought that now she should go to the ball. But the mother said, ‘No, no! you slut, you have no clothes, and cannot dance; you shall not go.’ And when Ashputtel begged very hard to go, she said, ‘If you can in one hour’s time pick two of those dishes of peas out of the ashes, you shall go too.’ And thus she thought she should at least get rid of her. So she shook two dishes of peas into the ashes.

They carefully gathered all the good grain into the dishes, leaving behind only the ashes. This work was completed swiftly, in less than half an hour, and the birds flew out again. 

Ashputtel, feeling hopeful, took the dishes to her stepmother, rejoicing at the thought that she might now go to the ball. But her stepmother scoffed, saying it was useless—she had no fine clothes, couldn't dance, and would only embarrass them. With that, the stepmother departed for the ball with her two daughters, leaving Ashputtel behind, dreaming of her own chance to attend someday.

---

*Note: The above segment aligns with the opening line and the sequence of events described in the summary, capturing the magical aid of the birds and Ashputtel's hopes.*

events.title: First Night at the Ball: Magical Attire, Royal Dance, and Cunning Escape
detailed_summary: Once everyone had left for the ball, Ashputtel went sadly to the hazel-tree and uttered a charm for gold and silver.
Her avian friend flew from the tree, bringing her a dress of gold and silver and slippers of spangled silk.
She put on the attire and went to the feast, following her sisters.
Her stepsisters did not recognize her, assuming she was a foreign princess due to her fine appearance, taking it for granted that Ashputtel was at home in the dirt.
The king's son approached her, took her hand, and danced exclusively with her, never releasing her hand.
If anyone else asked her to dance, he would state that she was already dancing with him.
They danced late into the night; when she wished to go home, the king's son offered to escort her, wanting to see where she lived.
She managed to slip away from him unnoticed and ran towards home.
As the prince followed, she jumped into the pigeon-house and shut the door.
The prince waited until her father returned and told him the unknown maiden from the feast had hidden there.
However, when they broke open the pigeon-house door, they found no one inside.
Upon returning to the main house, Ashputtel was found lying in her dirty frock by the ashes, her dim lamp burning, having swiftly changed at the hazel-tree and returned her finery to the bird.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: For she had run as quickly as she could through the pigeon-house and on to the hazel-tree, and had there taken off her beautiful clothes, and put them beneath the tree, that the bird might carry them away, and had lain down again amid the ashes in her little grey frock.

events.text_segment:
Now when all were gone, and nobody left at home, Ashputtel went sorrowfully and sat down under the hazel-tree, and cried out:
‘Shake, shake, hazel-tree,
  Gold and silver over me!’
Then her friend the bird flew out of the tree, and brought a gold and silver dress for her, and slippers of spangled silk; and she put them on, and followed her sisters to the feast. But they did not know her, and thought it must be some strange princess, she looked so fine and beautiful in her rich clothes; and they never once thought of Ashputtel, taking it for granted that she was safe at home in the dirt.
The king’s son soon came up to her, and took her by the hand and danced with her, and no one else: and he never left her hand; but when anyone else came to ask her to dance, he said, ‘This lady is dancing with me.’
Thus they danced till a late hour of the night; and then she wanted to go home: and the king’s son said, ‘I shall go and take care of you to your home’; for he wanted to see where the beautiful maiden lived. But she slipped away from him, unawares, and ran off towards home; and as the prince followed her, she jumped up into the pigeon-house and shut the door. Then he waited till her father came home, and told him that the unknown maiden, who had been at the feast, had hid herself in the pigeon-house. But when they had broken open the door they found no one within; and as they came back into the house, Ashputtel was lying, as she always did, in her dirty frock by the ashes, and her dim little lamp was burning in the chimney. For she had run as quickly as she could through the pigeon-house and on to the hazel-tree, and had there taken off her beautiful clothes, and put them beneath the tree, that the bird might carry them away, and had lain down again amid the ashes in her little grey frock.
