events.text_segment:
The next day when the feast was again held, and her father, mother, and sisters were gone, Ashputtel went to the hazel-tree, and said:
‘Shake, shake, hazel-tree,
  Gold and silver over me!’
And the bird came and brought a still finer dress than the one she had worn the day before. And when she came in it to the ball, everyone wondered at her beauty: but the king’s son, who was waiting for her, took her by the hand, and danced with her; and when anyone asked her to dance, he said as before, ‘This lady is dancing with me.’
When night came she wanted to go home; and the king’s son followed here as before, that he might see into what house she went: but she sprang away from him all at once into the garden behind her father’s house. In this garden stood a fine large pear-tree full of ripe fruit; and Ashputtel, not knowing where to hide herself, jumped up into it without being seen. Then the king’s son lost sight of her, and could not find out where she was gone, but waited till her father came home, and said to him, ‘The unknown lady who danced with me has slipped away, and I think she must have sprung into the pear-tree.’ The father thought to himself, ‘Can it be Ashputtel?’ So he had an axe brought; and they cut down the tree, but found no one upon it. And when they came back into the kitchen, there lay Ashputtel among the ashes; for she had slipped down on the other side of the tree, and carried her beautiful clothes back to the bird at the hazel-tree, and then put on her little grey frock.

events.title: The Slipper Test: Stepsisters' Mutilation, Deception, and Exposure by the Dove
detailed_summary: Both stepsisters were overjoyed to hear the prince's vow, as they had beautiful feet and were confident they could wear the golden slipper.
The eldest went first into the room where the slipper was, with her mother standing by, intending to try it on.
However, her great toe could not fit into it, and the shoe was far too small for her overall.
Her mother gave her a knife, advising her to cut off her toe, reasoning that as a queen, she wouldn't need to walk or care about toes.
The girl cut off her great toe, squeezed her foot into the shoe, and went to the king's son.
He took her as his bride, set her beside him on his horse, and rode away with her homewards.
On their way, they had to pass the hazel-tree Ashputtel had planted, where a little dove on a branch sang a warning about the shoe being too small and bloodied, revealing she was not the true bride.
The prince dismounted, looked at her foot, and saw from the streaming blood the trick she had played.
He turned his horse around, brought the false bride back to her home, and stated she was not the right one, requesting the other sister try the slipper.
The second sister went into the room and managed to get her foot into the shoe, except for her heel, which was too large.
Her mother forced her heel in until blood came, and then took her to the king's son.
He set her as his bride by his side on his horse and rode away with her.
When they came to the hazel-tree, the little dove was still there and sang the same warning about the shoe and the false bride.
The prince looked down and saw so much blood streaming from the shoe that her white stockings were quite red.
So he turned his horse and brought her also back again.

events.text_segment:
Then both the sisters were overjoyed to hear it; for they had beautiful feet, and had no doubt that they could wear the golden slipper. The eldest went first into the room where the slipper was, and wanted to try it on, and the mother stood by. But her great toe could not go into it, and the shoe was altogether much too small for her. Then the mother gave her a knife, and said, ‘Never mind, cut it off; when you are queen you will not care about toes; you will not want to walk.’ So the silly girl cut off her great toe, and thus squeezed on the shoe, and went to the king’s son. Then he took her for his bride, and set her beside him on his horse, and rode away with her homewards.
But on their way home they had to pass by the hazel-tree that Ashputtel had planted; and on the branch sat a little dove singing:
‘Back again! back again! look to the shoe!
  The shoe is too small, and not made for you!
  Prince! prince! look again for thy bride,
  For she’s not the true one that sits by thy side.’
Then the prince got down and looked at her foot; and he saw, by the blood that streamed from it, what a trick she had played him. So he turned his horse round, and brought the false bride back to her home, and said, ‘This is not the right bride; let the other sister try and put on the slipper.’ Then she went into the room and got her foot into the shoe, all but the heel, which was too large. But her mother squeezed it in till the blood came, and took her to the king’s son: and he set her as his bride by his side on his horse, and rode away with her.
But when they came to the hazel-tree the little dove sat there still, and sang:
‘Back again! back again! look to the shoe!
  The shoe is too small, and not made for you!
  Prince! prince! look again for thy bride,
  For she’s not the true one that sits by thy side.’
Then he looked down, and saw that the blood streamed so much from the shoe, that her white stockings were quite red. So he turned his horse and brought her also back again.

The stepmother protested, saying Ashputtel was far too dirty and would not dare show herself.
However, the prince was resolute in wanting her to come.
Ashputtel first washed her face and hands, then went in and curtsied to him, and he handed her the golden slipper.
She removed her clumsy shoe from her left foot and put on the golden slipper, which fitted her perfectly, as if it had been made for her.
When the prince drew near and looked at her face, he recognized her and declared, 'This is the right bride.'
The stepmother and both sisters were frightened and turned pale with anger as he took Ashputtel on his horse and rode away with her.
As they came to the hazel-tree, the white dove sang a song confirming the shoe was made for her, she was a princess, and the true bride by the prince's side.
After finishing its song, the dove flew down, perched upon Ashputtel's right shoulder, and accompanied her home.

events.text_segment:
‘This is not the true bride,’ said he to the father; ‘have you no other daughters?’ ‘No,’ said he; ‘there is only a little dirty Ashputtel here, the child of my first wife; I am sure she cannot be the bride.’ The prince told him to send her. But the mother said, ‘No, no, she is much too dirty; she will not dare to show herself.’ However, the prince would have her come; and she first washed her face and hands, and then went in and curtsied to him, and he reached her the golden slipper. Then she took her clumsy shoe off her left foot, and put on the golden slipper; and it fitted her as if it had been made for her. And when he drew near and looked at her face he knew her, and said, ‘This is the right bride.’ But the mother and both the sisters were frightened, and turned pale with anger as he took Ashputtel on his horse, and rode away with her. And when they came to the hazel-tree, the white dove sang:
‘Home! home! look at the shoe!
  Princess! the shoe was made for you!
  Prince! prince! take home thy bride,
  For she is the true one that sits by thy side!’
And when the dove had done its song, it came flying, and perched upon her right shoulder, and so went home with her.

events.title: The King's Mysterious Daily Dish
detailed_summary: A long time ago, a king renowned for his profound wisdom ruled his land.
It appeared that no secrets were kept from him, as if information about the most confidential matters was mysteriously conveyed to him.
This king, however, maintained a peculiar daily practice.
Every day after dinner, when the dining table was cleared and all other attendees had departed, a loyal servant was tasked with bringing him one final dish.
This dish was always presented covered, and its contents were unknown even to the servant who delivered it.
The king would only remove the cover and consume its contents when he was entirely by himself, ensuring the nature of this meal remained a complete mystery to everyone else.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was covered, however, and even the servant did not know what was in it, neither did anyone know, for the king never took off the cover to eat of it until he was quite alone.

But he had a strange custom; every day after dinner, when the table was cleared, and no one else was present, a trusty servant had to bring him one more dish. It was covered, however, and even the servant did not know what was in it, neither did anyone know, for the king never took off the cover to eat of it until he was quite alone.

events.title: The Servant's Discovery and Acquired Animal Speech
detailed_summary: This routine continued for an extended period until one day, the servant responsible for removing the special dish was overcome by intense curiosity.
He found himself unable to resist the urge and secretly carried the covered dish into his own room.
After carefully securing the door, he lifted the cover of the dish.
Upon doing so, he discovered a white snake lying on it.
The sight of the snake was compelling, and he could not resist tasting it.
He cut off a small portion of the snake and placed it in his mouth.
The moment the piece of snake touched his tongue, he heard peculiar, soft whispering voices originating from outside his window.
He approached the window to listen more closely and discerned that it was sparrows chattering amongst themselves.
The sparrows were discussing various things they had observed in the fields and forests.
The act of eating the snake had bestowed upon him the ability to understand the language of animals.

No sooner had it touched his tongue than he heard a strange whispering of little voices outside his window. He went and listened, and then noticed that it was the sparrows who were chattering together, and telling one another of all kinds of things which they had seen in the fields and woods. Eating the snake had given him power of understanding the language of animals.

events.title: Accusation, Animal Aid, and Exoneration
detailed_summary: Coincidentally, on that very same day, the queen misplaced her most cherished and beautiful ring.
Suspicion for the theft quickly fell upon the trusted servant, as his duties allowed him access to all areas of the palace.
The king summoned the servant and angrily threatened him with execution if he could not identify the actual thief by the following day.
The servant's declarations of innocence were futile; he was dismissed without any favorable resolution.
Overwhelmed with distress and fear, he descended into the courtyard, desperately trying to devise a plan to escape his predicament.
He noticed some ducks resting quietly by a brook, preening their feathers and engaging in what seemed like a private conversation.
The servant stood nearby and listened intently, now able to understand their discussion.
The ducks were recounting their morning activities, the places they had waddled, and the good food they had found.
One duck then complained in a pitiful tone about a heavy feeling in its stomach, admitting it had hastily swallowed a ring found beneath the queen’s window while eating.
Recognizing the opportunity, the servant immediately grabbed the duck by its neck and carried it to the kitchen.
He instructed the cook to kill and prepare the duck.
The cook, after weighing the duck, remarked on its plumpness, noting it seemed well-fattened and ready for roasting.
The cook then decapitated the duck, and as it was being prepared for cooking, the queen’s lost ring was discovered inside it.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So he cut off her head, and as she was being dressed for the spit, the queen’s ring was found inside her.

events.text_segment:
Now it so happened that on this very day the queen lost her most beautiful ring, and suspicion of having stolen it fell upon this trusty servant, who was allowed to go everywhere. The king ordered the man to be brought before him, and threatened with angry words that unless he could before the morrow point out the thief, he himself should be looked upon as guilty and executed. In vain he declared his innocence; he was dismissed with no better answer.
In his trouble and fear he went down into the courtyard and took thought how to help himself out of his trouble. Now some ducks were sitting together quietly by a brook and taking their rest; and, whilst they were making their feathers smooth with their bills, they were having a confidential conversation together. The servant stood by and listened. They were telling one another of all the places where they had been waddling about all the morning, and what good food they had found; and one said in a pitiful tone: ‘Something lies heavy on my stomach; as I was eating in haste I swallowed a ring which lay under the queen’s window.’ The servant at once seized her by the neck, carried her to the kitchen, and said to the cook: ‘Here is a fine duck; pray, kill her.’ ‘Yes,’ said the cook, and weighed her in his hand; ‘she has spared no trouble to fatten herself, and has been waiting to be roasted long enough.’ So he cut off her head, and as she was being dressed for the spit, the queen’s ring was found inside her.

As he wandered in the courtyard, he noticed some ducks resting by a brook, preening and chatting among themselves. Listening closely, he understood that they had been discussing their morning activities, including one duck lamenting a heavy feeling in its stomach after swallowing something shiny. Recognizing the opportunity, the servant seized the duck and took it to the kitchen, instructing the cook to prepare it. The cook, noticing the duck's plumpness, decided to roast it, and during the preparation, the queen’s missing ring was found inside the duck, thus revealing the thief.

The servant, overwhelmed with fear and shame, swore he was innocent and begged for a chance to find the ring. The queen, moved by his distress, decided to give him a day to search thoroughly. As the hours passed, the servant searched high and low, in every corner of the palace, but the ring was nowhere to be found. Meanwhile, the queen's heart grew heavier with worry and doubt.

That evening, as the servant sat in despair, an old woman who was passing by noticed his sorrow and asked what troubled him. He explained his plight, and she listened carefully. Then, she told him a secret: the ring was not stolen but had slipped into a hidden pocket of his coat when he was helping the queen with her jewelry.

The servant, surprised and grateful, hurried to show the old woman his coat. Sure enough, the ring was found tucked away. Overjoyed, he returned the ring to the queen, who was relieved and pleased. She realized her servant was honest and true, and she praised him for his integrity.

From that day on, the servant was held in even higher regard, and the queen learned to trust her faithful servant more deeply. The story spread throughout the land, reminding everyone that honesty and patience are virtues that always lead to the truth and happiness.

events.title: A Royal Pardon, a Humble Request, and a Lifesaving Act
detailed_summary: With the ring recovered from the duck, the servant was able to convincingly demonstrate his innocence.
The king, seeking to compensate for the injustice, granted the servant permission to ask for any favor, even offering him the most prestigious position in the royal court he might desire.
The servant, however, declined all offers of courtly advancement.
Instead, he requested only a horse and some money for travel, expressing a wish to see the world and journey a little.
His modest request was granted, and he embarked on his travels.
One day, his journey led him to a pond where he observed three fish ensnared in the reeds, gasping desperately for water.
Although fish are generally considered silent, he could hear them lamenting their imminent and miserable demise.
Possessing a compassionate nature, he dismounted his horse and carefully returned the three trapped fish to the water.
The fish, filled with joy at their rescue, surfaced, put their heads out of the water, and called out to him, promising to remember his deed and repay him for saving their lives.

They leapt with delight, put out their heads, and cried to him: ‘We will remember you and repay you for saving us!’

events.title: An Inadvertent Threat and a Considerate Diversion
detailed_summary: The servant continued his journey on horseback.
After some time, he perceived a voice seemingly emanating from the sand at his feet.
He listened closely and understood it to be an ant-king complaining.

The ant-king lamented how people and their large animals carelessly disregarded ant colonies, specifically mentioning that the servant's 'stupid horse' was mercilessly trampling his ant subjects with its heavy hooves.
Upon hearing this, the servant immediately guided his horse onto a side path to avoid further disturbance to the ants.
The ant-king then called out to him, expressing gratitude and vowing that the ants would remember his considerate action, affirming the principle that one good deed begets another.

events.text_segment: He rode on, and after a while it seemed to him that he heard a voice in the sand at his feet. He listened, and heard an ant-king complain: ‘Why cannot folks, with their clumsy beasts, keep off our bodies? That stupid horse, with his heavy hoofs, has been treading down my people without mercy!’ So he turned on to a side path and the ant-king cried out to him: ‘We will remember you—one good turn deserves another!’

events.title: A Sacrifice for the Starving Ravens
detailed_summary: The side path eventually led the servant into a dense wood.
There, he witnessed a scene where two parent ravens were standing by their nest and forcibly ejecting their young ones.
The old ravens cried out to their offspring, calling them idle and worthless, stating they could no longer provide food for them and that the young birds were now large enough to fend for themselves.
The poor young ravens, however, lay on the ground, feebly flapping their wings and crying out in distress.
They lamented their helplessness, acknowledging their inability to fly and their predicament of being left to starve.
Moved by their plight, the kind young man (the servant) dismounted, drew his sword, and killed his own horse.
He then offered the horse's carcass to the starving young ravens as food.

The young ravens eagerly hopped towards the unexpected meal, ate until they were satisfied, and then cried out to him, promising to remember his sacrifice and repay his kindness, echoing the sentiment that one good turn deserves another.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The path led him into a wood, and there he saw two old ravens standing by their nest, and throwing out their young ones.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they came hopping up to it, satisfied their hunger, and cried: ‘We will remember you—one good turn deserves another!’

events.text_segment: The path led him into a wood, and there he saw two old ravens standing by their nest, and throwing out their young ones. ‘Out with you, you idle, good-for-nothing creatures!’ cried they; ‘we cannot find food for you any longer; you are big enough, and can provide for yourselves.’ But the poor young ravens lay upon the ground, flapping their wings, and crying: ‘Oh, what helpless chicks we are! We must shift for ourselves, and yet we cannot fly! What can we do, but lie here and starve?’ So the good young fellow alighted and killed his horse with his sword, and gave it to them for food. Then they came hopping up to it, satisfied their hunger, and cried: ‘We will remember you—one good turn deserves another!’

events.title: Arrival in the City and the Princess's Perilous Challenge
detailed_summary: Having sacrificed his horse, the young man now had to continue his journey on foot.
After walking a considerable distance, he arrived at a large city.
The city streets were filled with a great deal of noise and a large crowd of people.
A man on horseback rode through the streets, loudly proclaiming a message: the king's daughter was seeking a husband.
However, any man who wished to marry her first had to complete a formidable task.
The announcer also warned that failure to succeed in this task would result in the forfeiture of the suitor's life.
Many men had previously attempted the challenge but had all failed, losing their lives in the process.
Despite these grim accounts, when the youth saw the king's daughter, he was so struck by her immense beauty that all thoughts of danger vanished from his mind.
He went before the king and formally declared himself as a suitor for the princess's hand.
Subsequently, he was escorted to the seashore.
In his presence, a gold ring was cast into the sea.

The king then commanded him to retrieve this ring from the ocean floor, adding a dire warning: if he resurfaced without the ring, he would be repeatedly thrown back into the sea until he drowned among the waves.
All the onlookers felt sorrow for the handsome youth as they departed, leaving him isolated by the sea.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: All the people grieved for the handsome youth; then they went away, leaving him alone by the sea.

events.text_segment:
And now he had to use his own legs, and when he had walked a long way, he came to a large city. There was a great noise and crowd in the streets, and a man rode up on horseback, crying aloud: ‘The king’s daughter wants a husband; but whoever seeks her hand must perform a hard task, and if he does not succeed he will forfeit his life.’ Many had already made the attempt, but in vain; nevertheless when the youth saw the king’s daughter he was so overcome by her great beauty that he forgot all danger, went before the king, and declared himself a suitor.
So he was led out to the sea, and a gold ring was thrown into it, before his eyes; then the king ordered him to fetch this ring up from the bottom of the sea, and added: ‘If you come up again without it you will be thrown in again and again until you perish amid the waves.’ All the people grieved for the handsome youth; then they went away, leaving him alone by the sea.

events.title: The Fishes' Repayment: Retrieval of the Sunken Ring
detailed_summary: The youth stood on the shore, contemplating his seemingly impossible task and what course of action he should take.
As he pondered, he suddenly observed three fish swimming towards him through the water.
He recognized them as the very same three fish whose lives he had saved earlier by returning them to the pond.
The fish in the middle was holding a mussel in its mouth.
It approached the shore and deposited the mussel at the youth's feet.
The youth picked up the mussel and opened it.
Inside the shell, he discovered the gold ring that had been thrown into the sea.
Overcome with joy, he took the ring and went to the king, anticipating that he would now be granted the promised reward for completing the task.

events.title: The Princess's Second Task and the Ants' Meticulous Aid
detailed_summary: However, when the proud princess observed that the youth was not her social equal in terms of birth or status, she looked down on him.
Despite his success with the first task, she demanded that he perform another one before she would consider him.
She descended into the royal garden and, with her own hands, scattered ten sacks full of millet-seed across the grass.
She then instructed the youth that all these seeds must be collected by the following morning before sunrise, with not a single grain left behind.
The youth sat down in the garden, deeply troubled, as he tried to figure out how he could possibly accomplish such a feat.
He could devise no solution and sat there in sorrow, awaiting the dawn which he believed would bring his execution.
But as the very first rays of sunlight touched the garden, he looked up and saw all ten sacks standing neatly side by side, completely full, and not one grain of millet was missing from them.
The ant-king had arrived during the night, accompanied by thousands upon thousands of ants.

These grateful creatures had diligently worked throughout the night, picking up every single millet-seed and carefully gathering them into the sacks, thereby repaying the youth for his earlier kindness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But when the proud princess perceived that he was not her equal in birth, she scorned him, and required him first to perform another task.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The ant-king had come in the night with thousands and thousands of ants, and the grateful creatures had by great industry picked up all the millet-seed and gathered them into the sacks.

events.text_segment:
But when the proud princess perceived that he was not her equal in birth, she scorned him, and required him first to perform another task. She went down into the garden and strewed with her own hands ten sacksful of millet-seed on the grass; then she said: ‘Tomorrow morning before sunrise these must be picked up, and not a single grain be wanting.’
The youth sat down in the garden and considered how it might be possible to perform this task, but he could think of nothing, and there he sat sorrowfully awaiting the break of day, when he should be led to death. But as soon as the first rays of the sun shone into the garden he saw all the ten sacks standing side by side, quite full, and not a single grain was missing. The ant-king had come in the night with thousands and thousands of ants, and the grateful creatures had by great industry picked up all the millet-seed and gathered them into the sacks.

events.title: The Final Quest for the Apple of Life and a Joyful Union
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, the king's daughter herself came down to the garden.
She was astounded to witness that the young man had successfully completed the difficult task she had assigned him.
Despite this, her proud heart was not yet won over, and she declared that although he had performed both tasks, he would not become her husband until he brought her an apple from the Tree of Life.

The youth had no knowledge of where the Tree of Life was located, but he set out on the quest anyway, prepared to walk indefinitely, as long as his legs could carry him, even though he held little hope of finding it.
After journeying through three different kingdoms, he arrived one evening in a wood and lay down beneath a tree to rest and sleep.
While resting, he heard a rustling sound in the branches above him, and a golden apple fell directly into his hand.
At that very moment, three ravens flew down to him and perched on his knee.
They identified themselves as the three young ravens whom he had saved from starvation.
They explained that once they had grown large and strong, they heard about his quest for the Golden Apple.
Consequently, they had flown across the sea to the very end of the world, where the Tree of Life stands, and had brought back the apple for him.
The youth, filled with immense joy, began his journey homeward.
He presented the Golden Apple to the king's beautiful daughter, who now had no further excuses to refuse him.
Together, they cut the Apple of Life in two and ate it.
Upon eating the apple, the princess's heart was filled with love for him, and they lived together in undisturbed happiness to a very old age.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They cut the Apple of Life in two and ate it together; and then her heart became full of love for him, and they lived in undisturbed happiness to a great age.

They cut the Apple of Life in two and ate it together; and then her heart became full of love for him, and they lived in undisturbed happiness to a great age.

The youth, knowing not where the Tree of Life was, set out on his quest, prepared to walk endlessly, even without hope of finding it. After traveling through three kingdoms, he arrived one evening in a wood and lay down beneath a tree to rest. As he rested, he heard a rustling in the branches above, and a golden apple fell into his hand. At that moment, three ravens flew down and perched themselves upon his knee. They revealed themselves as the three ravens he had once saved from starvation, and explained that after they had grown large and strong, they heard about his quest for the Tree of Life, and had flown across the sea to the very end of the world, where the Tree of Life stands, bringing back the apple for him. Filled with joy, he began his journey homeward, and presented the apple to the princess. She had no further excuses to refuse him. They cut the apple in two and ate it. Upon eating the apple, her heart was filled with love for him, and they lived together in happiness to a very old age.

chapters.chapter_title: THE WOLF AND THE SEVEN LITTLE KIDS

events.title: Mother Goat's Warning and Departure
detailed_summary: A mother goat, who deeply loved her seven young children, needed to go into the forest to find food.
She gathered all seven kids and warned them to be vigilant against the wolf.
She emphasized that if the wolf got inside, he would eat them completely—skin, hair, and all.
The mother explained that the wolf frequently used disguises but could be identified by his harsh voice and black feet.
The little kids assured their mother they would be very careful and told her she could leave without any worry.
Satisfied, the old goat bleated and left, feeling confident in her children's safety.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once upon a time an old goat who had seven little kids, and loved them with all the love of a mother for her children.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the old one bleated, and went on her way with an easy mind.

events.text_segment: There was once upon a time an old goat who had seven little kids, and loved them with all the love of a mother for her children. One day she wanted to go into the forest and fetch some food. So she called all seven to her and said: ‘Dear children, I have to go into the forest, be on your guard against the wolf; if he comes in, he will devour you all—skin, hair, and everything. The wretch often disguises himself, but you will know him at once by his rough voice and his black feet.’ The kids said: ‘Dear mother, we will take good care of ourselves; you may go away without any anxiety.’ Then the old one bleated, and went on her way with an easy mind.

Be careful, and do not open the door to anyone but me. The wolf is very cunning, and he might try to deceive you. If he comes, listen to his voice and look at his feet. If his voice is harsh and his feet are black, then it is the wolf, and you must not let him in." The little kids promised to be careful and said, "Mother, we will be very cautious and will not open the door to anyone but you." The mother goat then bleated and went away, leaving her children safe and sound.

events.title: The Wolf's Disguise: Softened Voice and Whitened Paws
detailed_summary: The wolf then went to a shopkeeper, bought a large piece of chalk, and ate it to make his voice softer.
He returned to the kids' house, knocked, and again pretended to be their mother with gifts.
However, the wolf had placed his black paws on the window, and the children saw them.
They cried out that they would not open, as their mother did not have black feet like his, again identifying him as the wolf.
The wolf then ran to a baker, claiming he had injured his feet and asked for dough to be rubbed on them.
After the baker applied the dough, the wolf went to a miller and demanded white meal be sprinkled on his feet.
The miller suspected the wolf's deceitful intentions and initially refused.
The wolf threatened to devour the miller if he did not comply.
Frightened, the miller whitened the wolf's paws, reflecting that this kind of deception was common among people.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then the wolf went away to a shopkeeper and bought himself a great lump of chalk, ate this and made his voice soft with it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Truly, this is the way of mankind.

events.text_segment: Then the wolf went away to a shopkeeper and bought himself a great lump of chalk, ate this and made his voice soft with it. Then he came back, knocked at the door of the house, and called: ‘Open the door, dear children, your mother is here and has brought something back with her for each of you.’ But the wolf had laid his black paws against the window, and the children saw them and cried: ‘We will not open the door, our mother has not black feet like you: you are the wolf!’ Then the wolf ran to a baker and said: ‘I have hurt my feet, rub some dough over them for me.’ And when the baker had rubbed his feet over, he ran to the miller and said: ‘Strew some white meal over my feet for me.’ The miller thought to himself: ‘The wolf wants to deceive someone,’ and refused; but the wolf said: ‘If you will not do it, I will devour you.’ Then the miller was afraid, and made his paws white for him. Truly, this is the way of mankind.

events.title: The Wolf Deceives and Devours the Kids
detailed_summary: The deceitful wolf approached the house for the third time, knocked, and announced he was their dear mother, back from the forest with a gift for each of them.
The little kids requested to see his paws first to verify his identity.
He showed his whitened paws through the window.
Believing it was truly their mother because of the white paws, the kids opened the door.
To their horror, the wolf entered, causing them to scatter and try to hide.
One hid under the table, the second in the bed, the third in the stove, the fourth in the kitchen, the fifth in the cupboard, the sixth under the washing-bowl, and the seventh in the clock-case.
The wolf found them all without much effort and swallowed six of them one by one.
Only the youngest kid, hidden in the clock-case, was not found by the wolf.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So now the wretch went for the third time to the house-door, knocked at it and said: ‘Open the door for me, children, your dear little mother has come home, and has brought every one of you something back from the forest with her.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The youngest, who was in the clock-case, was the only one he did not find.

events.text_segment: So now the wretch went for the third time to the house-door, knocked at it and said: ‘Open the door for me, children, your dear little mother has come home, and has brought every one of you something back from the forest with her.’ The little kids cried: ‘First show us your paws that we may know if you are our dear little mother.’ Then he put his paws in through the window and when the kids saw that they were white, they believed that all he said was true, and opened the door. But who should come in but the wolf! They were terrified and wanted to hide themselves. One sprang under the table, the second into the bed, the third into the stove, the fourth into the kitchen, the fifth into the cupboard, the sixth under the washing-bowl, and the seventh into the clock-case. But the wolf found them all, and used no great ceremony; one after the other he swallowed them down his throat. The youngest, who was in the clock-case, was the only one he did not find.

events.title: Mother Goat's Return and Heartbreak
detailed_summary: Once the wolf had eaten his fill, he left, lay down under a tree in a nearby green meadow, and fell asleep.
Shortly thereafter, the mother goat returned from the forest.
She encountered a terrible sight: the house door was wide open.
The table, chairs, and benches were knocked over, the washing-bowl was smashed, and the bed covers were pulled off.
She searched for her children but could not find them anywhere.
She called each of them by name, but none answered.
Finally, when she called the youngest, a soft voice responded, saying, 'Dear mother, I am in the clock-case.'
She took the kid out, and he told her that the wolf had come and eaten all the others.
One can only imagine the extent of her weeping for her unfortunate children.

The table, chairs, and benches were thrown down, the washing-bowl lay broken to pieces, and the quilts and pillows were pulled off the bed. She sought her children, but they were nowhere to be found. She called them one after another by name, but no one answered. At last, when she came to the youngest, a soft voice cried: ‘Dear mother, I am in the clock-case.’ She took the kid out, and it told her that the wolf had come and had eaten all the others. Then you may imagine how she wept over her poor children.

The girl, feeling sorry for him, decided to help. She ran to her grandmother's house and brought some bread and milk. When she returned, she shared her food with the wolf, who was very grateful. From that day on, the wolf and the girl became friends, and he promised never to harm anyone again. They often played together in the meadow, enjoying the sunshine and the fresh air, and everyone in the village learned to see the wolf in a new light.

events.title: The Miraculous Rescue of the Swallowed Kids
detailed_summary: Eventually, in her deep sorrow, she went outside, and the youngest kid accompanied her.
When they reached the meadow, they saw the wolf lying by the tree, snoring so loudly that the branches shook.
She examined him from all angles and noticed movement and struggling within his swollen belly.
A hopeful thought struck her: 'Oh heavens, could my poor children, whom he swallowed for supper, still be alive?'
The youngest kid was then instructed to hurry home and fetch scissors, a needle, and thread.
The mother goat carefully cut open the sleeping monster's stomach.
She had barely made the first incision when one little kid poked its head out.
As she cut further, all six kids emerged one after another, all alive and unharmed because the greedy monster had swallowed them whole.
There was tremendous rejoicing; they hugged their dear mother and jumped around like a tailor at his wedding.
The mother then said, 'Now go find some large stones, and we will fill the wicked beast’s stomach with them while he is still asleep.'
The seven kids quickly gathered stones and filled the wolf's stomach with as many as they could fit.
The mother then sewed him up very quickly, so that he remained unaware and did not stir at all.

events.text_segment: At length in her grief she went out, and the youngest kid ran with her. When they came to the meadow, there lay the wolf by the tree and snored so loud that the branches shook. She looked at him on every side and saw that something was moving and struggling in his gorged belly. ‘Ah, heavens,’ she said, ‘is it possible that my poor children whom he has swallowed down for his supper, can be still alive?’ Then the kid had to run home and fetch scissors, and a needle and thread, and the goat cut open the monster’s stomach, and hardly had she made one cut, than one little kid thrust its head out, and when she had cut farther, all six sprang out one after another, and were all still alive, and had suffered no injury whatever, for in his greediness the monster had swallowed them down whole. What rejoicing there was! They embraced their dear mother, and jumped like a tailor at his wedding. The mother, however, said: ‘Now go and look for some big stones, and we will fill the wicked beast’s stomach with them while he is still asleep.’ Then the seven kids dragged the stones thither with all speed, and put as many of them into this stomach as they could get in; and the mother sewed him up again in the greatest haste, so that he was not aware of anything and never once stirred.

The old woman, seeing her sorrow, asked what troubled her. The girl poured out her heart, telling of her lost children and her despair. The wise woman listened patiently and then handed her a small, shining box. "Open this only when you are truly in need," she advised. Grateful yet uncertain, the girl took the box and continued her journey. As she walked, she felt a strange warmth emanating from it, a promise of hope and comfort. Days passed, and her grief remained heavy, but she kept the box close. One day, she found herself in a dark, tangled thicket, feeling hopeless and lost. Remembering the wise woman's words, she opened the box. To her astonishment, a gentle light spilled out, illuminating her path and revealing a clear way through the woods. With renewed courage, she followed the light, eventually reaching her home. There, she found her children safe and sound, waiting for her with joyful smiles. The girl realized that the box contained not gold or jewels, but hope and faith, which helped her endure her sorrow and find her way back to happiness.

events.title: The Wolf's Demise and Joyful Celebration
detailed_summary: When the wolf finally woke up after sleeping soundly, he got to his feet.
The stones in his stomach made him extremely thirsty, so he wanted to go to a well to drink.
However, as he began to walk and move, the stones in his stomach knocked against each other and rattled.
He then cried out, wondering what was rumbling and tumbling against his poor bones, thinking it was the six kids but feeling like big stones.
When he reached the well and bent over the water to drink, the heavy stones caused him to fall in, and he drowned miserably.
Upon seeing this, the seven kids ran to the spot, shouting joyfully, 'The wolf is dead! The wolf is dead!'
They danced with their mother in celebration around the well.

events.text_segment:
When the wolf at length had had his fill of sleep, he got on his legs, and as the stones in his stomach made him very thirsty, he wanted to go to a well to drink. But when he began to walk and to move about, the stones in his stomach knocked against each other and rattled. Then cried he:
‘What rumbles and tumbles
  Against my poor bones?
  I thought ‘twas six kids,
  But it feels like big stones.’
And when he got to the well and stooped over the water to drink, the heavy stones made him fall in, and he drowned miserably. When the seven kids saw that, they came running to the spot and cried aloud: ‘The wolf is dead! The wolf is dead!’ and danced for joy round about the well with their mother.

events.title: The Dwarf's Compassionate Interventions on the Journey
detailed_summary: Two princes, having become profligate and impoverished, found themselves unable to go back to their kingdom.
Their younger brother, a small and unassuming dwarf, embarked on a journey to find his lost siblings.
Upon their reunion, the elder brothers ridiculed the dwarf, doubting his capacity to navigate the world when they, supposedly wiser, had failed.
Despite the mockery, all three set out together and eventually reached an ant-hill.
The two older brothers intended to dismantle the ant-hill merely to observe the ants scurrying in panic with their eggs.
However, the little dwarf intervened, asking them to let the ants be and stating he would not permit them to disturb the creatures.
Continuing their journey, they arrived at a lake where numerous ducks were swimming.
The two brothers expressed a desire to capture and roast a pair of ducks.
Once more, the dwarf stepped in, pleading for the ducks' lives and insisting they should not be killed.
Their travels then led them to a bees' nest situated in a hollow tree, from which honey flowed abundantly down the trunk.
The elder brothers proposed starting a fire beneath the tree to eliminate the bees and seize their honey.
The dwarf again prevented their actions, asserting that the insects should be allowed to live and that he could not let them be burned.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Two kings’ sons once upon a time went into the world to seek their fortunes; but they soon fell into a wasteful foolish way of living, so that they could not return home again.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But the dwarf held them back, and said, ‘Let the pretty insects enjoy themselves, I cannot let you burn them.’

events.text_segment:
Two kings’ sons once upon a time went into the world to seek their fortunes; but they soon fell into a wasteful foolish way of living, so that they could not return home again. Then their brother, who was a little insignificant dwarf, went out to seek for his brothers: but when he had found them they only laughed at him, to think that he, who was so young and simple, should try to travel through the world, when they, who were so much wiser, had been unable to get on. However, they all set out on their journey together, and came at last to an ant-hill. The two elder brothers would have pulled it down, in order to see how the poor ants in their fright would run about and carry off their eggs. But the little dwarf said, ‘Let the poor things enjoy themselves, I will not suffer you to trouble them.’
So on they went, and came to a lake where many many ducks were swimming about. The two brothers wanted to catch two, and roast them. But the dwarf said, ‘Let the poor things enjoy themselves, you shall not kill them.’ Next they came to a bees’-nest in a hollow tree, and there was so much honey that it ran down the trunk; and the two brothers wanted to light a fire under the tree and kill the bees, so as to get their honey. But the dwarf held them back, and said, ‘Let the pretty insects enjoy themselves, I cannot let you burn them.’

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Two kings’ sons once upon a time went into the world to seek their fortunes; but they soon fell into a wasteful foolish way of living, so that they could not return home again.

Now, these two princes, having squandered their wealth and lost their way, found themselves impoverished and unable to go back to their kingdom. Meanwhile, their younger brother, a small and unassuming dwarf, set out on a journey to find his lost siblings.

After some time, the three brothers met again. The elder brothers, seeing the dwarf, mocked him, doubting his ability to survive in the world when they, who considered themselves wiser, had failed. Despite their ridicule, they all decided to continue their journey together.

Their first notable stop was at an ant-hill. The elder brothers wanted to destroy it just to see the ants scurry about in panic with their eggs. But the dwarf intervened, asking them to leave the ants alone, saying he would not permit them to harm the creatures.

Further along, they reached a lake filled with ducks swimming peacefully. The elder brothers expressed a desire to catch and roast some ducks for food. The dwarf again stepped in, pleading for the lives of the ducks and insisting they should not be killed.

Finally, they arrived at a bees' nest in a hollow tree, from which honey was flowing down the trunk. The elder brothers proposed to set fire to the tree to kill the bees and take the honey. But the dwarf once more prevented them, asserting that the insects should be allowed to live and that he could not allow them to be burned.

events.title: Arrival at the Silent Castle and Encounter with the Grey Old Man
characters: Three brothers (the two elder, the little dwarf)
detailed_summary: The three brothers eventually reached a castle.
As they passed the stables, they observed magnificent horses, all of which were made of marble, and there was no sign of any person.
They proceeded through all the rooms of the castle until they arrived at a door secured with three locks.
A small opening, a wicket, in the center of this door allowed them to peer into the adjacent room.
Inside, they saw a small, elderly man with grey hair sitting at a table.
They called out to him once or twice without response, but upon their third call, he rose and came out to meet them.

There they saw a little grey old man sitting at a table; and they called to him once or twice, but he did not hear: however, they called a third time, and then he rose and came out to them.

events.title: The Old Man's Hospitality and the First Perilous Task
detailed_summary: The old man, without uttering a word, took them by the hand and led them to a splendid table laden with a variety of fine foods.
After they had satisfied their hunger and thirst, he individually showed each brother to a bed-chamber for the night.
The following morning, the old man approached the eldest brother.
He guided the eldest to a marble table on which lay three tablets detailing the methods to disenchant the castle.
The first tablet described the initial challenge: to locate one thousand pearls belonging to the king's daughter, which were hidden beneath moss in the nearby wood.
It carried a dire warning: if even a single pearl was not found by sunset, the person undertaking the search would be transformed into marble.

events.title: The Elder Brothers' Failure and Petrification
detailed_summary: The eldest brother commenced his search for the pearls, diligently looking throughout the entire day.
However, as evening approached, he had not managed to find even the initial one hundred pearls.
Consequently, as the tablet had forewarned, he was turned into stone.
The next day, the second brother took on the challenge.
His attempt was no more successful than his elder brother's; he was only able to locate the second hundred pearls.
Therefore, he too suffered the same fate and was transformed into stone.

events.title: The Dwarf's Success: The Pearls Found with Ants' Aid
detailed_summary: Finally, it was the little dwarf's turn to attempt the task of finding the pearls.
He searched in the moss, but the pearls were extremely difficult to find, and the effort quickly became overwhelming.
Feeling disheartened by the daunting task, he sat down on a stone and began to weep.
As he sat there crying, the king of the ants, whose life the dwarf had previously saved, arrived with a legion of five thousand ants to assist him.
Through the collective effort of the ants, it did not take long for all one thousand pearls to be located and gathered together in a pile.

events.title: The Dwarf's Success: Identifying the Princess with the Bee's Guidance
detailed_summary: The third task was presented as the most challenging: to select the youngest and finest of the king's three daughters.
All three princesses possessed great beauty and were identical in appearance, making visual distinction impossible.

The dwarf received a crucial piece of information: the eldest daughter had eaten a piece of sugar, the middle one some sweet syrup, and the youngest a spoonful of honey; he had to identify the one who consumed the honey.
At this juncture, the queen of the bees, whom the dwarf had saved from the fire, arrived to help him.
The queen bee flew to each of the three princesses and delicately touched their lips.
She finally came to rest on the lips of the princess who had eaten the honey, thereby revealing to the dwarf which one was the youngest.

events.text_segment:

Now they were all beautiful, and all exactly alike: but he was told that the eldest had eaten a piece of sugar, the next some sweet syrup, and the youngest a spoonful of honey; so he was to guess which it was that had eaten the honey.
Then came the queen of the bees, who had been saved by the little dwarf from the fire, and she tried the lips of all three; but at last she sat upon the lips of the one that had eaten the honey: and so the dwarf knew which was the youngest.

events.title: The Spell Broken and Joyful Resolutions
characters: All who had been turned into stones
detailed_summary: Upon the dwarf's correct identification of the princess, the enchantment that lay upon the castle was immediately broken.
Everyone who had been transformed into stone awakened and reverted to their natural forms.
The little dwarf married the youngest and most virtuous of the princesses.
Following the death of her father, the dwarf ascended to the throne and became king.
His two elder brothers, in turn, married the other two sisters.

events.title: The Honest Shoemaker's Hardship and Pious Preparation
detailed_summary: An honest and hardworking shoemaker faced extreme poverty, with only enough leather left for a single pair of shoes.
He meticulously cut the leather, preparing it for the next day's work, intending to rise early for the task.
Despite his troubles, he maintained a clear conscience and a light heart, entrusting his worries to divine providence before peacefully going to sleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once a shoemaker, who worked very hard and was very honest: but still he could not earn enough to live upon; and at last all he had in the world was gone, save just leather enough to make one pair of shoes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His conscience was clear and his heart light amidst all his troubles; so he went peaceably to bed, left all his cares to Heaven, and soon fell asleep.

events.text_segment:
There was once a shoemaker, who worked very hard and was very honest: but still he could not earn enough to live upon; and at last all he had in the world was gone, save just leather enough to make one pair of shoes.
Then he cut his leather out, all ready to make up the next day, meaning to rise early in the morning to his work. His conscience was clear and his heart light amidst all his troubles; so he went peaceably to bed, left all his cares to Heaven, and soon fell asleep.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
There was once a shoemaker, who worked very hard and was very honest: but still he could not earn enough to live upon; and at last all he had in the world was gone, save just leather enough to make one pair of shoes.

He took out his last piece of leather, and cut it out very carefully, intending to make a fine pair of shoes the next day. He laid the leather on his work-table, and then, feeling very tired, he went to bed, trusting that divine Providence would take care of him.

He was a man of a good conscience, and he went to sleep with a light heart, and did not worry about his troubles. Early the next morning, he got up and began to work again, and when he had finished the shoes, he was surprised to find that they were the most beautiful and perfect shoes he had ever made.

People who saw them admired them very much, and he was able to sell them at a good price. From that time, his luck changed, and he became prosperous, always remembering to be honest and to trust in divine Providence.

events.title: A Cycle of Prosperity Through Unseen Aid
detailed_summary: That very day, a customer was so pleased with the miraculous shoes that he paid more than the usual price.
This enabled the shoemaker to purchase enough leather for two more pairs.
He cut the leather in the evening, planning to work on it the next day, but again found the shoes completed by morning.
Buyers quickly purchased these shoes, providing him with enough money for leather for four more pairs.
This pattern continued: leather prepared in the evening was transformed into finished shoes by morning.
As a result, the shoemaker's financial situation steadily improved, and he became prosperous once more.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He cut out the work again overnight and found it done in the morning, as before; and so it went on for some time: what was got ready in the evening was always done by daybreak, and the good man soon became thriving and well off again.

events.text_segment: The same day a customer came in, and the shoes suited him so well that he willingly paid a price higher than usual for them; and the poor shoemaker, with the money, bought leather enough to make two pairs more. In the evening he cut out the work, and went to bed early, that he might get up and begin betimes next day; but he was saved all the trouble, for when he got up in the morning the work was done ready to his hand. Soon in came buyers, who paid him handsomely for his goods, so that he bought leather enough for four pair more. He cut out the work again overnight and found it done in the morning, as before; and so it went on for some time: what was got ready in the evening was always done by daybreak, and the good man soon became thriving and well off again.

events.title: The Decision to Uncover the Secret Helpers
detailed_summary: One evening around Christmas, while the shoemaker and his wife were conversing by the fire, he expressed a wish to stay awake that night to identify his mysterious helpers.
His wife found the idea appealing.
They decided to leave a light burning and conceal themselves behind a curtain in the room to observe the night's events.

events.title: The Revelation of the Elfin Shoemakers
detailed_summary: Precisely at midnight, two small, unclothed dwarfs entered the room.
They seated themselves at the shoemaker's bench and immediately began working on the pre-cut leather.
The dwarfs worked with astonishing speed and dexterity, stitching, rapping, and tapping with their tiny fingers.
The shoemaker watched in complete wonder, unable to divert his gaze from their industrious activity.
The dwarfs finished all the shoes, leaving them ready on the table, well before the break of day.
They then departed with the swiftness of lightning.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As soon as it was midnight, there came in two little naked dwarfs; and they sat themselves upon the shoemaker’s bench, took up all the work that was cut out, and began to ply with their little fingers, stitching and rapping and tapping away at such a rate, that the shoemaker was all wonder, and could not take his eyes off them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This was long before daybreak; and then they bustled away as quick as lightning.

events.text_segment: As soon as it was midnight, there came in two little naked dwarfs; and they sat themselves upon the shoemaker’s bench, took up all the work that was cut out, and began to ply with their little fingers, stitching and rapping and tapping away at such a rate, that the shoemaker was all wonder, and could not take his eyes off them. And on they went, till the job was quite done, and the shoes stood ready for use upon the table. This was long before daybreak; and then they bustled away as quick as lightning.

events.title: A Plan of Gratitude: Clothing the Elves
detailed_summary: The next day, the shoemaker's wife remarked on how these small beings had brought them wealth and suggested they should show their gratitude by doing something kind for them in return.
She expressed her sadness at seeing them run about without any clothes, considering it improper and noting they would be cold.
She proposed a specific plan: she would sew a shirt, a coat and waistcoat, and a pair of trousers for each of them.
She then suggested that her husband, the shoemaker, should craft a tiny pair of shoes for each dwarf.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next day the wife said to the shoemaker. ‘These little wights have made us rich, and we ought to be thankful to them, and do them a good turn if we can.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I’ll tell you what, I will make each of them a shirt, and a coat and waistcoat, and a pair of pantaloons into the bargain; and do you make each of them a little pair of shoes.’

events.text_segment: The next day the wife said to the shoemaker. ‘These little wights have made us rich, and we ought to be thankful to them, and do them a good turn if we can. I am quite sorry to see them run about as they do; and indeed it is not very decent, for they have nothing upon their backs to keep off the cold. I’ll tell you what, I will make each of them a shirt, and a coat and waistcoat, and a pair of pantaloons into the bargain; and do you make each of them a little pair of shoes.’

events.title: The Elves' Joyful Acceptance of Gifts and Their Departure
detailed_summary: The shoemaker was greatly pleased with his wife's compassionate idea.
One evening, when all the miniature garments and shoes were ready, they carefully placed these items on the table instead of the usual cut-out leather.
The shoemaker and his wife then hid themselves again to observe how the little elves would react.
Around midnight, the elves entered, joyfully dancing and skipping about the room, before preparing to sit down to their usual work.
However, upon seeing the clothes laid out for them, they laughed and chuckled, appearing immensely delighted.
They dressed themselves in the new outfits in an instant.
Filled with extreme joy, they danced, capered, and leaped about with great merriment.
Finally, their joyful dance led them out of the door and they vanished across the green.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The thought pleased the good cobbler very much; and one evening, when all the things were ready, they laid them on the table, instead of the work that they used to cut out, and then went and hid themselves, to watch what the little elves would do.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they dressed themselves in the twinkling of an eye, and danced and capered and sprang about, as merry as could be; till at last they danced out at the door, and away over the green.

events.text_segment:
The thought pleased the good cobbler very much; and one evening, when all the things were ready, they laid them on the table, instead of the work that they used to cut out, and then went and hid themselves, to watch what the little elves would do.
About midnight in they came, dancing and skipping, hopped round the room, and then went to sit down to their work as usual; but when they saw the clothes lying for them, they laughed and chuckled, and seemed mightily delighted.
Then they dressed themselves in the twinkling of an eye, and danced and capered and sprang about, as merry as could be; till at last they danced out at the door, and away over the green.

events.title: Lasting Prosperity and the Elves' Final Absence
detailed_summary: The shoemaker and his wife never encountered the little elves again after that night.
Despite the elves' absence, the couple's good fortune persisted, and they continued to live prosperously for the rest of their days.

events.title: The Childless Couple's Wish and the First Wife's Fate
detailed_summary: A prosperous man and his beloved, beautiful wife lived long ago, their happiness marred only by their lack of children.
Despite the wife's fervent prayers day and night, they remained childless.
A juniper tree grew in the courtyard before their house.
One winter day, as the wife peeled apples beneath this tree, she cut her finger, and drops of her blood fell onto the snow.
Seeing this, she sighed and wished for a child as red as blood and as white as snow.
Instantly, her heart felt lighter, as if her wish were on the verge of fulfillment, and she returned indoors, comforted.
The seasons changed: snow melted, the earth turned green, trees budded, grew dense with leaves, and then their blossoms fell.
The wife once again stood under the juniper tree, now heavy with a sweet fragrance that made her heart leap; overcome with joy, she knelt.
As the fruit ripened, she felt peaceful; but after eagerly eating the ripe berries, she became ill and sorrowful.
Weeping, she told her husband that if she were to die, she wished to be buried under the juniper tree.
She then felt reassured and happy again, and within a month, she bore a child who was indeed as white as snow and as red as blood.
The sight of her child brought her such immense joy that she died.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Long, long ago, some two thousand years or so, there lived a rich man with a good and beautiful wife.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her joy was so great that she died.

events.text_segment:
Long, long ago, some two thousand years or so, there lived a rich man with a good and beautiful wife. They loved each other dearly, but sorrowed much that they had no children. So greatly did they desire to have one, that the wife prayed for it day and night, but still they remained childless.
In front of the house there was a court, in which grew a juniper-tree. One winter’s day the wife stood under the tree to peel some apples, and as she was peeling them, she cut her finger, and the blood fell on the snow. ‘Ah,’ sighed the woman heavily, ‘if I had but a child, as red as blood and as white as snow,’ and as she spoke the words, her heart grew light within her, and it seemed to her that her wish was granted, and she returned to the house feeling glad and comforted. A month passed, and the snow had all disappeared; then another month went by, and all the earth was green. So the months followed one another, and first the trees budded in the woods, and soon the green branches grew thickly intertwined, and then the blossoms began to fall. Once again the wife stood under the juniper-tree, and it was so full of sweet scent that her heart leaped for joy, and she was so overcome with her happiness, that she fell on her knees. Presently the fruit became round and firm, and she was glad and at peace; but when they were fully ripe she picked the berries and ate eagerly of them, and then she grew sad and ill. A little while later she called her husband, and said to him, weeping. ‘If I die, bury me under the juniper-tree.’ Then she felt comforted and happy again, and before another month had passed she had a little child, and when she saw that it was as white as snow and as red as blood, her joy was so great that she died.

They had a lovely daughter, who was the joy of their lives. The girl was kind and gentle, with a heart full of love and a face that shone like the morning sun. As she grew older, her beauty and goodness became known throughout the land, and many suitors came to seek her hand in marriage. But her parents wished for her to marry someone worthy of her noble spirit.

One day, a prince from a distant kingdom heard of her beauty and virtue. He traveled many days and nights to meet her, bringing with him gifts and promises of a happy life together. The girl and the prince quickly fell in love, and her parents, seeing her happiness, gave their blessing.

However, a wicked sorcerer, jealous of the girl’s happiness, cast a spell upon her, turning her into a swan by day and a maiden by night. The prince was heartbroken and searched far and wide for a way to break the spell. He learned that only a true love’s kiss, given with a pure heart, could restore her.

The prince, determined and brave, ventured into the sorcerer’s dark forest, facing many dangers and challenges. At last, he found the sorcerer’s lair and, with courage and love, defeated him. Returning to the girl, he kissed her with all his heart. The spell was broken, and she was restored to her human form.

They lived happily ever after, their love stronger than any magic, and their story became a legend told for generations, reminding all of the power of true love and the importance of kindness and bravery.

events.title: The Second Wife's Jealousy and Cruelty Towards the Boy
detailed_summary: The husband buried his first wife under the juniper tree, mourning her deeply.
Gradually, his sorrow lessened, and though he still grieved at times, he resumed his normal life and eventually remarried.
His second wife bore him a little daughter.
The child from his first wife was a boy, as red as blood and as white as snow.
The new mother loved her own daughter immensely, but looking at the boy, she felt a pang of resentment, believing he would impede her daughter's inheritance.
She became increasingly consumed by the desire to secure the entire property for her child.
This wicked thought grew stronger, leading her to treat the boy with great unkindness, constantly driving him away with abuse.
The poor child lived in constant fear, finding no respite from her cruelty between leaving for school and returning.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Her husband buried her under the juniper-tree, and wept bitterly for her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She drove him from place to place with cuffings and buffetings, so that the poor child went about in fear, and had no peace from the time he left school to the time he went back.

events.text_segment:
Her husband buried her under the juniper-tree, and wept bitterly for her. By degrees, however, his sorrow grew less, and although at times he still grieved over his loss, he was able to go about as usual, and later on he married again.
He now had a little daughter born to him; the child of his first wife was a boy, who was as red as blood and as white as snow. The mother loved her daughter very much, and when she looked at her and then looked at the boy, it pierced her heart to think that he would always stand in the way of her own child, and she was continually thinking how she could get the whole of the property for her. This evil thought took possession of her more and more, and made her behave very unkindly to the boy. She drove him from place to place with cuffings and buffetings, so that the poor child went about in fear, and had no peace from the time he left school to the time he went back.

The new wife loved her own daughter dearly, but when she looked at the boy, a pang of resentment stirred within her, for she feared he might inherit her husband's estate and threaten her own child's future. The boy lived in constant fear, finding no peace between leaving for school and returning home, as her cruelty cast a shadow over his young life.

events.title: The Stepmother Murders the Boy
detailed_summary: One day, the little daughter asked her mother for an apple while in the store-room.
The mother gave her a beautiful apple from a chest that had a very heavy lid and a large iron lock.
The daughter then asked if her brother could also have an apple.
This angered the mother, though she concealed it, replying that he could have one when he returned from school.
Just then, seeing the boy approaching through the window, an evil impulse seemed to possess her; she snatched the apple from her daughter, declaring the brother should not have one before him.
She threw the apple into the chest and closed it.
When the little boy entered, the evil spirit prompted his stepmother to ask him kindly if he wanted an apple, even as she gave him a malevolent look.
The boy commented on her dreadful appearance but agreed, asking for an apple.
The thought to kill him then came to her.
She told him to come with her, lifted the chest's lid, and instructed him to take an apple for himself.
As the boy bent over into the chest, the evil spirit urged her, and she slammed the heavy lid down, decapitating him.
Overwhelmed by fear and the gravity of her act, she immediately thought of how to conceal it.
She went to her room, retrieved a white handkerchief, carefully repositioned the boy's head on his shoulders, and bound it with the handkerchief to hide the injury.
Finally, she placed him on a chair by the door, with an apple in his hand.

events.text_segment:
One day the little daughter came running to her mother in the store-room, and said, ‘Mother, give me an apple.’ ‘Yes, my child,’ said the wife, and she gave her a beautiful apple out of the chest; the chest had a very heavy lid and a large iron lock.
‘Mother,’ said the little daughter again, ‘may not brother have one too?’ The mother was angry at this, but she answered, ‘Yes, when he comes out of school.’
Just then she looked out of the window and saw him coming, and it seemed as if an evil spirit entered into her, for she snatched the apple out of her little daughter’s hand, and said, ‘You shall not have one before your brother.’ She threw the apple into the chest and shut it to. The little boy now came in, and the evil spirit in the wife made her say kindly to him, ‘My son, will you have an apple?’ but she gave him a wicked look. ‘Mother,’ said the boy, ‘how dreadful you look! Yes, give me an apple.’ The thought came to her that she would kill him. ‘Come with me,’ she said, and she lifted up the lid of the chest; ‘take one out for yourself.’ And as he bent over to do so, the evil spirit urged her, and crash! down went the lid, and off went the little boy’s head. Then she was overwhelmed with fear at the thought of what she had done. ‘If only I can prevent anyone knowing that I did it,’ she thought. So she went upstairs to her room, and took a white handkerchief out of her top drawer; then she set the boy’s head again on his shoulders, and bound it with the handkerchief so that nothing could be seen, and placed him on a chair by the door with an apple in his hand.

events.title: The Gruesome Cover-up: Marleen's Discovery and the Deceived Father
detailed_summary: Shortly after, little Marleen approached her mother, who was by the fire stirring boiling water, and reported that her brother was sitting by the door looking pale and did not respond when she asked for his apple, which frightened her.
Her mother instructed her to go to him again and, if he still didn't answer, to give him a box on the ear.
Marleen went to her brother and asked for the apple; when he remained silent, she struck him on the ear, causing his head to roll off.
Utterly terrified, she ran crying and screaming to her mother, exclaiming that she had knocked off her brother's head, and wept inconsolably.
Her mother admonished her, stating that what she had done was terrible but that no one must know, so she must remain silent, as what's done cannot be undone.
The mother then declared they would make him into puddings.
She proceeded to take the little boy, cut him up, prepare him as puddings, and put him in the pot.
Marleen stood by, weeping continuously, her tears falling into the pot, making salt unnecessary.
When the father came home and sat for dinner, he asked where his son was.
The mother, without answering, served him a large dish of black pudding, while Marleen continued to weep ceaselessly.
The father asked again about his son.
The wife then lied, claiming the boy had gone to the country to visit his mother's great uncle and would stay there for some time.
When the father questioned why he left without saying goodbye, the wife explained that he enjoyed being there, had told her he'd be away for six weeks, and was being well cared for.
The husband expressed his unhappiness and unease, feeling the boy should have bid him farewell.
He continued eating his dinner, asking Marleen why she wept and assuring her that her brother would soon return.
He then requested more pudding from his wife and, as he ate, tossed the bones under the table.

events.text_segment:
Soon after this, little Marleen came up to her mother who was stirring a pot of boiling water over the fire, and said, ‘Mother, brother is sitting by the door with an apple in his hand, and he looks so pale; and when I asked him to give me the apple, he did not answer, and that frightened me.’
‘Go to him again,’ said her mother, ‘and if he does not answer, give him a box on the ear.’ So little Marleen went, and said, ‘Brother, give me that apple,’ but he did not say a word; then she gave him a box on the ear, and his head rolled off. She was so terrified at this, that she ran crying and screaming to her mother. ‘Oh!’ she said, ‘I have knocked off brother’s head,’ and then she wept and wept, and nothing would stop her.
‘What have you done!’ said her mother, ‘but no one must know about it, so you must keep silence; what is done can’t be undone; we will make him into puddings.’ And she took the little boy and cut him up, made him into puddings, and put him in the pot. But Marleen stood looking on, and wept and wept, and her tears fell into the pot, so that there was no need of salt.
Presently the father came home and sat down to his dinner; he asked, ‘Where is my son?’ The mother said nothing, but gave him a large dish of black pudding, and Marleen still wept without ceasing.
The father again asked, ‘Where is my son?’
‘Oh,’ answered the wife, ‘he is gone into the country to his mother’s great uncle; he is going to stay there some time.’
‘What has he gone there for, and he never even said goodbye to me!’
‘Well, he likes being there, and he told me he should be away quite six weeks; he is well looked after there.’
‘I feel very unhappy about it,’ said the husband, ‘in case it should not be all right, and he ought to have said goodbye to me.’
With this he went on with his dinner, and said, ‘Little Marleen, why do you weep? Brother will soon be back.’ Then he asked his wife for more pudding, and as he ate, he threw the bones under the table.

events.title: The Boy's Transformation into a Bird at the Juniper Tree
detailed_summary: Little Marleen went to her room, took her finest silk handkerchief from her drawer, and used it to gather all the bones from under the table, weeping all the while.
She carried them outside and laid them in the green grass beneath the juniper tree.
As soon as she had done this, her sadness seemed to lift, and she stopped weeping.
The juniper tree then began to stir, its branches moving back and forth, apart and then together, as if joyfully clapping.
A mist enveloped the tree, and within the mist, a fire-like burning appeared.
Out of this fire, a beautiful bird emerged, soaring high into the air, singing magnificently.
When the bird was no longer visible, the juniper tree stood as it was before, and both the silk handkerchief and the bones had vanished.
Little Marleen then felt as lighthearted and happy as if her brother were still alive.
She returned to the house, sat down cheerfully at the table, and ate.

events.text_segment:
Little Marleen went upstairs and took her best silk handkerchief out of her bottom drawer, and in it she wrapped all the bones from under the table and carried them outside, and all the time she did nothing but weep. Then she laid them in the green grass under the juniper-tree, and she had no sooner done so, then all her sadness seemed to leave her, and she wept no more. And now the juniper-tree began to move, and the branches waved backwards and forwards, first away from one another, and then together again, as it might be someone clapping their hands for joy. After this a mist came round the tree, and in the midst of it there was a burning as of fire, and out of the fire there flew a beautiful bird, that rose high into the air, singing magnificently, and when it could no more be seen, the juniper-tree stood there as before, and the silk handkerchief and the bones were gone.
Little Marleen now felt as lighthearted and happy as if her brother were still alive, and she went back to the house and sat down cheerfully to the table and ate.
